postContent:
On this Earth Day, we want to highlight the incredible work of Fellows from our global mycelium who are exemplifying Earth-centred leadership in all that they do. Here are just a few amazing projects that have come to life in recent months:

ğŸŒ€ Fellow Heather Knight has co-developed TENDING TO ENDINGS, a card deck for reimagining our relationship to endings. Drawing on the garden as a metaphor, this deck offers imaginative yet grounded ways to navigate difficult terrain. Learn more at https://lnkd.in/eTfPTRZi

ğŸª¶ Fellows Rachel Musson and Holly Everett have continued to develop their Triple WellBeing framework through their organisation, ThoughtBox Education. They are now offering several practitioner and leadership courses to bring the framework to educators across the UK and beyond. Learn more at https://lnkd.in/eEb-wjQ8

ğŸŒ¾ Fellow Gina Maffey has launched The Reeding Room, a monthly online book club in dialogue with the natural world. Each month features a book or a theme, and there is a monthly Zoom call, sometimes with special guests, to discuss the topic at hand. Learn more and join here: https://lnkd.in/ewrEErBP

And finally, hereâ€™s a brilliant list of podcasts created and hosted by Bio-Leadership Fellows!

postContent:
Wow. Just yesterday we held a session in the Bio-Leadership Fellowship on Facing Uncertainty and Building Resilience. One of our guests, the brilliant Andy Middleton, shared how the risks that are coming to the world are equivalent to a category 5 or 6 white water rafting event - the most severely difficult and challenging types of water to navigate. But much of society is still thinking about them as category 1 or 2 risks. 

Are we having a big enough conversation about preparation for risks and building resilience? 

Yesterday the US stopped funding a body that assesses climate risks. What form of thinking stops the alarm and intelligence systems on severe risks to a whole society?: https://lnkd.in/e5kyi_qr 

We continue our module on resilience today - working on how natural systems stay resilient, then going deeper into how to stay personally resilient in tough times. 

More recently Iâ€™ve been doing more work on resilience, including workshops with Patagonia in Europe, on resilience and integrity. 

Iâ€™d love to help more people connect with these themes if they are of interest. I very much plan to stay connected with Andy and others on how to support more conversations and actions on resilience closer to home. A huge inspiration from Andy - letâ€™s not be afraid to be honest about whatâ€™s needed and frame big intentions about what we can do. 

Watch this space and do please reach out if resilience is something on your mind.

#resilience
#systems

postContent:
We're helping to deliver the UK's third Dutch-Style Roundabout! 

Featured by BBC News, we are project managing these Section 278 works at Westgate Roundabout in Chichester. The roundabout will open later this month. 

Andrea O'Shea, project manager for the works, told the BBC: "The roundabout gives priority to non-motorised users, it will have a dedicated lane for cyclists who will have priority over cars. The concept comes from the Netherlands and has been brought across to try and improve cycle facilities in the UK. The completed scheme should actually not have a significant impact on traffic."

You can read the full BBC article here - https://lnkd.in/eCrVXRWv

And you can watch a flythrough of the roundabout on our YouTube channel - https://lnkd.in/ebyvHM5Y

postContent:
Pendennis are proud to announce that our latest bespoke build, the explorer motor yacht FOX is a BOAT International World Superyacht Awards finalist. The team are looking forward to the awards ceremony in Venice in May.
 
Proudly British, FOX hails from the drawing boards of Q London, with Pendennis responsible for her engineering and construction. Foxâ€™s striking exterior design is muscular and practical in appearance, and her beach-house style interiors are bright and modern.
 
Key to her design is the 103.5sqm (1,114sqft) main deck aft, which enables her to carry a huge range of equipment, from water toys and two 7.5m (24.6ft) tenders to amphibious vehicles and submersibles, launched by two 2.5T SWL deck cranes - carrying capacity usually unheard of in a yacht of this size. FOXâ€™s main aft deck has endless possibilities for relaxation and entertainment, sheâ€™s a true explorer yacht of Northern European quality.
 
Catch FOX at the Palm Beach International Boat Show, where she will be exhibiting with her central agents Burgess in the Palm Harbor Marina. FOXâ€™s berth location will be E111. A team from Pendennis will be in Palm Beach onboard. 

Contact info@pendennis.com to arrange an appointment to view FOX.

BOAT International Media 
Burgess

postContent:
Successionâ€¦â€¦It doesnâ€™t have to be, and more importantly shouldnâ€™t be, like an episode of this series. (which I love btw)

Succession = Progress = Growth = Opportunity

Too often people use this word to only talk about Director or Shareholder levels in business but it is so much more.

As we have grown mustard | B Corpâ„¢ weâ€™ve worked super hard to work on succession planning at all levels through the business. We encourage and want everyone thinking about how they can scale and add to their part of the business and ultimately move to their next role, pulling people up behind them.

Whether its Talent Partner to Mentor/Lead Consultant, Senior Consultant to Team Leader, Or Associate Director to Director Level. If you have a growth mindset, are selfless with your time and ultimately mentor the next you to come through, you will be going along way to create the opportunity for your next role.

Weâ€™ve had some big moves across our team over the last 6 months and there will be more to comeâ€¦..

Soâ€¦if you are 3 to 12 months into recruitment, love the industry but your day to day is battling for attention in a toxic environment like an episode of Successionâ€¦. Drop our internal recruitment legend a line Imogen Shelleyâ€¦ weâ€™d love to hear from you!

p.s Roman Roy is ğŸ”¥ğŸ˜‚

#succession #recruitment #growth #people

postContent:
Weâ€™ve been waiting for the best time formally to announce this. First we had Nicks OBE trip then Dr. Paul Stewart tour of Poland to tell everyone about. But now seems perfect - as it should be for Nick Gazzard OBE who is one of the best guys and a fantastic personal friend & support to us all. 

We are honoured to welcome Nick Gazzard OBE as a Safeguarding Fundamentals Ambassador.

Nickâ€™s unwavering commitment to safeguarding and violence prevention has profoundly impacted countless lives. As the founder of the Hollie Gazzard Trust, established in memory of his daughter Hollie, Nick has dedicated himself to raising awareness about domestic abuse and stalking. The Trustâ€™s initiatives, including educational workshops and the development of the Hollie Guard personal safety app, have empowered individuals and communities across the UK to recognise the signs of abuse and take proactive measures to stay safe .

Nick shared:

â€œIt is an honour to become an Ambassador for Safeguarding Fundamentals. This initiative is a transformative step toward ensuring the safety and well-being of children across all organisations. Safeguarding Fundamentals embodies a commitment to creating environments where children are protected, respected, and given the opportunity to thrive. As someone deeply invested in creating a safer future, I believe this cause is not just worthwhile but essential. Every child needs to feel supported, valued, and safe.â€

Having Nick join the #TeamSGF movement amplifies our collective voice. His lived experience, advocacy, and leadership are invaluable as we strive to change the culture of safeguarding.

Together, we can make safeguarding simpler, more human, and rooted in shared responsibility.

Kim Hart (Collins) Richard Gardner Karen Leach Gary Cliffe Gary Dack 

#TeamSGF #Safeguarding #Leadership #ChildSafety #SGFAmbassador #NickGazzardOBE #HollieGazzardTrust
author: Safeguarding Fundamentals

ğ—–ğ—µğ—®ğ—¿ğ—¶ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—²ğ˜€, ğ—¶ğ—³ ğ˜†ğ—¼ğ˜‚â€™ğ—¿ğ—² ğ—²ğ˜…ğ—½ğ—²ğ—°ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ ğ˜†ğ—¼ğ˜‚ğ—¿ ğ—³ğ˜‚ğ—»ğ—±ğ—¿ğ—®ğ—¶ğ˜€ğ—²ğ—¿ğ˜€ ğ˜ğ—¼ ğ—¿ğ—²ğ˜€ğ—°ğ˜‚ğ—² ğ˜†ğ—¼ğ˜‚ ğ—³ğ—¿ğ—¼ğ—º ğ˜†ğ—¼ğ˜‚ğ—¿ ğ—³ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—®ğ—»ğ—°ğ—¶ğ—®ğ—¹ ğ—½ğ—¿ğ—¼ğ—¯ğ—¹ğ—²ğ—ºğ˜€ â€“ ğ—¸ğ—»ğ—¼ğ˜„ ğ˜ğ—µğ—¶ğ˜€:

As a charity YOU control the majority of the fundraising process.Â Â Followed by the funders.

The fundraisers have the least control over the process. 

ğŸ“Œ Because fundraisers match, coordinate and communicate what ALREADY exists.
 
Charities control "what" the funders fund - and funders control "how, why and when" they fund it.

ğ—œğ—»ğ˜ğ—²ğ—¿ğ—»ğ—®ğ—¹ğ—¹ğ˜†, ğ—³ğ˜‚ğ—»ğ—±ğ—¿ğ—®ğ—¶ğ˜€ğ—²ğ—¿ğ˜€:

Match your charity with donors â€“ based on your impact evidence.
â†ªï¸ weak to no impact evidence = poor matching.

Invite donors to join you in changing the world over the short and long term â€“ based on your track record and your future ability to deliver change.
â†ªï¸ no real ability to change the world/compelling vision = unappealing invitation/ask.

Deliver a wonderful donor experience, so funders stick around and recommend you to other funders â€“ based on your stewardship and relationship building opportunities.
â†ªï¸ Too few opportunities to deepen the relationship = too few reasons for donors to stick around.

ğ—˜ğ˜…ğ˜ğ—²ğ—¿ğ—»ğ—®ğ—¹ğ—¹ğ˜† ğ—³ğ˜‚ğ—»ğ—±ğ—¿ğ—®ğ—¶ğ˜€ğ—²ğ—¿ğ˜€:

Identify which donors already believe in your cause â€“ based on their funding criteria or past activities.
â†ªï¸ Donors allow fundraisers in or keep them out = limited accessibility to networks limits identifying best fit donors.

Engage donors in conversation to determine interest, value of potential partnership and timing â€“ based on the donorsâ€™ predetermined goals, budgets and timelines.
â†ªï¸ Donors determine the parameters = no alignment evidence, no detailed budgets or a need to rush the donation stops engagement before it can even start.

Asks for a donation when it is appropriate to do so - based on the donorsâ€™ timeline.
â†ªï¸ Donors have multiple timelines = having one timeline (money in by the end of the financial year) makes your fundraisers out of sync.

Steward the donors to deepen the relationship for long term funding â€“ based on meeting their needs in proportion to the value of the donation given.
â†ªï¸ Donors judge the quality of their experience = not enjoying the relationship means there's no need to stick around or give again. 

Charities you need to be fundraising ready or willing to listen to fundraisers to make you so. 

Do you have:

âœ… A compelling vision
âœ… The ability to deliver (and evidence) how you change the world
âœ… Access to funding networks to engage and invite funders to join you (if not see me) ğŸ˜€
âœ… Flexibility to fundraise in and out of this financial year 
âœ… The ability to deepen donor relationships 

What you do have is:

author: Michelle Benson

postContent:
A common complaint charity CEOs have is that their trustees don't help. I've frequently been told- 'they do nothing apart from going to meetings'. 

I've  been a CEO for over 20 years and served as a trustee and chair for several charities, so I've seen both sides. Part of the reason for this is that they're not asked and supported to help in the right way. 

What I've found really useful is to encourage my trustees to be external Ambassadors ('cos I can't be everywhere), to open up opportunities. So I thought I'd share some things I've learned that worked well.

1. Be clear - put the requirement to act as an external Ambassador in the trustee role description
2. Reframe - be clear that you're not asking them to fundraise ("it's not asking for cash"); instead they are influencing and sharing the passion for your cause.
3. Train them - on charity story-telling, elevator pitch, your theory of change and heart-warming case studies - keeping it personal
4. Tool them - give them your killer stats, no. of people helped, your outcome figures - so they're readily to hand to explain your impact - and encourage them to share these in their networks.
5. Support them ongoing - chat informally, agenda item at board meetings, celebrate successes, thank them in-person & newsletters.

Remember: Being visible creates trust. Trust creates opportunity. Opportunity opens doors.

Once a new opportunity has been opened, the follow-through is handled by the CEO, who keeps the trustees looped in.

I hope this helps - let me know if this has worked for you.

postContent:
Well done to all the regional candidates for a closely run race and congratulations to Helen Godwin.

As results roll in across the UK, from regional mayors to local councillors, what's clear is our political landscape is evolving. 

Whether or not you agree with the new options, having more choice is good for democracy. It keeps established parties active and alert, and gives voters more say in shaping the future they want to see. 

The Runcorn by-election, where just four votes separate the top two candidates leading to a recount is a powerful reminder: every vote really does count and donâ€™t let anyone tell you otherwise.

As the Skunk Anansie lyric goes, "we love your apathy"; never forget to show up.

Always make your voice heard.

#WestOfEngland #WEMayorVote #TurnUpToVote #NoVoteNoVoice #MakeItCount #MyVoteMyVoice #LocalElections2025
author: Emma Harvey

postContent:
Only a few days to go until polling day, 1st May, when the West of England gets to decide who's their next regional mayor for the combined authority. 

Please don't believe this is a powerless post. This role weilds significant devolved powers and they're able to make strategic decisions locally from central government. 

This is a directly elected role that will oversee key areas such as transport, housing, strategic planning and adult education. The combined authority manages millions of pounds of investment and they're also able to lever more funds by working with cross-sector stakeholders from across Bristol, Bath and North East Somerset, and South Gloucestershire councils 

WECA has the power to develop local transport plans, allocate grants to councils and develop and impliment strategies to shape areas such as development, enterprise and cultural opportunities.

The polls are super close - so vote with your hearts and your heads. 

Hear what the candidates have to say, here:

https://lnkd.in/eyBgxkP5

Your candidates are: Helen Godwin Arron Banks Steve Smith Oli Henman Mary Page Ian Scott

postContent:
Some of my best hires weren't the "perfect candidates."

But they turned out to be the best hires. 

I have interviewed over 5,000 candidates.
And I can tell you that most skills can be taught. 

The best hires come from different places. 
And, they don't always have the best resumes. 

These things are more important than experience:

âœ… CuriosityÂ to keep learning
âœ… DriveÂ to go above and beyond
âœ… AdaptabilityÂ to grow with the role
âœ… CollaborationÂ to work well with others
âœ… EmpathyÂ to understand and connect with others 
âœ… AccountabilityÂ to take ownership and follow through
âœ… Self-motivationÂ to stay proactive and get things done 
âœ… CreativityÂ to bring fresh ideas and solutions to the table
âœ… IntegrityÂ to do the right thing, even when no oneâ€™s watching
âœ… ResilienceÂ to handle challenges and setbacks with a positive attitude

These qualities arenâ€™t always visible on paper.
But they make all the difference once hired.

When hiring, remember that skills can be trained. 
But values and attitudes canâ€™t.

Do you agree?

â™»ï¸Â Repost to advocate for better hiring practices
â• Follow Anna Chernyshova for more posts like this

postContent:
Chronicles of a chronically ill CEO ğŸ“š

One of the toughest challenges I face day-to-day is staying on top of tasks, especially as someone whose mind races a mile a minute with new ideas and as I attempt to juggle many tasks at a time.

This has become even more important now I am growing a team, as I realise the wonderful Fanny Salmon is not a mind reader and also cannot keep up with the thoughts and ideas that are in my head.

Balancing my health and managing projects has been a journey, to say the least. That's why finding efficient processes for Fanny Salmon to seamlessly continue working when I'm unwell, and exploring better ways to approve content, has become essential.

Notion has been a game-changer, gone are the days of hundreds of back and fourths via whatsapp at all hours.

We now have our Human Beauty Hub which keeps everything in one accessible place. I can now approve content on the go and write down all my ideas when I have them without having to disturb anyone in the middle of the night (if i don't write it down when it comes, the idea is gone forever!).

If anyone else can relate to these struggles, I can't recommend Notion enough. If you'd like to give it a try, use the link below to apply for 6 months free access, including unlimited use of their AI.

https://lnkd.in/eBTef4bg

Now, I just need to look at other ways to start organising my brain and digital space! Does anyone have any recommendations or things they do to calm a racing mind or keep their working environment as organised as possible?

#Ad
#ChronicallyIllCEO #SmallBusinessOwner #TeamCollaboration #Notion

postContent:
I donâ€™t normally post on here but I wanted to #sharewithpride.  Iâ€™ve been a nurse for over 20 years but never have I been moved to tears 46 times in a shift...once for every person who left my vaccination pod. Once for every person who had a tale to tell.  Tales of loneliness; of endless months missing family and friends. For 46 people who asked â€œcan I go and hug my grandchildren now or see my friends?â€ Once for every elderly person who hadnâ€™t seen another human for months on end. But most of all for the 87 year old man who when asked if he had any questions before his injection said â€œjust one love. I lost my wife. Will you marry meâ€.  ğŸ¥²ğŸ¥²
Iâ€™m proud to be a nurse and grateful to be able to contribute.  Letâ€™s put an end to this pandemic. Together letâ€™s save lives and protect peopleâ€™s mental health. 
#grateful #hopeforthefuture #mentalillnessawareness

After trying to back out of their commitment to protect millions of fish in the Severn Estuary, EDF is now reconsidering the AFD at Hinkley Point, and we'll be keeping a close eye on their updated proposals.

Our CEO, Mark Lloyd, says:

"We are very pleased to see that EDF is reconsidering and will continue to examine their proposals as they develop. However, any deterrent at Hinkley wonâ€™t be completely effective, so they must also commit to restoring degraded areas of the Severn Estuaryâ€”home to several iconic fish speciesâ€”and improving fish passage in all its connected rivers."

It's not over yet. Add your name to the petition to help keep the pressure on ğŸ‘‡

postContent:
Remember, Remember â€“ BCA hosts Bangers4Ben sale at 3pm on Tuesday 5th November
 
As well as a packed programme of 25 sales offering over 4,100 vehicles at BCA Online tomorrow, the annual Bangers4Ben sale takes place at 3pm, auctioning vehicles that took part in this yearâ€™s international rally with all sale proceeds going to automotive charity, Ben.
 
The 2024 Bangers4Ben rally covered around 1,500 miles across mainland Europe and the Alps, covering some of the best roads and mountain passes that France and Switzerland have to offer.
 
Entrants had to buy their car for no more than Â£750 then theme, paint or decal it before converging on Folkestone last month to embark on the rally in aid of Ben, with funds raised going towards the vital work the charity does for those in need who work or have worked in the motor industry.
 
The Bangers4Ben sale features 20 vehicles from the event, including a 2007 Fiat Scudo van reinvented as Thomas the Tank Engine, a 2006 Mercedes-Benz E320 3.0 saloon carrying C3PO and R2D2 from Star Wars as passengers and a fur lined 2004 MG TF 1.8 Roadster redesigned as Jerry the Mouse, from the famous Hanna-Barbera cartoons.Â Other delights on offer included a 1997 Vauxhall Tigra Marine Coupe styled as Tigger from Winnie the Pooh and a patchwork quilt 2001 Volvo V40 2.0 Estate. 

For more details on the great work done by Ben supporting those in need within the motor industry, visit www.ben.org.uk 
 
To check out the full selection of vehicles in the Bangers4Ben sale as well as all the other vehicles on offer at BCA tomorrow, visit www.bca.co.uk
author: BCA UK

postContent:
An ode to Bangers4Ben #b4b24


At Bangers4Ben 2024, the engines roar,
A race of passion, for a cause we adore.
Rusty old cars, with hearts full of speed,
Each one driven to serve a noble need.

From junkyard dreams to track-side pride,
In every banger, stories collide.
Painted with laughter, covered in grime,
They roll for charity, one lap at a time.

For Ben, the cause, they gather as one,
Through twists and turns, under autumnâ€™s sun.
Not just for victory, but something more,
To lend a helping hand, to open a door.

With wheels that wobble, but spirits strong,
They drive with purpose all day long.
A festival of fun, a tribute to care,
Where community thrives, and memories share.

So hereâ€™s to the racers, the cars that may bend,
At Bangers4Ben, where the journeyâ€™s the end.
2024, a year to be bold,
In engines and hearts, let the stories unfold.

Joel Combes ğŸ¤«ğŸ˜‰ğŸ˜¬

postContent:
206,000 will be living in temporary accommodation by 2029. A shocking stat from Shelter on the front page of The Guardian today. 

This â€˜stopgap accommodationâ€™ can often be rat and mold infested but is becoming home from 2+ years to families up and down the country. As taxpayers, weâ€™re paying loads of money to house people in places that make them sick, remove their hope and diminish their opportunities. 

Yet, anyone in the business of trying to build more housing will likely have been told at a public consultation recently that â€˜we donâ€™t need more homes in [insert name of city, town or village here]â€™. 

What can be done to help?

- Publishing TA stats right alongside housing targets and proposals. The public have to be given the whole picture. 

- Councillors should visit TA at the same time as pre-committee site visits. They should ask themselves, would I want to raise my family here? Are the concerns expressed by the residents against a planning application more of a concern than the living conditions of the TA residents? There is a human cost of turning down applications. 

- Challenge your local representatives to tell you what they are doing to address this issue and vote accordingly. I can guarantee that opponents are asking their representatives the very opposite and doing it quite loudly. Letâ€™s be louder.

#housingcrisis #homelessness
author: Nikki Davies

postContent:
Really enjoyed my chat with Ben Simpson and Joseph Baum yesterday on the Meeting Place and Lichfields UK webinar exploring the Planning and Infrastructure Bill. 

The sheer ambition of it is impressive - got to take your hat off the government to pulling all the leavers they can to make the changes they feel are necessary. 

There are so many changes coming our way with the NPPF, devolution, and now this Bill â€“ is it too much at once â€“ can the creaking system adapt and survive? Can it be done in time to make a difference before we all head back to the ballot box? 

If you tuned in yesterday, you know that implementation of the measures in this bill will take time. 

ğŸ“° Spatial Development Strategies need combined authorities in place, some already do exist of course, but then they need time and resource to be put to their creation. It is unrealistic to think we'll see any within this Parliament. 

ğŸ™‹â€â™€ï¸ Planning committee reform, unlikely to be at the top of the agenda for LPAs who are unsure of whether they will exist in two yearsâ€™ time and the focus of local government's minds on the mammoth task of devolution at the moment should not be underestimated.

However, weâ€™ve seen the mention of â€˜grey beltâ€™ move the dial on some decisions and BNG already felt like policy by the time it was officially ushered in. The intention set by the Bill has the ability to change the course of the sector, way before royal assent. 

Keep an eye out for the details as they come forward in the form of regulation, this is important for things like the implantation of planning fee reform, the national scheme of delegation and the roll out of the Nature Restoration Fund. 

For now, however, let's hope that the overarching message of the Bill is received loud and clear by everyone who has a chance to influence the growth and regeneration of this country. It's time to speed up planning decisions, remove unnecessary blockers and deliver.

#planning #housingcrisis #infrastructure
author: Nikki Davies

postContent:
**Update**
I have just been advised that schuh sell single shoes to their customers, well done Schuh! 

Hoping my network may be able to offer some advice or have contacts who can help.
So what do you do as a 15 year old girl, who has lost her right leg after a battle with bone cancer, when you want to buy running trainers to start getting active again with you newly fitted Ottobock blade which doesn't require a trainer. You only need the left trainer and want to invest in some new ones to start this next chapter of your new life. The dilemma one of my best friends daughters had last week

Let me share the story with a bit more detail. Halle has been very sporty throughout childhood, really good at football and generally any sport she decided to play. In August 2023 Halle's world changed forever when they were given the news that she had osteosarcoma, a rare form of bone disease. Halle has undergone a year of aggressive chemotherapy and in January this year underwent surgery to remove her right leg from just above her knee. This meant that she had the best possible chance of the cancer not spreading and being free of the disease.

Halle and her parents, Maddy and James have dealt with the past year with such positvity, resilience and in all honesty are just incredible. She now has so many plans of things she wants to achieve and such a great example of others going through the same journey. She is recovering incredibly well and last week at her enablement appointment was told that she could be fitted for a running blade, so she will be able to start running again. 

I met up with Maddy last week and she explained that because a trainer isn't required for the running blade she had reached out to a running brand she herself had recently bought from, HOKA to see if there was any way they could purchase one trainer. Sadly she received the response yesterday which is shown here that this wasn't an option in their system ğŸ™„ but thanked her for sharing her story. Disappointing.

I have reached out to an old colleague who now works at adidas and we are hopeful they may be able to help.

But it certainly got me thinking and frustrated, surely there are options for amputees or those with disabilities that mean they just don't ned to spend out on tow shies when only 1 is required?

I also thought back to my days as a student working in a shoe shop, we constantly had one shoe go missing and would be left with an odd one that got sent back to head office and probably ended up in landfill.

I'm hoping there is a solution for Halle, she definitely deserves this and so much more.

Nike, Brooks Running, do you have any suggestions?

The picture shows Halle in her normal prosthetic that she wears to walk around, this one requires both trainers as you can see but the running blade doesn't need a shoe.

Comment, like and share as I'm on a mission to resolve this for them. I can't believe that with the Paralympics just behind us there isnâ€™t more help with this
author: Cathy Knight

postContent:
ğŸŒŠ The Importance of Swimming Pool Filter Vessel Inspections ğŸŒŠ

Ensuring a clean and safe swimming pool environment goes far beyond just chemical balance and regular cleaning. One often overlooked but important aspect is the inspection of swimming pool filter vessels.

Regular inspections of filter vessels are vital for several reasons:

1. Safety - Pool filter vessels operate under high pressure, and any undetected weaknesses or defects can lead to failures. Regular inspections help prevent accidents, ensuring the safety of both swimmers and maintenance staff.

2. Optimal Performance - A well-maintained filter vessel ensures that your filtration system operates at peak efficiency, keeping your pool water clear and free from contaminants.

3. Cost Efficiency - Identifying issues early through regular inspections can save you from costly repairs or complete system replacements down the line. Itâ€™s an investment in the long-term health of your pool infrastructure.

By prioritizing filter vessel inspections, youâ€™re not just maintaining a poolâ€”youâ€™re safeguarding a communityâ€™s health and well-being.

#Broadwater #PWTAG #PoolSafety #MaintenanceMatters #SwimmingPool #WaterSafety #FacilityManagement
author: Broadwater Technologies Ltd.

postContent:
ğŸŒŸ Employee Spotlight: Phil Moore â€“ European President of Tchoukball! ğŸŒŸ
At Broadwater Technologies Ltd, we take pride in celebrating the multifaceted talents of our team. Today, we're excited to spotlight Philip Moore, who not only excels in his role with us but also serves as the European President of Tchoukball.

Whatâ€™s Tchoukball, you ask? 
Tchoukball is a dynamic and inclusive sport that combines elements of handball and volleyball. Played on an indoor court, it involves two teams aiming to score points by rebounding a ball off a frame at either end of the court. The catch? The opposing team can't intercept but must prevent the ball from hitting the ground. It's a game of strategy, agility, and teamworkâ€”much like the work we do here at Broadwater!

European Championship 2024
 As the European President of Tchoukball, Phil Moore plays a crucial role in promoting and organizing the sport across the continent. Last week, he spearheaded the European Tchoukball Championship in Ferrara, Italy. Under his leadership, the event brought together talented teams from various countries, fostering a spirit of camaraderie and competition. 

Join us in congratulating Phil on his incredible achievements and for bringing the same energy and commitment to Broadwater Technologies that he does to the world of Tchoukball. We're lucky to have you on our team, Phil! ğŸŒŸğŸ‘

postContent:
This is a truly unique venue, well known to fellow members of HMC (The Heads' Conference). It has a sense of mission and purpose which you donâ€™t find in more corporate surroundings, but then few of them are former royal residences and even fewer can offer guests a sumptuous bedroom which was once a private chapel!

I was delighted (but somehow unsurprised) to discover on my first visit to Cumberland Lodge that the late Sir Roger Young, my distinguished predecessor as Principal of George Watson's College, had been involved in the establishment of Cumberland Lodge as an educational charity after the Second World War. It was an example of just the kind of pragmatic idealism that characterised his later service to the School.

I am very much looking forward to going back to Cumberland Lodge for a meeting next month.

postContent:
Farewell to a friend and TV scienceÂ superstar 

I wasÂ so shocked to hear the news about the shocking death of TV presenter Michael Moseley who died last week while taking a walk in Greece. Everyone at One Tribe TV sends our condolences to his family and friends . I had the pleasure of working with him closely for around two years while in BBC Science on the seriesÂ â€œInventions the Changed The Worldâ€.Â At the time he was still an TV executive producer and I was the series producer- it was back in the 00â€™s . Owen Gay our creative director worked with him when he started presenting on The One Show .Â Michael had a unique gift of being able to make science and health content accessible and interesting to a mainstream TVÂ audience. This is such a rare ability driven by this infectious andÂ genuine enthusiasm and energy . The last time I saw Michael was when we walking down the Red carpet at the BAFTAâ€™s in London having both arrived by tube . Michael was totally upstaged by the arrival of the One Way is Essex cast in a stretch limo !Â Â We both laughed as we sipped on Tattinger before the awards started as we talked about the influence of â€œrealityâ€ shows - but Michaelâ€™sÂ science shows really did make a difference to so many people and livesÂ .Â Anyway he will be missed by so many in the industry and the TV audience .

Dale Templar , Managing Director, One Tribe TV

postContent:
Really eye opening from Bloomberg across the board here, but this is the bit that jumped out to me:

â€œSpringHill, which grew to 200 employees, raised money at the top of the market for production companies, back when streaming services were adding billions of dollars to their budgets each year to chase new customers.â€

In a world where eyeballs are moving towards creator-owned media companies with smaller staff, reliance on outside vendors, and direct distribution to consumers, I donâ€™t see how viable it is to sustain a 200 person â€œsmallâ€ independent production company. Which in and of itself has potentially seismic impact on entertainment industry jobs. Then you add on real estate rental and other overhead, and itâ€™s hard to make the math work given the pullback on exorbitant streamer spending. 

Everything across media (other than AAA/tentpole) seems to be moving towards smaller teams, lower overhead, and leveraging online media it seems. Disruptive timesâ€¦

On Sky Kids and NOW TV in the UK is the second season of Wildseedâ€™s show â€˜Dodoâ€™ â€“ created and directed by Jack Bennett, co-written with Ben Ward. Full credits for the series are here. We â€˜discoveredâ€™ Jack while he was doing his MA at UWE and making his graduation film â€˜Not The End Of The Worldâ€™.

Dodo is such a lovely series â€“ funny, compassionate, cringe-making (in a good way) â€“ it celebrates the moment when we first go to secondary school and try to fit in and the fantasy worlds kids create to try and make sense of everything. It plots our first steps in teenage friendship, dating â€“ the loss of innocence that primary school protects â€“ the beginning of the emergence of our adult personalities. Itâ€™s a joy to be honest, and I am immensely proud of it and everyone who worked on it. Please do catch the new season on Sky Kids or Now Tv â€“ Season one is on ITVX if you havenâ€™t got Sky.

postContent:
Are there any UK manufactures of pipette tips left? We have a custom tip requirement and are trying to find a supplier but I can't find anyone and it seems mad to import to assemble into out kits and for re-export to customers! We'd also be interested in anybody's experience with recycled PE for tip production, is it a no-no? Sustainability has to be a goal for disposable items!

EDIT: 

I must admit I hadn't realised the depth of skill in this area still sat here in the UK. Advanced manufacture is alive and kicking and I'm grateful to everyone who responded and will be in contact.

For us I think part of this is coming from the environmental impact of production of plastics and how we try and lower that impact in a market where those materials are the only option, but also the growing uncertainty around supply in a rapidly changing global landscape - we want to make sure that when we have product in market that we can supply all territories at a cost that makes sense to the customer and isn't artificially hiked - more so in diagnostics...

EDIT 2:

Thank you everyone who responded, such a kind industry we're in! If anyone wants any conclusions or help I'm happy to jump on a call and share experiences we've had
author: Ben Cobb

postContent:
The biohacking and self-quantified movement continues to grow, not just in size, but in sophistication. What began with wearables and wellness tracking is now evolving into personal genomics, microbiome sequencing, and now even gene expression analysis.

Biohackers have always been pioneers on the edge, like the early computer hackers of the early 1980s and as an X-gen teen at the time I found myself in that camp. We are the early adopters of tools and methods long before they reach the mainstream. Today, biohackers are leading the charge into at home testing at molecular-level, self-exploration, running N=1 experiments, setting up home labs, and asking deeper questions about the biology behind performance, health, and longevity.

If youâ€™re in this space, letâ€™s connectâ€¦
author: Ben Cobb

postContent:
Sample processing has typically required follow on purification to remove the lysing agents. At ReadyGo we have pioneered a diagnostic friendly solution that allows you to lyse cells and go directly into your PCR or isothermal amplification. It's what we dry down on to our snapcollect device. It has been demonstrated with difficult to lyse bacteria such as Mycobacterium tuberculosis and Borrelia species, and with viruses such as SARS and RSV. 

We are making this available as a wet chemistry to researchers in oder to extend to range of suitable sample types and to different targets. 

Simply add reagent A directly into your sample for instantaneous lyse at room temperature, followed by reagent B to neutralise it. This is then suitable to go directly into your test without the added faff of magnetic beads or silica bead capture, centrifugation or multiple wash steps; sample dependent of course. 

All very convenient. 

Please contact us to learn more about this product.
author: Ben Cobb

postContent: We are proud to announce the first notification of patent grant for snapcollect in the EU. This product integrates sample collection and processing into an easy to use disposable. What looks simple is very clever because it allows drying of chemistry into an absorbent nib that then collects and processes sample, for example lysing cells or viruses, or treating the sample into some pre-analytical way. Lots to come from this product in self-collection and pre-analytical sample preparation... In times where parts of the world seems hell bent in looking inward, we are proud to make accessible products that can have an impact globally!
author: Ben Cobb

postContent: The US pulling back support for global TB research, especially cutting off affordable diagnostics for low- and middle-income countries, is like aiming a fire extinguisher at a campfire in your own backyard while the whole forest around you burns. Sure, the NIH is doing good work, but itâ€™s trying to protect its own geography. The problem is TB, and drug-resistant strains doesnâ€™t care about borders. If we donâ€™t invest in stopping the blaze where itâ€™s burning hottest, in places with the least resources, itâ€™s going to come right back around. Ignoring the global fight isnâ€™t just short-sighted itâ€™s like turning your back on the fire and hoping the wind doesnâ€™t change direction. Whatever direction it changes will have an impact. https://lnkd.in/ev6SK2Xx

postContent: *this* is the stuff government should be taking seriously and making happen, if they actually want to shift the possibilities for people with a disability to do good quality paid work. postContent:
Breaking Barriers Through Education: A New Chapter for Para Pentathlon

One of the greatest challenges in integrating Para into a historically established sport like modern pentathlon is not the physical logistics â€” itâ€™s the knowledge gap. Misconceptions, unconscious bias, and a lack of understanding can create invisible barriers that hold us back from true inclusivity.

Thatâ€™s why Iâ€™m proud to share a major milestone: the launch of a new educational module developed as one of the first initiatives of the UIPM - World Pentathlon Para Commission with support from the classification research ongoing at Liverpool John Moores University 

This resource has been designed for national pentathlon federations, officials, coaches, and athletes â€” a foundational step toward building a global culture of understanding and support for Para Pentathlon. From demystifying classification procedures to providing practical tips for training and competition, our goal is to empower everyone involved with the tools and knowledge to embrace and elevate Para sport.

This is more than a module â€” itâ€™s a movement to shift perspectives, break down stigma, and champion equity in sport.

Letâ€™s keep learning. Letâ€™s keep opening doors.
#ParaPentathlon #InclusionThroughEducation #UIPM #AdaptiveSport #DiversityInSport

Sign up for the free training on the UIPM World Pentathlon educational platform

postContent: We are delighted that our recent Bond Offer reached the target of Â£1.2 million, an incredible 75 days ahead of schedule. At TravelLocal, we believe travel should be a force for good - not just for our travelers, but also for the communities they visit.

Thatâ€™s why weâ€™re proud to support incredible initiatives through our Fund For Good, including our long-standing partnership with Just a Drop. Recently, our very own Marie had the opportunity to volunteer with Just a Drop and their local partner Water for Cambodia in Siem Reap - and what an experience it was!

Over the course of 4 days, Marie got stuck into: 
ğŸ’§ Building and installing biosand water filters in family homes

The more we grow bookings, the more we can give back. Every trip booked through TravelLocal helps fund community-driven projects like these â€” creating meaningful impact far beyond the destination.

postContent:
As April bows out (Bank Holiday Weekend is nearly upon us!), I have been reflecting on a whole month spent diving into one of my favourite topics - apprentice mentoring!

At South West Apprenticeship Company Limited (SWAC), mentoring isnâ€™t just something we â€œdoâ€ - itâ€™s in our DNA. This month we shone the spotlight on the people, practices, and lightbulb moments that make mentoring such a game-changer for apprentices and employers. 

Hereâ€™s a little rewind of what we got up to ğŸ‘‡ 

ğŸš€ Why Every Apprentice Deserves a Mentor
 We kicked off with the â€œwhyâ€. Spoiler alert: because mentors change everything. I shared a bit about my own experience in banking - when someone believed in me before I knew how to believe in myself. Thatâ€™s the magic. At SWAC, every apprentice gets a mentor whoâ€™s there not just for day one, but for the whole journey.

ğŸ† Top 10 Qualities of a Great Mentor
 We dug into what makes someone a mentor worth their weight in gold. Generous with time, brilliant listeners, able to challenge and cheerlead in equal measure. The best ones arenâ€™t trying to impress - theyâ€™re trying to uplift.

ğŸŒ± How to Be a Brilliant Mentee
 Mentoringâ€™s a two-way street - and the best mentees donâ€™t just show up, they step up. Set goals, ask questions, be open to feedback (even the tricky stuff), and say thank you. A mentor can open the door - but youâ€™ve got to walk through it.

âš¡ Mentor vs. Manager: Letâ€™s Clear It Up
 Not the same thing! Managers help you tick off your tasks. Mentors help you figure out what youâ€™re really good atâ€”and where you want to go. You need both, but they play very different roles in your growth.

ğŸ”„ Reverse Mentoring: Yes, Really.
 Hereâ€™s where things got juicy. Apprentices have a lot to teach the rest of us- especially around tech, trends, and fresh perspectives. The best leaders are the ones who keep learningâ€”and sometimes that learning comes from someone half your age.

ğŸ’¬ The Big Takeaway?
Mentoring isnâ€™t just a â€œnice to haveâ€. Itâ€™s a superpower. It builds confidence, connection, and cultures where people donâ€™t just surviveâ€”they thrive. If your apprentices donâ€™t have a mentor yet, itâ€™s time to change that. (Need help? You know where I am.)

To everyone who joined the conversation, shared their stories, or simply cheered us onâ€”thank you. Letâ€™s keep building workplaces where everyone has someone in their corner. ğŸ’ª

#MentoringMonth #Apprenticeships #SWAC #MentoringMatters #PeopleDevelopment #ReverseMentoring #GrowthMindset #FutureTalent

postContent:
A lesson I'm teaching my daughter.

And itâ€™s not found in any textbook.

Getting comfortable asking for what you want is a superpower few people develop early enough.

With my daughter, I'm intentionally building this skill.

Teaching her to articulate her goals, engage others in her vision and make direct requests without apology. Not just with family, but with teachers, sports coaches and other adults in her world.

But this a pattern I also recognise from everywhere - colleagues waiting for the "right time" to pitch ideas, professionals delaying career moves until they feel "fully ready.â€

We're taught to wait for permission rather than ask for what we need.

Why permission-waiting holds us back:

- Opportunities rarely announce themselves - they respond to direct requests
- Decision-makers can't address needs they don't know exist
- Self-advocacy skills compound in value over decades
- Waiting creates a widening gap between potential and achievement
- Initiative consistently outperforms obedience in today's workplace

Key principles anyone can apply:

1. ğ— ğ—®ğ—¸ğ—² ğ—®ğ˜€ğ—¸ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ ğ—® ğ—µğ—®ğ—¯ğ—¶ğ˜, ğ—»ğ—¼ğ˜ ğ—®ğ—» ğ—²ğ˜…ğ—°ğ—²ğ—½ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—»: The skill of requesting what you need should be practiced regularly, not reserved for rare occasions.
2. ğ—™ğ—¼ğ—°ğ˜‚ğ˜€ ğ—¼ğ—» ğ˜ğ—µğ—² ğ˜ƒğ—®ğ—¹ğ˜‚ğ—² ğ—²ğ˜…ğ—°ğ—µğ—®ğ—»ğ—´ğ—²: frame requests around mutual benefit: "Here's what I'm trying to accomplish and how you can help."
3. ğ——ğ—²ğ˜ğ—®ğ—°ğ—µ ğ—¼ğ˜‚ğ˜ğ—°ğ—¼ğ—ºğ—² ğ—³ğ—¿ğ—¼ğ—º ğ—¶ğ—±ğ—²ğ—»ğ˜ğ—¶ğ˜ğ˜†: a rejected request doesn't mean you're unworthy - itâ€™s just a misaligned opportunity.
4. ğ—•ğ˜‚ğ—¶ğ—¹ğ—± ğ˜€ğ˜ğ—¿ğ—®ğ˜ğ—²ğ—´ğ—¶ğ—° ğ—®ğ˜€ğ—¸ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ ğ˜€ğ—¸ğ—¶ğ—¹ğ—¹ğ˜€: know when, how, and to whom specific requests should be made for maximum effectiveness.
5. ğ— ğ—¼ğ—±ğ—²ğ—¹ ğ˜„ğ—µğ—®ğ˜ ğ˜†ğ—¼ğ˜‚ ğ˜„ğ—®ğ—»ğ˜ ğ˜ğ—¼ ğ˜€ğ—²ğ—²: leaders who ask directly create cultures where others feel empowered to do the same.

ğ—£ğ—¿ğ—®ğ—°ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—°ğ—®ğ—¹ ğ˜„ğ—®ğ˜†ğ˜€ ğ˜ğ—¼ ğ˜€ğ˜ğ—¿ğ—²ğ—»ğ—´ğ˜ğ—µğ—²ğ—» ğ˜†ğ—¼ğ˜‚ğ—¿ ğ—®ğ˜€ğ—¸ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ ğ˜€ğ—¸ğ—¶ğ—¹ğ—¹ğ˜€

- Request one stretch opportunity each month that feels slightly out of reach
- Replace "Just checking if..." with "I'd like to propose..."
- Track and celebrate requests made, not just those granted
- Identify three places you're currently waiting for permission unnecessarily
- Study how effective people in your field make and frame their asks

What are you waiting for someone else to authorise that you could simply start doing today?

------

postContent:
"Would you like some coaching?"
The most self-defeating question in leadership.

It's equivalent to asking "Would you like some training?" without mentioning what for.

ğ—ªğ—µğ˜† ğ˜ğ—¿ğ—®ğ—±ğ—¶ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—»ğ—®ğ—¹ ğ—°ğ—¼ğ—®ğ—°ğ—µğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ ğ—¼ğ—³ğ—³ğ—²ğ—¿ğ˜€ ğ—³ğ—®ğ—¶ğ—¹:

1. ğ—£ğ—²ğ—¿ğ—°ğ—²ğ—½ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—» ğ—´ğ—®ğ—½
When you say "coaching," they hear "correction."
When you mean "development," they translate to "deficiency."

2. ğ—§ğ—µğ—² ğ—µğ—¶ğ—±ğ—±ğ—²ğ—» ğ—¿ğ—²ğ˜€ğ—¶ğ˜€ğ˜ğ—®ğ—»ğ—°ğ—² ğ˜ğ—¿ğ—¶ğ—´ğ—´ğ—²ğ—¿ğ˜€
"Do you want coaching?" activates immediate mental barriers:
"I don't have time for another commitment"
"What am I doing wrong?"
"Is this a performance issue?"
"How will this look to others?"

3. ğ—©ğ—®ğ—¹ğ˜‚ğ—² ğ—¿ğ—²ğ—ºğ—®ğ—¶ğ—»ğ˜€ ğ—¶ğ—»ğ˜ƒğ—¶ğ˜€ğ—¶ğ—¯ğ—¹ğ—²
Coaching's true benefits stay hidden behind vague terminology.
The transformation potential never enters the conversation.

ğ—›ğ—¼ğ˜„ ğ˜ğ—¼ ğ—½ğ—¿ğ—²ğ˜€ğ—²ğ—»ğ˜ ğ—°ğ—¼ğ—®ğ—°ğ—µğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´:

1.  ğ—Ÿğ—²ğ—®ğ—± ğ˜„ğ—¶ğ˜ğ—µ ğ˜€ğ—½ğ—²ğ—°ğ—¶ğ—³ğ—¶ğ—° ğ—¼ğ˜‚ğ˜ğ—°ğ—¼ğ—ºğ—²ğ˜€
"Who wants to make decisions with 30% more confidence?"
"Who's interested in reducing team conflict by half?"
"Who would like to cut meeting time while improving results?"

2. ğ—™ğ—¿ğ—®ğ—ºğ—² ğ—¶ğ˜ ğ—®ğ˜€ ğ—½ğ—²ğ—¿ğ—³ğ—¼ğ—¿ğ—ºğ—®ğ—»ğ—°ğ—² ğ—®ğ—°ğ—°ğ—²ğ—¹ğ—²ğ—¿ğ—®ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—»
Position coaching as the competitive advantage it is.

3. ğ—¦ğ—µğ—®ğ—¿ğ—² ğ—°ğ—¼ğ—»ğ—°ğ—¿ğ—²ğ˜ğ—² ğ˜€ğ˜‚ğ—°ğ—°ğ—²ğ˜€ğ˜€ ğ—½ğ—®ğ˜ğ˜ğ—²ğ—¿ğ—»ğ˜€
"Team members who engaged in our coaching programme last quarter reported 40% higher job satisfaction and delivered projects 25% faster."

4. ğ—–ğ—¿ğ—²ğ—®ğ˜ğ—² ğ—™ğ—¢ğ— ğ—¢, ğ—»ğ—¼ğ˜ ğ—¼ğ—¯ğ—¹ğ—¶ğ—´ğ—®ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—»
Make coaching feel like an opportunity everyone deserves.
Universal access with personalised impact creates genuine engagement.

The strongest teams don't receive coaching because they're struggling.

postContent:
Coaching isn't therapy. It's not training.

And it's definitely not just for "fixing problems."

Here are 6 coaching myths debunked;
1.ğ—›ğ—¶ğ—´ğ—µ ğ—½ğ—²ğ—¿ğ—³ğ—¼ğ—¿ğ—ºğ—²ğ—¿ğ˜€ ğ—±ğ—¼ğ—»'ğ˜ ğ—»ğ—²ğ—²ğ—± ğ—°ğ—¼ğ—®ğ—°ğ—µğ—²ğ˜€
â†³ The elite in every field have coaches.
â†³ The best leaders seek feedback before it's required
â†³ Waiting until you're struggling means starting from behind
ğ—¦ğ—²ğ—¹ğ—³-ğ—°ğ—¼ğ—®ğ—°ğ—µğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—½: Schedule regular "performance reviews" with yourself to reflect on successes, challenges and gaps. Don't wait for external triggers to evaluate performance.

2.ğ—–ğ—¼ğ—®ğ—°ğ—µğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ ğ—¶ğ˜€ ğ—¼ğ—»ğ—¹ğ˜† ğ—³ğ—¼ğ—¿ ğ˜ğ—¼ğ—½ ğ—²ğ˜…ğ—²ğ—°ğ˜‚ğ˜ğ—¶ğ˜ƒğ—²ğ˜€
â†³ Effective coaching should be accessible at all levels
â†³ Democratising development creates organisational resilience
â†³ When coaching reaches everyone, innovation and engagement flourish
ğ—¦ğ—²ğ—¹ğ—³-ğ—°ğ—¼ğ—®ğ—°ğ—µğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—½: Build peer coaching circles and meet colleagues monthly to share challenges and ask questions.

3.ğ—–ğ—¼ğ—®ğ—°ğ—µğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ ğ˜€ğ—µğ—¼ğ˜‚ğ—¹ğ—± ğ—³ğ—¼ğ—°ğ˜‚ğ˜€ ğ—¼ğ—» ğ˜„ğ—²ğ—®ğ—¸ğ—»ğ—²ğ˜€ğ˜€ğ—²ğ˜€
â†³ Exceptional performance comes from leveraging strengths
â†³ Fixing weaknesses creates adequacy, not excellence
â†³ The greatest ROI is in your top capabilities, not your bottom ones
ğ—¦ğ—²ğ—¹ğ—³-ğ—°ğ—¼ğ—®ğ—°ğ—µğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—½: Identify your top three strengths and focus 60% of your week on them. Track the energy and results that come from this versus time spent compensating for weaknesses.

4.ğ——ğ—²ğ˜ƒğ—²ğ—¹ğ—¼ğ—½ğ—ºğ—²ğ—»ğ˜ ğ—³ğ—¼ğ—¹ğ—¹ğ—¼ğ˜„ğ˜€ ğ—® ğ—¹ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—²ğ—®ğ—¿ ğ—½ğ—®ğ˜ğ—µ
â†³ Growth happens in bursts, not steady increments
â†³ Plateau periods are where integration happens
â†³ The most valuable lessons often come from detours, not the main road
ğ—¦ğ—²ğ—¹ğ—³-ğ—°ğ—¼ğ—®ğ—°ğ—µğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—½: Keep a "growth journal" to track insights and breakthroughs. When you hit a plateau, review your journal to recognise progress and trigger patterns for growth spurts. Embrace plateaus as consolidation periods, not failures.

5.ğ—” ğ—´ğ—¼ğ—¼ğ—± ğ—°ğ—¼ğ—®ğ—°ğ—µ ğ—´ğ—¶ğ˜ƒğ—²ğ˜€ ğ˜†ğ—¼ğ˜‚ ğ˜ğ—µğ—² ğ—®ğ—»ğ˜€ğ˜„ğ—²ğ—¿ğ˜€
â†³ Exceptional coaches ask questions you can't Google
â†³ The answers that transform are the ones you discover yourself
â†³ True clarity comes from within, not from external prescription
ğ—¦ğ—²ğ—¹ğ—³-ğ—°ğ—¼ğ—®ğ—°ğ—µğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—½: Build a set of powerful questions when facing challenges: "What assumptions am I making?" "What would I advise someone else in this situation?" "What's the opportunity hidden in this problem?" Regular use builds sharper self-reflection. ğŸ’ª

6.ğ—–ğ—¼ğ—®ğ—°ğ—µğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ ğ—¶ğ˜€ ğ—½ğ—¿ğ—¶ğ—ºğ—®ğ—¿ğ—¶ğ—¹ğ˜† ğ—®ğ—¯ğ—¼ğ˜‚ğ˜ ğ—®ğ—°ğ—µğ—¶ğ—²ğ˜ƒğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ ğ—´ğ—¼ğ—®ğ—¹ğ˜€
â†³ Goals are the vehicle, not the destination
â†³ Great coaching sharpens thinking and action
â†³ When coaching works, you solve problems before they arise
ğ—¦ğ—²ğ—¹ğ—³-ğ—°ğ—¼ğ—®ğ—°ğ—µğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—½: Check how your thinking evolved before chasing the next goal. Ask yourself: "How has my approach to problem-solving changed?" "What new capabilities have I developed?" These insights are often more valuable than the goal itself.

postContent:
Are you always being told youâ€™re doing great?

You might have a problem.

Are you actually getting the truth or just what's "nice" to hear?

ğ—¦ğ—¶ğ—´ğ—»ğ˜€ ğ˜†ğ—¼ğ˜‚'ğ—¿ğ—² ğ—´ğ—²ğ˜ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ "ğ—»ğ—¶ğ—°ğ—²" ğ—¶ğ—»ğ˜€ğ˜ğ—²ğ—®ğ—± ğ—¼ğ—³ ğ—µğ—¼ğ—»ğ—²ğ˜€ğ˜ ğ—³ğ—²ğ—²ğ—±ğ—¯ğ—®ğ—°ğ—¸:
ğŸ”¹Vague praise without specific examples.
â†³Â You miss critical opportunities to develop key skills.
ğŸ”¹Feedback that never includes areas for improvement.
â†³Â Your weaknesses become increasingly obvious to everyone but you.
ğŸ”¹Colleagues who agree with all your ideas in meetings.
â†³Â You develop a false sense of competence in areas needing work.
ğŸ”¹Performance reviews that feel superficial.
â†³Â Career advancement stalls without clear guidance on what to improve
ğŸ”¹The same blind spots persisting year after year.
â†³Â You're the last to know about problems affecting your reputation.

ğ—›ğ—¼ğ˜„ ğ˜ğ—¼ ğ—®ğ˜ƒğ—¼ğ—¶ğ—± ğ˜ğ—µğ—² "ğ—»ğ—¶ğ—°ğ—²" ğ—¯ğ—®ğ—¿ğ—¿ğ—¶ğ—²ğ—¿:
1. ğ—”ğ˜€ğ—¸ ğ—¯ğ—²ğ˜ğ˜ğ—²ğ—¿ ğ—¾ğ˜‚ğ—²ğ˜€ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—»ğ˜€
 Replace "How am I doing?" with "What's one thing I could improve right now?"
2. ğ—¥ğ—²ğ˜„ğ—®ğ—¿ğ—± ğ—°ğ—®ğ—»ğ—±ğ—¼ğ˜‚ğ—¿ ğ—²ğ˜…ğ—½ğ—¹ğ—¶ğ—°ğ—¶ğ˜ğ—¹ğ˜†
 "That feedback was really helpful - I appreciate you being straight with me."
3. ğ—–ğ—¿ğ—²ğ—®ğ˜ğ—² ğ—½ğ˜€ğ˜†ğ—°ğ—µğ—¼ğ—¹ğ—¼ğ—´ğ—¶ğ—°ğ—®ğ—¹ ğ˜€ğ—®ğ—³ğ—²ğ˜ğ˜†
 Show you can handle truth by responding thoughtfully, not defensively.
4. ğ—¦ğ—²ğ—²ğ—¸ ğ—¼ğ˜‚ğ˜ ğ˜ğ—µğ—² ğ˜€ğ˜ğ—¿ğ—®ğ—¶ğ—´ğ—µğ˜-ğ˜€ğ—µğ—¼ğ—¼ğ˜ğ—²ğ—¿ğ˜€
 Identify colleagues known for honesty and specifically request their input.
5. ğ—Ÿğ—¼ğ—¼ğ—¸ ğ—³ğ—¼ğ—¿ ğ—½ğ—®ğ˜ğ˜ğ—²ğ—¿ğ—»ğ˜€ ğ—¶ğ—» ğ˜€ğ˜‚ğ—¯ğ˜ğ—¹ğ—² ğ—³ğ—²ğ—²ğ—±ğ—¯ğ—®ğ—°ğ—¸
If multiple people make "small suggestions" in the same area, that's your growth opportunity.

ğ—¤ğ˜‚ğ—²ğ˜€ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—»ğ˜€ ğ˜ğ—µğ—®ğ˜ ğ˜‚ğ—»ğ—°ğ—¼ğ˜ƒğ—²ğ—¿ ğ—¿ğ—²ğ—®ğ—¹ ğ—³ğ—²ğ—²ğ—±ğ—¯ğ—®ğ—°ğ—¸:
1. "ğ—ªğ—µğ—®ğ˜ ğ˜„ğ—¼ğ˜‚ğ—¹ğ—± ğ˜†ğ—¼ğ˜‚ ğ—µğ—®ğ˜ƒğ—² ğ—±ğ—¼ğ—»ğ—² ğ—±ğ—¶ğ—³ğ—³ğ—²ğ—¿ğ—²ğ—»ğ˜ğ—¹ğ˜†?"
 Invites alternative approaches without framing your work as wrong.
2. "ğ—ªğ—µğ—®ğ˜ ğ—®ğ—º ğ—œ ğ—»ğ—¼ğ˜ ğ˜€ğ—²ğ—²ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´?"
 Acknowledges potential blind spots and invites perspective.
3. "ğ—¢ğ—» ğ—® ğ˜€ğ—°ğ—®ğ—¹ğ—² ğ—¼ğ—³ 1-10, ğ—µğ—¼ğ˜„ ğ˜„ğ—¼ğ˜‚ğ—¹ğ—± ğ˜†ğ—¼ğ˜‚ ğ—¿ğ—®ğ˜ğ—² ğ˜ğ—µğ—¶ğ˜€ ğ˜„ğ—¼ğ—¿ğ—¸?"
 If you hear "7," follow with "What would make it a 9?"
4. "ğ—ªğ—µğ—®ğ˜'ğ˜€ ğ˜ğ—µğ—² ğ˜ğ—µğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ ğ˜†ğ—¼ğ˜‚ ğ˜ğ—µğ—¶ğ—»ğ—¸ ğ—œ ğ—ºğ—¶ğ—´ğ—µğ˜ ğ—»ğ—¼ğ˜ ğ˜„ğ—®ğ—»ğ˜ ğ˜ğ—¼ ğ—µğ—²ğ—®ğ—¿?"
 Creates space for difficult but valuable truth.
5. "ğ—ªğ—µğ—²ğ—¿ğ—² ğ—®ğ—º ğ—œ ğ˜€ğ—²ğ˜ğ˜ğ—¹ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ ğ˜„ğ—µğ—²ğ—» ğ—œ ğ—°ğ—¼ğ˜‚ğ—¹ğ—± ğ—¯ğ—² ğ—²ğ˜…ğ—°ğ—²ğ—¹ğ—¹ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´?"
 Focuses feedback on potential rather than criticism.

The most valuable professional relationships aren't with people who protect your feelings - they're with those who protect your future by telling you what you need to hear.

When was the last time you received feedback that made you uncomfortable but helped you grow?

postContent:
It was a pleasure to welcome West of England Combined Authority Mayoral candidate Oli Henman to Bristol Beacon this week to discuss the importance of arts, culture and music to the region. 

We talked about our role as the West of England Music Education Hub lead, leveraging investment into schools programmes, establishing new teacher training and leading the production of a new national music curriculum.

We also covered our resident artists developmental programmes, our collaborative work with a wide range of partners, how we leveraged capital support for the transformation project, and  how we can work with the Combined Authority to support and add value.

We look forward to working with whoever is elected on May 1 to deliver cultural opportunities for the region.

postContent:
Weâ€™re delighted to share that the Reserved Matters application for the Dene Road site in Cotford St Luke has beenÂ unanimously approvedÂ at committee!
This exciting development will deliverÂ 80 new homes, includingÂ 20 affordable dwellingsÂ of mixed tenure and size, featuringÂ two wheelchair-accessible houses, to meet the evolving needs of the local community.

The schemeâ€™s layout and design were shaped through extensive collaboration with the local authority, includingÂ design workshopsÂ to align closely with their vision for the site. We also benefited fromÂ design panel reviewsÂ with experienced professionals from multiple disciplines, helping us ensure the proposals integrate seamlessly into the character and context of Cotford St Luke.

Sustainability at the Core
Weâ€™re proud to say that sustainability has been embedded throughout the project. From energy-efficient design to biodiversity enhancements and infrastructure for active travel and integrated places for social interaction, our goal is to deliver a development thatâ€™s environmentally responsible and built for the future.

A huge thank you to everyone involved in getting us to this stage â€”Â now onto the working drawing phase as we bring the vision to life!

ğŸ“šÂ A whole year on, and Stroud Library is looking just as good as the day we handed it over! 
 
We've officially reached the end of defects period on the project, and a site visit last Friday morning enabled us to check in with the end users. It was wonderful to see how loved the library is by both the staff and all its visitors. In its first year, the library saw around 150,00 visitors, nearly double than what the previous library received! 
 
It was great to hear about the many services the library has to offer and the positive engagement it has had within the local community. We are proud to be a part of the libraryâ€™s journey to this point.

postContent:
Are you looking for a new job and challenge? 

Trainee and experienced Recruitment Consultants wanted! 

Boston Rose are looking for enthusiastic, hardworking and motivated individuals to join our fantastic team. Based on Gloucester Road in Bristol, Boston Rose is great place to work, always promoting having fun whilst working hard and supporting your development along the way.

You will receive a basic salary with a generous commission structure. There are also many ongoing sales incentives that run throughout the year so individuals who consistently meet and exceed targets will have the opportunity to join our two annual all-expenses paid VIP trips (Skiing and Las Vegas) as well as a seat at our monthly Lunch Clubs (where you will be wined and dined at a top restaurant). For the big billers, there is a Rolex target and on top of that, there are socials (lots of socials) and an opportunity to get involved in the company charity.
 
We have a dedicated in-house training academy and ensure everyone is fully supported and developed throughout their career with us.

We are looking for a positive â€˜can doâ€™ attitude, hardworking, goal driven, proactive individuals with a desire to succeed. Our consultants come from a wide variety of backgrounds and we do not require any specific experience or qualifications, however we are looking for evidence that you are hardworking, goal driven and outgoing.

Please feel free to give me a call on 0117 929 6200 Â or email me on ben.maxfield@bostonrose.co.uk

The reception at the HOC was hosted by Edward Morello MP on behalf of SEUK and EDF Renewables. 

Huge thanks go to the large number of solar companies who contributed their data to this report. https://lnkd.in/ejJ4fy6n 

Watch out for the SEUK Webinar happening tomorrow evening on the latest Solar Habitat publication and an exploration of BNG within solar facilities. https://lnkd.in/eQweuGR5 (this is a SEUK member only event)
author: Thomas Clarkson

postContent:
Has been a pleasure to work with Solar Energy UK on this years report on trends in biodiversity on solar sites, extending and taking our own Solarview reports to the next level!

Our monitoring highlights some of the ecological benefits that can be derived from well designed and appropriately managed solar arrays.  It helps to dispel some of the myths around 'solar deserts' and provides an evidence base against which to consider delivery of biodiversity net gain.

Continued monitoring strengthens the evidence base for the potential positive environmental gain that can be delivered by solar farms.  This can only assist decision makers and further improve the green credentials of this renewable energy sector. 

Big thanks should go to Hannah Montag, AdÃ¨le Remazeilles and Bex Sandey from C&W who have been instrumental at coordinating this report, along with partners at Lancaster University, Wychwood Ecology and SolarEnergyUK.
author: Thomas Clarkson

postContent:
The C&W team and I are delighted to have been part of three back to back appeals in North Somerset on behalf of Persimmon Homes and MEAD REALISATIONS LIMITED.  Each won - 3 from 3 - a pretty good record!  Each appeal presented its own challenges with the proximity of each site to the North Somerset and Mendip Bats SAC being a key issue on every site.  Local experience and in-depth understanding of the SAC and the bats therein, and the North Somerset SPD really are key to being able to effectively respond to questions in a "cogent and compelling" manner.  (Not my words but the Inspectors). 
The next task is to make sure the mitigation for each site works.  Careful planning and continued close working with the planning and construction teams will be fundamental.
Lots of folk to tag: Joel Wright, Henry Sturgess, Kathryn Ventham, Jeremy Smith, Caroline Featherston, Harry Quartermain, Nick Paterson-Neild, Peter Mansell, Ian Jewson, Nigel Evers, Luke Hutcheson, Adam Parsons ARB RIBA, Emma Reid, Alistair Mead, Josh Ashwin, Tim Watton, Raheel Mahmood MRTPI, and by no means least Charles Banner QC, Leanne B. and Christopher Young QC
author: Thomas Clarkson

postContent:
Clarkson and Woods is thrilled to announce that we have been awarded the prestigious â€˜Ecological Consultancy of the Yearâ€™ award is our size category (11-50 employees) at the 2019 CIEEM Awards.  Tom, Harry and Rachel attended the ceremony to collect the award from David Lindo - the Urban Birder.  The awards ceremony was a lavish affair which celebrated the best projects, companies and individuals within our industry. 

Since 2010 the company has grown from a team of 5 to a team of over 20 full time ecologists offering leading expertise across a wide range of protected and notable species.  We couldnâ€™t be more proud of the current team of Ecological Consultants whose dedication and hard work has led to this Award. The team, past and present, have been such a committed, passionate and great bunch of people to work with and have all helped to shape the business in to what it is today. The late Michael Woods and his son Jonathan lay the foundation for this success, and we thank them for their passion and dedication to supporting British wildlife.  I know they would be pretty excited about our success last week and what the future holds for the business. 

#cieemawards #clarksonwoods #hardwork

postContent:
The Dogs Trust is the latest charity to announce it is considering some 300 job cuts to ensure its â€œfinancial sustainabilityâ€.

Already this year weâ€™ve had announcements like these:
- 181 people have left Guide Dogs
- 91 job losses at Mind
- 200 job cuts at Save the Children UK
- 60 job cuts at the Royal Academy of Arts
- 40 job cuts at Young Minds
- Recruitment freeze at National Trust
- The Vagina Museum narrowly saved from closure by a crowdfunding campaign
- Half of Stonewallâ€™s 114 employees face redundancy after USAID cuts
- Scottish Council for Voluntary Organisations (SCVO) asks for voluntary redundancies to save Â£500,000 per year
- 413 redundancies at Macmillan Cancer Support in 2024
- 189 proposed cuts at English Heritage
- Job losses at RNIB in Â£10m savings drive
- Scope shutters charity shops after Â£1.5m retail loss 

Many smaller charities, such as Women and Children First, have shut down altogether. 

From April the changes to National Insurance payments kick-in, adding an even bigger financial strain to our beloved charities. 

Now is not the time to be complacent or to maintain the status quo. We urgently need to modernise fundraising programmes, build donor relationships and make service delivery more efficient with technology. 

As a sector we need to innovate and do it quicklyâ€¦

#charities #fundraising #redundancies

postContent:
Sneak peak. Just putting the final touches to our brand strategy document. 

Milk & Tweed has changed so much over the last 6 years. Bigger studio, bigger customers, and even BIGGER Christmas bar bills.

But our brand and website hasn't changed. We have been wanting to do a new website for the last 2 years, but still haven't got round to doing it - always so hard to do your own work.

So we wanted to revisit our brand strategy before we embarked on a brand tweak and a new website. And after doing it, I am so excited for it, and the future of Milk & Tweed - exciting times ahead :)

If you would like a brand strategy workshop for your business or brand, then get in touch!
author: Jake Jeffries

postContent:
I could quite quickly list off lots of things that I am not very good at. But would struggle with the, what I am good at list.

Recently I had a strengths workshop, where I had to take a test with Gallup. Below were my results. 

I have always had the mindset of, leaning into what you enjoy and your strengths. Rather than focussing on what you are not very good at. I think our education system could do this a little more to be honest.

I always liked the quote, "if you judge a fish by its ability to climb a tree, it will live its whole life believing that it is stupid."
author: Jake Jeffries

Our team found the presentation particularly valuable in reviewing the updated energy performance benchmarks with new standards for building performance pushing the boundaries of occupant wellbeing.

Sustainability is one of our core principles here at Quattro and we were delighted to hear that BREEAM Version 7 aligns more closely with global decarbonisation efforts whilst also setting a clearer path for future-proofing buildings against the environmental challenges ahead.

postContent:
Bristol at its best.

Last night was Anti Banquet, bringing Bristol businesses together to raise money for grassroots causes - funding some of our cityâ€™s most vital community food projects that support people in need.

The idea is simple: businesses buy a table, and their CEOs and Directors work in the kitchen or serve their guests.

The execution is not so simple. It was great to see first hand the skill, dedication and hard graft involved by a huge amount of people in the planning and staging for an event for nearly 1,000 people. And a point of pride that my first waiting job was for the incredible Josh Eggleton and his team (though I've yet to be offered a full-time role).

A wonderful cause and a memorable evening - definitely one to add to the diary for next year.

Kudos to everyone who generously gave their time to make it happen. 

Read more about the cause here: www.antibanquet.co.uk/
author: Nick Farrar

postContent:
DAS Fire are again expanding its team and seek a Service and Small Works Engineer to join us.

You should be competent in Fire Alarm service work covering a range of manufacturers and be able to operate alone or as part of a team to a level including fault finding. Service works would cover conventional and addressable fire systems including aspirating and also suppression systems (Gas and Water). A working knowledge of suppression systems is essential.

The role would also include small works so that minor changes to site systems can be undertaken so a good understanding of the Fire Industry British Standards is required.

The candidate should ideally be based on the M4 corridor side of London as most works will be in the south east and be able to join our 24/7 call out rota.

postContent:
Most people read a majority of the content of the posts they â€˜likeâ€™ on LinkedIn but only a small minority read all of the content of all the posts they 'like.'

Thatâ€™s according to the results from my poll about this over the last week. 


â–¶ï¸ Almost two-thirds (65%) either read 51%-99% of the content or 100% of it. 

â–¶ï¸ Hats off to the 14% who always read all of it â€“ impressive!

â–¶ï¸ A sizable minority (30%) read 26%-50% of content on average, with two people reading a quarter or less.

The base was 37.


Many thanks to those who completed the survey, I appreciate it.

And presumably, two thirds of you may have got far enough down this post to see my â€˜thank you!â€™

#LinkedIn #Engagement 

Tagging in the people tagged to the original post in case you want to see the results.

postContent:
I made what must have been â€“ judging by the looks on membersâ€™ faces - a pretty lousy suggestion at a recent TAB Exeter board.

And I didnâ€™t mind. I didnâ€™t feel an idiot. Or not want to make a suggestion ever again. 

And that's because a TAB board is such a safe space. Even for the facilitator! 

Everyone brings a key issue along each month. Lots of ideas and suggestions are freely given as to how that issue might be addressed. 

And because it's a safe place, comprising peers with no vested interest other than wanting to help each other, people are comfortable with making all sorts of suggestions. 

Many are really helpful and occasionally some are like my recent one! And that's okay. 

I really like a Sir Ken Robertson talk in which he points out that children are far more creative than adults partly because they are less fearful about making mistakes.

He observes: â€˜Kids are not frightened of being wrong. I donâ€™t mean to say that being wrong is the same as being creative, but what we do know is that if youâ€™re not prepared to be wrong you will never come up with anything original.â€™ 

So, what did I come out with?

Simply that whilst discussing a memberâ€™s possible new service â€“ and with several people present knowing rather a lot about brand â€“ I decided to suggest a name for the new service that relied on a poor pun and was almost impossible to pronounce. 

But Iâ€™ll not hesitate to suggest something next time! Even a new service name! ğŸ˜‰ 

#tabboards #tabexeter #safespace #creativeideas #freshideas
-------------------------------------------------------------------

TAB Exeter peer boards meet monthly and comprise local business owners who help each other to better their businesses by advising each other on the challenges and opportunities they face. Everyone benefits from the collective relevant experience round the table. Iâ€™ve been running them for more than five years. 

I also run complimentary Business Ownersâ€™ Boards at Exeter Golf & Country Club and the next one is on Thurs 15th May (9am to 11.30am). Look out for other LinkedIn Posts for Eventbrite details.

postContent:
I read in todays Sifted newsletter that growing tensions between Donald Trump and EU leaders are causing anxiety over Europe's reliance on US cloud giants like AWS, Microsoft Azure, and Google Cloud. There are fears that Trump could disrupt services through tariffs or executive orders. Although Microsoft has promised legal action to protect European access, concerns persist. Even without a complete shutdown, political pressure could lead to service slowdowns or interruptions, impacting critical digital infrastructure. As one executive put it: â€œThe only thing guaranteed is uncertainty.â€

This kind of uncertainty can certainly feel unsettling. For those feeling anxious about this or other challenges, it might help to remember that uncertainty is a part of life. Take a deep breath and focus on the next step forward. Sometimes, the best approach is to maintain a positive outlook, take the high ground in any related discussions, and allow heated situations to eventually cool down.

#sifted #cloud #cloudservices #positive #mentalhealth
author: Neil Pick

postContent:
ğŸ‘‰Everyone is Always Right:

The system creates the conditions for our actions. And anyone who consistently takes an action is doing it because based on who they are, what they see, what they believe, and the feedback loop they're in, this is exactly the right thing to do.

Perhaps they might change what they do if they saw something else, if they received different feedback from the system, or if their status shifted.

We can show up with a story that resonates, and we can create the conditions for people to make different choices.

But we cannot easily persuade someone that they are wrong. (Seth Godin)

Follow Neil Pick 

#persuasion #knowledge #empathy #humancondition

postContent:
What is strategy?

In it's simplest form it is who we want to be tomorrow.  Strategy should be applied to ourselves, our businesses, our communities, our nation and the world at large - hopefully for good.

A bad strategy is not knowing where we want to be tomorrow, as we will attempt to go in many directions at the same time and get nowhere.

postContent:
This week, I lost three incredible members of staffğŸ˜¢.

Not because they didnâ€™t love what they do.
Not because they lacked passion, skill, or commitment.

They left because they simply couldnâ€™t afford to stay.

These were care professionals through and through , heroes, each one of them.

They showed up with heart.

They held hands through grief, they enabled dignity, they sparked joy.

And now?

Theyâ€™re heading to McDonaldâ€™s because it pays more.

Let that sink in.

We are losing some of the most compassionate, skilled, and selfless people in this country not to burnout, not to disillusionment but to poverty pay.

And Iâ€™m angry.ğŸ˜¡ 

Because I want to pay them more.
I should be able to pay them more.
But without fair uplifts, without funding that reflects the real cost of care, our hands are tied.

Theyâ€™re not leaving me.
Theyâ€™re being pushed out of a sector they love, by a system that keeps telling them they donâ€™t matter.

This is a loss to all of us.
To the people we support.
To families.
To the future of care.

And I know Iâ€™m not the only one watching this happen.

To the government officials tracking â€œcapacityâ€ I hope you track the compassion thatâ€™s slipping through your fingers aswell.

These are not numbers.
These are people.
And every time we lose one, the system gets weaker.

This is what weâ€™re fighting for at Providers Unite.
Because without change, there wonâ€™t be a workforce left to lead.

#ProvidersUnite #SocialCareCrisis #FairFundingNow #VoiceForCare #RealPeopleRealLoss #ThisIsWhatMatters

postContent:
Regarding my Tribunal preliminary hearing judgement - 
I have today spoken with Victoria Macdonald of Channel 4 News and the story is to be featured tonight at 7pm. 
I do hope you might share this please and encourage viewing. 

I sincerely hope that we can start (continue?) a national debate on integrity, accountability and genuine freedom to speak up among NHS leadership. 

The consequences of silencing, and indeed removing, those who try to prevent harm are devastating. In the case of Bradford Teaching Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust, it led to further preventable infant deaths and a knowingly dishonest media strategy designed to cover up.

Thank you. 

#Bradford
#Whistleblowing
#NHS
#Integrity
#Truth

postContent:
What do you get when you cross a recruiter, a client, and a shotgun?

Nope â€“ not an opportunity to â€œimprove the T&Csâ€â€¦
The Kingston Barnes | B Corpâ„¢ Shooting Day, of course.

A cracking Friday spent at Lady's Wood Shooting School with some of our lovely clients, a few brave candidates, and the KB team letting off steam (and a fair few cartridges).

Expert instruction, first-class hospitality, and a lemon drizzle cake so good it nearly sparked its own shoot-out.

We may have won our own competition â€“ which feels a bit like scoring your own appraisal â€“ but Joshua Spokes from Mud Mortar came within one shot of stealing it. Strong shooting sir.

postContent:
While Luften can be (and is) helpful, it's not a stand alone solution. Whole-house ventilation, behaviour of occupants and improving fabric of buildings all help reduce condensation risks.

Since condensation forms on the coldest surfaces in a home, insulation continuity is vital. Poorly insulated areas can become cold spots, increasing the likelihood of condensation and mould. 

Have you ever noticed a specific spot in your home or building that just stays chilly, no matter how high you turn up the heating? These are known asÂ cold spots. While they might seem like minor annoyances, they often signal more serious underlying issues that need attention.

For further reading on cold spots see this link here: https://lnkd.in/e7SRuWN9

#ventilation #homes #warmhomes #coldspots #insulation #retrofit

postContent:
With the publication of PAS 2035:2023, several significant updates have been introduced to improve scalability, streamline processes, and strengthen compliance. This article (in full below on the link) explores the key changes from PAS 2035:2019 and the difference in approaches required for this wave.

Note the adoption timeline for PAS 2035:2023 - it is intended that users will commence adoption ofÂ PAS 2035:2023Â immediately following publication, with the goal of fully meeting its requirements and claiming compliance withÂ PAS 2030:2023Â (and therefore PAS 2035:2023) from theÂ 30th of March 2025. At this point,Â PAS 2035:2019+A1:2022Â will be withdrawn, so retrofit professionals must transition to the new standard now.

To successfully navigate these changes and ensure your projects are fully compliant, timely adoption of the updated standard is critical. If you need support with PAS 2035 compliance and retrofit assessments, get in touch with us, our experts can help you meet the latest standards and ensure your retrofit projects are a success.

#PAS2035 #retrofit #compliance #industrystandards #SHDF #energyefficiency

postContent:
I saw this on the back of a loo door years ago and had to have it.



So I took a picture, had it retyped and framed three times.

One for the office wall
One for the office loo
One for the meeting room

It has stayed with us through office moves, Covid and various business changes. Day to day I forget it's there and every so often, when I need a reminder it catches my eye.

So I'm sharing in case you need reminding today.....


It's ok to...Be wrong. Cry. Say you don't know. Have a tough day. Ask for help. Fail. Have a different opinion. Take a break when you need it.

It's great to... Ask questions. Put your hand up when you make mistakes. Go home. Be ambitious. Go for a walk to clear your head. Switch off completely during holidays.

Please...Be kind. Be helpful. Be mindful of your own limits. Share knowledge. Ask people how they're doing. Remember there are no silly questions. Leave things better than you found them.

You should...Talk to people about doubts and concerns. Be yourself. Give candid, timely feedback. Be honest, even when it's uncomfortable.

Try to...Soften the edges. Be hard on problems, not people (including yourself). Put your ego aside.

#mental-health
author: Sharon Alred

But, if we reduce the gender pay gap by 1% we can increase economic growth by 3%

The impact of the confidence (BS) gap in financial knowledge is negativity impacting the amount of investment made by women. We need education.

The incredible panel line up with Emma Wood Alice Bretherton, Clare Wilkinson, Rebecca Baldwin-Cantello as well as the key notesÂ discussed:
