I sat back and absorbed the lived experiences shared in the 5 minutes that matter from Tara Miran, Kyrby Brown, Bianca Jones, Matt Humberstone, Lewis Wedlock
Thank you for being so generous and impactful.

What an event! A huge congratulations to the Bristol Women in Business Charter team for putting it together and driving change in #Bristol. Thank you to all those who took part and shared insights, progress and the work still to be done.

If you are not already involved, I highly recommend you take a look!

postContent:
Is "Cultural Fit" at Odds with Diversity? 
 
When hiring new talent, we often talk about finding someone who's a "good fit" for our team. 
But what exactly do we mean by "fit"? And does prioritising it undermine our diversity goals?
 
The "Fit" Trap

When we say we want someone who "fits," are we really saying:
â“ Someone just like us?
â“ Another version of our top performer?
â“ A person who won't disrupt our comfortable status quo?

This approach creates the ultimate echo chamber - a team that thinks alike, acts alike, and ultimately, faces the same blind spots.
 
The Diversity Advantage

Research consistently shows that diverse teams outperform homogeneous ones. Diversity brings:
âœ… Fresh perspectives on problems
âœ… Different approaches to solutions
âœ… Varied experiences that spark innovation
âœ… Healthy friction that challenges assumptions

When team members think differently from one another, they're more likely to identify risks, spot opportunities, and create breakthrough ideas.
 
Redefining "Fit"

True fit isn't about similarity - it's about complementary strengths. When hiring, consider:
â¡ï¸ What perspectives are missing from your current team?
â¡ï¸ Which skills would complement (not duplicate) existing talents?
â¡ï¸ How might different work styles enhance your team dynamic?

Values aligned, culture contribution.
 
The Short-Term vs. Long-Term Trade-off

When under pressure to fill positions quickly, it's tempting to choose someone who seems "easier" to integrate - someone familiar. But this short-term convenience often comes at a long-term cost to innovation, adaptability, and performance.
 
Moving Forward

Instead of asking "Will they fit in?" try asking:
â˜‘ï¸ Will they add something new to our team?
â˜‘ï¸ Do they share our core values while contributing to our culture?
â˜‘ï¸ How might they positively challenge our existing ways of thinking?

The most successful teams aren't built on sameness but on a foundation of shared purpose coupled with diverse approaches to achieving it.

Have you experienced the benefits of prioritizing diversity over conventional "fit" in your hiring process? Or have you seen the pitfalls of creating teams that are too similar? 

#DiversityAndInclusion #LeadershipThoughts #WorkplaceCulture #RecruitmentStrategy
author: Sharon Alred

postContent:
Leave well. 

How you handle your departure speaks volumes about your professional character and can impact future opportunities. 

People often remember the beginning, the end and the emotional peak/pit of an event. This translates into your work too. 

Here's how to ensure you leave on the best possible terms.
 
1 Give Appropriate Notice
-Deliver the news in person (or via video call) to your direct manager before telling colleagues
-Follow up with a formal resignation letter that includes your planned last day
 
2 Document Your Knowledge
-Create detailed handover documents that outline your responsibilities, processes, and ongoing projects, key contacts
-Add troubleshooting tips for common challenges in your role
-Perhaps record short video tutorials for complex processes
 
3 Train Your Replacement
-Develop a structured training plan for your remaining time
-Allow your replacement to shadow you and gradually take over tasks
-Be generous with your institutional knowledge - don't hoard information
 
4 Maintain Performance Standards
-Resist the temptation to mentally check out
-Complete as many outstanding projects as possible
-Don't start major new initiatives you can't finish
 
5 Set Colleagues Up for Success
-Introduce key contacts to the team members who will be taking over your responsibilities
-Transfer important relationships thoughtfully
-Ensure team members have access to necessary files, accounts, and resources
 
6 Exit Interviews and Feedback
-Participate constructively in exit interviews
-Offer honest but tactful feedback, focus on systems and processes rather than individuals
-Suggest practical improvements that could benefit the organization
 
7 Saying Goodbye
-Thank mentors and colleagues who supported your growth
-Consider a thoughtful email or card to the broader team
-If appropriate, bring in treats on your last day as a gesture of goodwill
 
8 Digital Housekeeping
-Return all company property and equipment
-Transfer ownership of accounts and documents
-Update passwords and access information for team accounts
 
9 Maintain Discretion After Leaving
-Never disparage your former employer or colleagues publicly
-Honour confidentiality agreements
-Be thoughtful about what you share on social media

Remember that industries can be surprisingly small, and professional paths often cross again. The impression you leave during your departure may well influence future opportunities, references, and collaborations.

How have you handled job transitions? What practices have you found most helpful when leaving a role professionally? 

#CareerTransition #ProfessionalDevelopment #JobChange #CareerAdvice #WorkplaceEtiquette

Wind turbines vs CHP units ğŸ¥Š

There are around 11,000 wind turbines in the UK â€“ generating clean energy for almost 30% of the national grid. But when it comes to generating power off-grid... which is right for you? 

A wind turbine or a CHP unit? 

Well, wind turbines require two things: wind and space. For a lot of the UK, generating power using wind turbines just isn't an option. 

A CHP unit using gas efficiently, will help you save money 24/7 and lower your emissions.

Find out more on our website: https://helec.co.uk/

postContent:
My good friend, and occasional-suffering colleague Tony Mears has written a book! 

Honoured that both I and Space Forge appears as an example and in the acknowledgements - even if the road there started with an idea for a podcast we killed before ever recording one line - no one needs another white guy podcast in their lives. 

Innovation is Dead seeks to demonstrate how it's possible to turn the tide on the perceived sluggishness of the public sector with new technology and new ways of getting stuff done inside government. 

If you operate at the intersection of government and new technologies I highly recommend giving it a read. I'm not just saying that because Tony is a mate. It is a lucid and erudite dissection of what's going wrong and ways to fix things - I didn't know he had it in him to write that well! 

https://lnkd.in/ePnB-7BP

postContent:
Hot on the heels of an invite to No.10 - I was also invited to the UK House of Lords to provide evidence on the growing space industry. (on the same day - I do own other suits!)

This work is being led by the UK Engagement with Space Committee to understand the challenges and opportunities for the sector.

Space is at an inflection point, just as the UK also is. At Space Forge we're ready to lead this new economy.

You can watch the whole session here: https://lnkd.in/eN5K3_y2 alongside my fellow panelists Katie King, PhD and Rory Holmes. 

I was the PhD combo breaker and under the ever watchful eye of Alan Thompson who was up after us on launch from the UK.
author: Joshua Western

postContent:
Remarkably after my last attempt, 10 Downing Street were willing to let me back in and try and stroke Larry the cat once more. 

Great to participate in a roundtable this morning regarding the future of advanced manufacturing in the UK and the upcoming Industrial Strategy. Chaired by Minister Sarah Jones of Department for Business and Trade there was a shared optimism around the table while tackling the ever-present challenges head on.

At Space Forge we're stood at the intersection of some of our most critical materials, compound semiconductors, and the critical domain of space. UK and European resurgence in manufacturing, defence, and national security is beginning to create the environment where we can succeed and win. The right environment needs the right support mechanisms, the rest falls into place. 

Our upcoming mission is just the start.

I was not what you'd call an academic student,  learning wasn't one of my strong points in my early years, but over time I have become an avid learner with a continuous learning mindset. Last week, I had the privilege of attending Oxford University as part of the Goldman Sachs 10,000 Small Businesses 10KSB UK program. This marked the half way point on this journey and I have been completely blown away with the quality of the course content and input from the team that runs #10KSB. Sitting in the Nelson Mandela Lecture Theatre, listening to some of the most amazing people from all areas of business is truly humbling. Who'd of thought it, leaving school at sixteen, I'd find myself in this incredible environment!

Being part of this cohort is one of the most inspiring things I have ever done. I'm surrounded by an amazing group of entrepreneurs who are passionate, driven, and making a real impact across the UK. The energy, ideas, and collaboration in the room are unlike anything Iâ€™ve experienced before. It feels so natural to be around so many people who are all living and breathing the day to day experiences of running a business, I no longer feel alone, so thank you to this wonderful bunch!

The 10KSB program is designed to help small businesses scale and thrive â€“ and itâ€™s doing exactly that. From world-class teaching to hands-on strategy development, it's been a game-changer already. The opportunity to step back, reflect, and work on the business rather than just in it has been invaluable.
Spending time at Oxford University last week â€“ a place steeped in history and innovation â€“ only made the journey more special. It was a moment to pause, connect, and re-energise for the road ahead.

To Goldman Sachs, Oxford University, and everyone involved in the programme â€“ thank you. Iâ€™m incredibly proud to be part of this community and canâ€™t wait to see where this journey leads next. ğŸš€

postContent:
A very thought provoking and interesting blog about the hot topic in the participant recruitment industry today.

The sole reason I founded People for Research, was to solve the problem of poor quality participant recruitment in the market research industry, and that was back in the analogue days. Yes, I am that old! The problems encountered then have translated into the digital world we now operate in, the same issues just wearing different clothes.

With Ai and now Synth participant platforms entering the market, you cannot ignore the impact they will have in the space of participant recruitment. But they are not the answer to all the issues regarding fake and fraudulent participants. Participant verification is the buzz word for most online platforms, that's not hard to achieve but it's also not hard to defeat either for the most determined fake participants. Verification is just step one in the process, the other ingredient and I would argue the most important, is the validation/screening of every participant done by a human. User Research is essentially about what people actually do do and not what they say they will do, which we know differs, so why rely on a recruitment system which sources participants based on how they answer a self completion screener, saying what they would do? This is the way any automated system works, whether that's Ai or self-serve platform.

To fully embrace the Ai world into our processes, we must adopt a "Human in the Loop" approach. This requires the symbiotic relationship between tech and human to reach an outcome that meets the high value output I would expect from good participant recruitment.

There is one slight flaw in all of this, which is value. For years I have struggled with the actual value researchers have placed on participant recruitment. By value I mean cost, whilst researchers command high day rates, they will often reject high cost recruitment in favour of a cheaper one, whilst at the same time demanding high quality. You cannot have both, we all know that, yet it is THE most common thing I hear from researchers consistently from over three decades of working in this industry. The market research sector is by far the worst, whilst the user researcher sector is much better at recognising the value/cost in good quality recruitment. Could this be due to the fact that they are generally not from a market research background but born from a digital/design/tech sector?

To drive accurate high quality insight it is vital we use reliable, validated and screened participants with human in the loop approach for both qual and quant research.



https://lnkd.in/eS-F_RXS
author: Paul Gooding

postContent: Really interesting post on a topic I am very passionate about. For me, the jury is out, waiting further evidence regarding using tech to detect and reduce participant fraud. It's not just about verifying who they are but also that they genuinely fit the criteria for the research. The digital world forever evolves and from my own experience you need to be alert to changes that open the door to fake participants. It needs a joint approach of tech and humans to get the best results. Point 3, absolutely yes! I've been involved in market research for 30 plus years and little has changed whereby researchers rarely value the cost of good quality participant recruitment. There is a distinct difference between market researchers and user researchers, the later valuing the cost of quality recruitment far more. It is vital to have reliable, validated participants for both qual and quant to drive good quality insights..... but it costs.

postContent:
ğŸ’¡ Project spotlight!ğŸ’¡
 
ğŸ‰ Today, we celebrate the Tond Tenga project in Burkina Faso. This is the first project registered in Verra's Verified Carbon Standard (VCS) Program that uses a VCS methodology approved by The Integrity Council for the Voluntary Carbon Market (ICVCM) as meeting the Core Carbon Principles (CCPs).
 
ğŸŒ³ Developed by Tree Aid with the support of Earthshot, the Tond Tenga project works to restore more than 12,000 hectares of degraded land in Burkina Faso through native tree planting and agroforestry practices.
 
In a region where climate change and deforestation are threatening the landscape and contributing to poverty and hunger, this project is implementing an innovative restoration model to improve soil quality and help local communities cope with increasingly warming temperatures.
 
The income from the sale of carbon credits provides another key benefit that supports the project's long-term impact on the local landscape, the people that inhabit and rely on it, and the global climate.
 
ğŸ‘ğŸ½ Congratulations to the Tond Tenga project for being a true trailblazer and demonstrating the climate mitigation impact of nature-based solutions.

postContent:
â€œThe trade show at the end of the worldâ€

Thatâ€™s how someone at COP16 described the vast array of different COPs which seem to have more and more record breaking attendance as we hurtle towards record breaking temperatures.

And itâ€™s easy to fall into the trap of cynicism. Itâ€™s true the pure number air miles required to discuss the very clear facts of climactic breakdown can make for easy fodder for the nihilistic view of our current predicament.

But Tree Aid has always offered a pragmatic and optimistic view of proven and scalable action which can solve those issues being debated. We have the tools - we just need to use them.

For my part - this year I attended two out of three COPs. First in Baku and then just now in Riyadh.

What I witnessed was a convergence of smart and able people coming together to learn from each other and push for implementing what we know works at scale. At the same time this group is, more than ever, recognising the power of nature and of indigenous people and local communities. Combining these two forces will undoubtedly be the key which unlocks successful climate action globally.

Weâ€™re playing our part at Tree Aid not just in how we deliver large scale, empowering, inclusive and effective programming. We are also bringing vital knowledge to events like COP. This year we launched 3 key pieces of evidence to help accelerate climate solutions:

ğŸŒ³  Alongside World Economic Forum and 1t.org we launched a paper to show how carbon financing can and should work in the Great Green Wall - and presented our own case study of how we did it in practice. https://lnkd.in/egKW2qzZ
ğŸŒ³  We brought our on the ground evidence of decades of delivering better forest and land governance to show its value and impact as part of restoration agendas. https://lnkd.in/ehWMqFFY
ğŸŒ³  In collaboration with Alliance of Bioversity International and CIAT we demonstrated the limitations and challenges of inclusive climate finance - and made clear recommendations for improvements for the next NDC process. https://lnkd.in/e4Q_zxVk

We have more reasons to be optimistic than not. With concerted and collaborative efforts, reversing land degradation rates and deforestation rates is possible. At Tree Aid weâ€™ll continue to raise the voice of those on the front line of the climate crisis and we wonâ€™t rest until weâ€™ve achieved our mission.

Have a great Christmas everyone!

postContent:
Delighted to take partÂ in an Innovationzero-AR panel yesterday exploring Building Bridges to Sustainable Finance. Great to speak alongside Beverley Gower-Jones OBE FEI, Yvonne Deane Harte and Ingrid Holmes examining what is required to create the optimal enabling environment for cleantech innovations to stay funded through successive rounds and achieve commercialisation and scale. We asked how investors can collectively coordinate and streamline the process by which an innovation moves from Seed to Series A, B, and beyond. The discussion covered: 

1. Demand side dynamics and the role of accelerators and facilities, PPP and others, that can work with the people that have a lab-proven technology and bring them through Pilot to Demo to FOAK, understanding that FOAK is the ultimate goal from the start.

2. Supply side dynamics and the role of concessional capital and the risk-sharing mechanisms that can lower the cost of capital and bring debt into the project sooner.

For more on this topic, please read our latest edition of the Green Finance Quarterly https://shorturl.at/uAYUW, particularly p.11.

#greenfinance #cleantech

It was fantastic to travel to Copenhagen and meet with all the thought leaders who are driving change and deploying capital into the green economy. Seeking and generating alpha with a decarbonisation mandate is alive and kicking.

postContent:
Open Letter to Travelodge CEO, MP for Scunthorpe & Humberside Police 
Yet another OTS Group service van stolen overnight while parked at Travelodge Scunthorpeâ€”and another targeted in an attempted theft. This is not the first time. Last year, we had the same issue at a Premier Inn, and hundreds of businesses have shared similar experiences.

Estimated Â£5,000â€“Â£8,000 losses per incident
No police presence or follow-up
No security improvements by hotels
 "Vehicles left at ownerâ€™s risk"â€”even in paid parking

This must change. We call for:
 âœ… Travelodge & UK hoteliers to state how they will improve vehicle security.
 âœ… MP for Scunthorpe to raise this growing issue affecting tradespeople.
 âœ… Humberside Police to review response policies for overnight thefts.
Tradespeople, contractors, and SMEs deserve better. Weâ€™re amplifying the voices of thousands working hard to support the UK economyâ€”only to be targeted, unsupported & left out of pocket.
If you or your business has faced similar incidents, comment, share & support this message. Letâ€™s push for real action.

#SecureParking
#ProtectTradespeople
#Travelodge
#TradesAtRisk
#UKSMEs 
#HumbersidePolice

postContent:
After 35 years with Cornwall Council it is finally time to move on. As from next week I am excited to be taking up the position of Chief Executive at the Council of the Isles of Scilly following the retirement of Paul Masters. I will be joining at an exciting time for the Council and the Islands and I am looking forward to the challenge of running  the most unique unitary Council in the UK that is 28 miles off the coast of England in the Atlantic Ocean.

I enjoyed my time at Cornwall Council and wish all my colleagues past and present all the best in the future. The  last 10 years being involved with the Cornwall Pension Fund and the wider  LGPS community was probably the most rewarding and exciting period and I hope the fund continues its exciting journey ...and is successful as I still have an interest as both an employer and employee in the fund!
author: Russell Ashman

postContent:
Agency owners are a smart and entertaining bunch.
 
Not only did I have a brilliant time with 100 of them at the â€œLong Lunchâ€ last weekâ€¦but I had some fascinating conversations too.
 
Artificial Intelligence came up â€“ of course it did â€“ so I decided to do a little experiment.
 
I followed up with 15 of the Agency Leaders I spoke with and asked them about the conversations theyâ€™d had throughout the day.
 
Then I took their replies and loaded them into Bard*.

---

Bard gave me this summary:
 
ğ—§ğ—®ğ—¹ğ—²ğ—»ğ˜: This word is mentioned 6 times, which suggests that the challenge of finding and retaining talent was a significant challenge for people in 2023.
 
ğ—”ğ—œ: This word is mentioned 5 times, which suggests that the impact of artificial intelligence on the creative industry was a topic of interest.
 
ğ—¥ğ—²ğ—°ğ—¿ğ˜‚ğ—¶ğ˜ğ—ºğ—²ğ—»ğ˜: This word is mentioned 5 times, which further emphasizes the challenge of finding and retaining talent.
 
ğ—šğ—¿ğ—¼ğ˜„ğ˜ğ—µ: This word is mentioned 4 times, which suggests that despite the challenges, there was still some growth this year.
 
ğ—˜ğ—°ğ—¼ğ—»ğ—¼ğ—ºğ˜†: This word is mentioned 3 times, which suggests that the economic climate was a factor in the challenges faced by businesses this year.
 
ğ—–ğ—¼ğ—»ğ—»ğ—²ğ—°ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—»: This word is mentioned 3 times, which suggests that building relationships with other agency professionals was seen as an important way to navigate the challenges faced by the industry.

----

That pretty much sums up my recollection of the discussions too. A tough year, but plenty of reasons to be optimistic. 

And just to be clear, no-one thought AI was going to take all the creative industry jobs. There is an expectation it will be disruptive, but not apocalyptic. 
 
Thanks to Susie McFarland for organizing this annual Christmas get together. 
 
*Bard chosen for no particular reason in this case.
 
#longlunch #christmasparty #agencyowners #2023reflections

author: Kirsty Owen-Hayward

postContent:
Attention all pubs, clubs and bars - and people who like to go to them! Will you help us save lives?
April is Testicular Cancer Awareness Month and we will be starting a brand new awareness-raising campaign to help people learn about the signs of testicular cancer and how to spot them. 
Will you help, by stocking our new beer mats in your venue? 
The earlier testicular cancer is spotted, the higher the chance of survival, so every single beer mat could literally save the life of one of your customers.
Just comment below or email hello@itsinthebag.org.uk and we'll send you some.
And if you don't run a pub but you do go to a pub, we would love it if you could ask them next time you're in! We reckon if every follower asked their local pub we could get the campaign covering pretty much the whole of south-west England - now there's a challenge for you!
(Not a pub-goer yourself? There are lots of other ways to help - check out the Raising Awareness Saves Lives link in our LinkTree for some ideas!)
#beermats #coasters #beerlovers #pub #club #bar #southwestUK #craftbeer #itsinthebag #charity #menshealth #southwestUK #checkyourballs #testicularcancer

This style of teaser and reveal campaign has become very popular within the entertainment industry and we can see why! Its effectiveness is undeniable, and Forwards is the latest example of how it gets people talking.

Forwards have just released their first wave of artists so make your guesses quickly!

So Iâ€™m going to be very honest, my orders are down this year for the first time in 9 years of being a full time marine artist. 
In the last 2 months Iâ€™ve had hardly any enquiries or results from any of the Ad campaigns on Facebook etc. 

For the first time in 9 years Iâ€™m now debating about getting another part time job. I was really hoping that I could get to the 10 year mark which would be March next year, but at the moment itâ€™s not sustainable. 

Iâ€™m not sure what the reason is, I like to think I price my work fairly for the amount of time each piece takes. 
Maybe itâ€™s just the economic climate at the moment? 
Either way, I donâ€™t think my work is being seen enough or by the right people. 

If any of you out there feel the urge to help a girl out by sharing my work, my Instagram @theyachtartist, my website or maybe you might know someone who would be interested in commissioning a painting from me, please help! ğŸ˜…ğŸ™ğŸ¼

postContent:
Is it time to grab a box of matches and set fire to your social guidelines? 'Chaos cultureâ€™ is the phrase we're hearing again and again at the moment.

The days of polished, high-production content are gone. Consumers want raw, unfiltered and unexpected content that grabs their attention and keeps them hooked.

Creatives have been given the green light to break the rules. Even the biggest brands are embracing the chaos. Just look at Duolingoâ€™s owl; killed off, resurrected and sparking a social media frenzy in the process.

Buckle up, things are about to getâ€¦interesting.

#ChaosCulture #SocialMediaTrends #Marketing
author: Charlotte Laing

postContent:
Authentic guest interactions are where the magic happens. You never *quite* know whatâ€™s coming next â€“ and thatâ€™s exactly why they're so entertaining. Now more than ever, in the age of AI, people want to see people, not just polished content. Thatâ€™s why we love stepping out from behind the screen and connecting with our clientsâ€™ audiences in real life.

From surprise giveaways to quick-fire opinions and behind-the-scenes moments, itâ€™s these genuine interactions that spark real engagement and lasting brand love.

#SocialMediaAgency #MarketingStrategy #GuestEngagement #ContentAgency #ContentCreators

postContent: As we start our 7th year since we completed our move into an empty building in St Anne's, Bristol, it is a good time to reflect on the transformation of the factory and the incredible progress of Taylor Brothers. The factory is now filled with a wide array of print equipment that enables us to be a modern, high quality and dynamic print company. An ongoing investment program has seen many installations of new equipment added  to keep us at the forefront of print quality and innovation. The journey has not always been smooth particularly with Covid hitting a short time after our move but our commitment and endeavour has never waivered and we are very proud of the progress in our business and its unique heritage. When reflecting it is important to acknowledge the positive contribution of our staff and supplier network that continue to be a vital part of the business every day. Finally, a big thank you to all our customers that continue to put their trust in our skills and expertise to create fantastic printed products. We really appreciate the faith you have in us as we continue our love of print.

postContent:
Big news to kick off 2025 from us at The Table Creative!

As we enter a brand-new year, weâ€™re reflecting on the incredible growth and change we experienced in 2024. Since starting The Table Creative in 2016, weâ€™ve evolved in many ways. The dedication of our fantastic team and the trust and encouragement from those around us have enabled us to grow alongside the changing needs of our clients. Now, weâ€™re taking the next step in our journey - and itâ€™s a big one!

From January 2025, The Table Creative has become The Rez Group.
This is more than a name change. Weâ€™re growing from one brand into three, creating a collective of specialist CGI studios to better serve different industries. While our name evolves, the core of what makes us special, our team, our values, and our dedication to creating incredible work, remains the same.

Let me introduce you to our new brands:

ProRez: A CGI studio dedicated to product-based businesses and manufacturers. Whether itâ€™s beautifully styled interior scenes or professional pack shot environments, we create photorealistic imagery that showcases your products in the best light.

HyRez: A bespoke property CGI brand, crafting photorealistic stills, animations, and interactive imagery that bring developments to life.

This shift is about creating space for our team to excel and grow in exciting new ways while delivering even greater value to our clients through focused expertise to meet the unique needs of different sectors while continuing to provide the high-quality work you know us for. Weâ€™re incredibly excited about whatâ€™s ahead!

Whether youâ€™ve worked with us, supported us, or followed our journey, thank you for being part of it.

Hereâ€™s to the future of The Rez Group!

postContent:
Why bother with sales training?  Well I was having a conversation with a sales director this week..  He said 'I'm frustrated with my team, I see them working hard, they tell me they are working hard....but....they are not working hard at the things I want them to be working hard on!'  Bridging this gap is what our clients strive to achieve.  Our sales training takes individuals from being 'unconsciously incompetent' That is working hard but not at what the business wants from them.  To achieving the state of being 'unconsciously competent'.  Working 'naturally' on exactly what the business wants.
We can all break rocks, but wouldn't it be better if we were breaking the ones our business wants us to break.
author: Roy Bowles

postContent: If you plan to make a cold call to me, just remember...  I am not expecting your call when my phone rings, I am busy, I am not your best mate, I don't know you, don't ask me how I am today.  If you want to attract my attention and achieve genuine interest that starts a genuine conversation with me, then simply...Talk to me clearly and tell me the reason for your call and why I should be interested and what I could potentially get out of this call.  What problems do you fix for your customers?  If you are finding that most of your prospecting calls are not getting off to a good start, then it is likely you are facing one or more of the above.  And if you want to improve I can help.

postContent:
Bob Dylan wrote this in 1964. A time of great change in the USA, Kennedy shot the year before, Cuban crisis, Mr King had his dream of a world void of segregation and racism. A time of great change. The first verse of this song applies more now than it did then. It clearly says to us.
See the reality of where we are now, accept it, and if what you have is worth fighting for, then face this fear and take it on. Thatâ€™s how we will move forward and thatâ€™s how we will build our next new reality.  That's my view.

Mr Bob Dylan â€“ The times they are a changinâ€¦

Come gather 'round people wherever you roam
 And admit that the waters Around you have grown
 And accept it that soon You'll be drenched to the bone.
 If your time to you is worth savin'
 Then you better start swimmin' Or you'll sink like a stone
 For the times they are a-changin'.

postContent:
This brave young lady breaks my heart but inspires me massively.

I have 4 kids and many of my LinkedIn friends know a bit about them because I post embarrassing Dad posts on them from time to time. Sorry kids ğŸ˜” 

Like when my singer/songwriter daughter Jen (artist name NORTH) has success I canâ€™t help but post something to celebrate and share. 

This post though isnâ€™t quite as uplifting, sorry. This is about my eldest daughter that our family often calls â€˜the brave oneâ€™, Josie. 

Josie had mild eczema from a baby and a severe nut allergy.

But In 2022 she had something altogether much, much worse.

Imagine being allergic to your own hair? Or feeling youâ€™ve been stung like a bee when water drops touch your skin. Not being able to be hugged or to touch another human being for fear of a skin flare akin to a cheese grater ripping up your skin. Thatâ€™s no exaggeration. 

Every doctor and consultant we saw (and we saw lots) said the same thing, â€œitâ€™s just severe Eczema, take these steroidsâ€. 
Except she didnâ€™t have eczema. She had the awful, painful effects of Topical Steroid Withdrawal (TSW) from using Steroids on her skin and oral digestion. 

The Big Pharma companies supporting the doctors and consultants said â€œitâ€™s just a return of your eczemaâ€.

And each time she finished a course of steroids the â€˜eczemaâ€™ (not!) would return even bigger, more painful and disfiguring. Her skin was dropping off her face. 

After a year of searching for help she put her beautiful but disfigured face and her whole soul on TikTok and â€¦

BOOM!

She went viral. Millions viewed it and thousands of TSW victims came forward; all disfigured and many, many mentally destroyed. All shared their Steroid stories, the resulting TSW and the pain. They continue to do so.

Some have sadly committed suicide due to living with this awful, permanently painful affliction. 

And big Pharma continues to deny it. 

Until now. 

The government is waking up to this. They are aware of it.

Josie wants to go further, faster. She wants to stop this now and gain mass awareness so others never have to go through this. 

Hereâ€™s my small ask. Does anyone know a producer, director, filmmaker for Netflix, Channel 4, ITV, BBC or other? She has written her story â€˜Breaking the Silenceâ€™ and wants to share it. I said Iâ€™d ask my LinkedIn friends. God bless, thank you for any contacts.
#netflix #channel4 #itv #bbc #IWD25 #breakingthesilence
author: Richard North

postContent:
Our programmes kicked off again last weekâ€”and as always, itâ€™s the most incredible joy to be in the room meeting our Mums for the first time.

Yes, WWL is about helping Mums find jobs. But itâ€™s about so much more.

When Camilla and I first started WWL, we were focussed on supporting Mums back into work that would give them economic stability for their families. What we didnâ€™t appreciate thenâ€”but have come to realise is EVERYTHINGâ€”is the powerful community thatâ€™s grown out of it.

The friendships, the stories, the sense of belongingâ€¦ so many Mums tell us they finally feel part of something. They feel more positive, more supportedâ€”and from that foundation, the work begins to follow.

One Mum I met last week shared that sheâ€™d been living in a new area for over a year and hadnâ€™t made a single friend. I canâ€™t imagine that kind of loneliness. Within moments, other Mums offered to meet her for coffee. Regardless of her employment outcome, sheâ€™s already less alone and that can only make life better in so many ways.

The world might be getting more high-tech by the day, and there's an ace AI tool for so many things. But in the end, itâ€™s the human connectionâ€”those face-to-face momentsâ€”that are making the biggest difference in getting our Mums back into work.

I absolutely love this video from some of our recent grads....
author: Rachel Mostyn

postContent:
Our reaction to the Welfare overhaul announced today: 

It is vital to realise the true barriers to work, because poor health and not working are often as a result of wider systemic failures. 

One of the huge barriers to employment is the soaring cost - and limited availability - of childcare. The average cost of a part-time (25 hours a week) nursery place for a child under two in England is Â£159.61 a week (Â£8,299.72 a year for 52 weeks). This is up 7.7% from Â£150.89 a week in 2023. For some, these costs can make it simply unaffordable to work.

Social housing issues and insufficient SEND provision create further barriers for many parents who wish to work. 126,040 households in England are homeless in temporary accommodation â€“ up 16% in a year. Those households with children increased by 15.7% to 80,530.

These overlapping issues are holding many people back from the labour market. 

We work with hundreds of economically inactive Mums who want to work. There's a big role here for specialist organisations to help unpick and address the complex barriers that people face, but there also needs to be an acknowledgment of these other factors that keep many Mums away from employment.

As an organisation, we have also supported Mums on PIPs who want to work. The desire to work is clear but it is also important for employers to recognise these barriers and give everyone a chance.

It is essential that these deep-rooted barriers to employment are tackled.
author: The Women's Work Lab

postContent:
When Camilla Rigby and I founded The Women's Work Lab, one of our biggest goals was to make professional spaces feel more welcoming and inclusive for all women. So many of the Mums who helped shape WWL told us they felt disconnected from the professional worldâ€”like they didnâ€™t belongâ€”simply because they had been away from the workplace for so long.

Thatâ€™s why today felt so special. A group of our Women's Work Lab Mums attended the fantastic West of England Mayoral Combined Authority Good Employment Charter International Women's Day event at Engine Shed. We heard from inspiring speakers like Lisa Upton from Thought Bubbles and Hazel Hayden from Bristol Menopause & Wellwoman Clinic. I was also delighted to join Kay Howick, FCIPD and Sabrina Shutter for a panel discussion on supporting women returning from maternity leave. Oh, and of courseâ€”there was plenty of networking too!

The whole event felt truly inclusive, and the feedback from our Mums was incredible. In our training, we often talk about â€˜the shiny officesâ€™ in townâ€”how they can feel intimidating from the outside, like they arenâ€™t spaces for everyone. But today was proof that wherever you are on your journey back to work, professional spaces should belong to us all.

Huge thanks to Genzenia Charles, Toby Howkins and the team for hosting such a brilliant event! ğŸ™Œ #IWD #Inclusion #WomenAtWork #CareerConfidence

Camilla Rigby and I are absolutely thrilled to have won the Cambridge Social Innovation Prize 2024 from the University of Cambridge ğŸ‰ 

We're also making history as the first-ever co-winners, which feels so The Women's Work Lab- our job share status being recognised at such a high level is amazing. ğŸ’ª

This prize is a little different from others. Itâ€™s not just about celebrating our work; itâ€™s a monetary award specifically for our own professional development. The idea is to grow ourselves so we can grow our impact. Plus, weâ€™re getting incredible support from the Cambridge Centre for Social Innovation, Cambridge Judge Business School & Trinity Hall, which is proving invaluable.

So far, weâ€™ve been doing some executive coaching with the brilliant Suzy Stollery MA FCIPD from Beside Ltd. Having a mix of joint and individual coaching has been a game-changer, especially as we head into this exciting phase of national growth. We also recently did The PRINTÂ® Survey, which digs into personality types, motivations, and behaviors. Iâ€™ve never done anything like it beforeâ€”it was SO eye-opening. What we discovered is that the magic of our partnership isnâ€™t just a feeling; itâ€™s an actual real thing. Weâ€™re so different, yet our strengths and development areas balance each other out perfectly. It has given us loads to think about in how we can keep bringing out the best in each other. Honestly, itâ€™s such a joy to do all this alongside someone I care about so so much ğŸ’›

Big congrats to the other amazing winners, Izzy Obeng, Daryl Chambers & JR Josephs and a huge thank you to Graham Ross Russell for funding this prize. If you want to learn more or apply for 2025, check it out here: https://lnkd.in/gg6j6p4G

Through our evaluations, we work closely with employers, policymakers, and participants to ensure that skills, training, and employment programmes truly meet the needs of the individual, the wider workforce and employers. Recent projects have explored:

When considering a Management Buyout (MBO) or Management Buy-In (MBI),Â understanding the true value of your businessÂ is one of the most importantâ€”and often misunderstoodâ€”steps.
Too many deals are derailed because expectations arenâ€™t aligned between owners, management teams, and funders.
ğŸ”Â Hereâ€™s what you need to know:
Valuation isnâ€™t just a numberÂ â€” it's a story about future earnings, market position, and perceived risk.
EBITDA multiples, adjusted earnings, and growth potentialÂ play key roles in determining value for MBO/MBI purposes.
Independent valuation adviceÂ is criticalâ€”emotions and personal attachments can cloud judgement.
Structuring mattersÂ â€” How much is paid upfront versus deferred can drastically change the deal dynamics.
ğŸ’¡Â Getting your valuation rightÂ ensures you donâ€™t leave value on the tableâ€”or scare off your own management team with unrealistic numbers.
At theÂ GJC MBO/MBI Academy, we break down the key valuation principles you need to understand, giving you and your management team the confidence to approach negotiations fairly and strategically.

postContent:
Employer Brand done right in 5 stepsâ€¦.

1ï¸âƒ£ EVP & culture discovery. Unearth your true ways of work, and what you do (& dont) offer folksâ€¦

2ï¸âƒ£ Embed & Operationalise. Through handbooks, rituals and practices.

3ï¸âƒ£ Align external messaging. Job Ads, Career Sites, Interviews and handbooks. All need to be a true reflection of life inside your org

4ï¸âƒ£ Openly Roadmap PX opportunities. Take the improvement areas surfaced in step 1ï¸âƒ£ and build a roadmap of opportunity areas to elevate PX. Make it open. 

5ï¸âƒ£ Build in Public as a people team. Document and share your journey, builds, project progress. This is the most authentic content you could every craft when it comes to PX. 

6ï¸âƒ£ Manage. This isnt a one-hit project. You need to manage this regularly through feedback loops like â€˜reality checkâ€™ surveys to track whether lived experience matches whatâ€™s been sold to folks when joining.

postContent: I completed my Movember last week, just wanted to thank everyone who gave money to me, or anyone else, supporting this wonderful charity. With 2 out of every 5 men likely to experience a premature death... I used the inspiration of my Great Grandfather Frank who died in his early 40's, unfortunately, leaving a legacy that affected how men in my family thought about their own mortality for at least two generations... so it's never he wrong time to go see your doctor, it's never the wrong time to talk pick up the phone and talk to a friend... it's never too late to think about what you eat and how much you move... thanks again for supporting Movember.
author: Phil Ashley

postContent:
The good looking chap sporting the splendid moustache is my Great Grandfather Frank Ashley, who died aged 45 in1906. This month I will try to replicate his moustachioed look by supporting Movember ...which is a global charity that funds men's health projects, such as mental health, prostate cancer and testicular cancer... too many young men still pass far too early, just like Frank, some of which is preventable.

So I will be raising awareness by looking vaguely ridiculous in the month of November... please bear with me...and if you desperately want you can give a few pounds to charity.... https://lnkd.in/eyez5q_A

postContent:
Brunel Insurance Brokers proudly announces the acquisition of the renewal rights to Liability & General Insurance Brokers Ltd (L&G), an esteemed Independent Broker based in Framlingham. This strategic move underscores Brunel's commitment to expanding its UK footprint with the opening of its seventh office, and a new presence in East Anglia.

Russell Lane, CEO of Brunel Group, expressed his excitement about the acquisition, stating, "We have long admired David and his team's dedication to putting clients first. The alignment between L&G and Brunel as true independent brokers makes this acquisition a natural fit for us. It has also been a group objective to have a physical presence and office in such a key geographical area. We are committed to investing heavily in the region, and expanding our team to better serve our clients."

In conjunction with the acquisition, Brunel will be opening a new office in East Anglia having recently secured premises in Stowmarket, and is actively recruiting for various positions, including Account Handlers, Account Brokers, and Account Executives. This expansion reflects Brunel's commitment to addressing the needs of businesses in the region and providing them with a wider range of insurance solutions, employee benefits, wealth management and mid to high net worth offering. 

Matt Harlin, Managing Director of Brunel Insurance Brokers, commented on the strategic significance of the acquisition, saying, "This acquisition marks a significant milestone for us in delivering local community broking to the region. David's leadership qualities and entrepreneurial drive will undoubtedly contribute to our continued growth and success. We eagerly anticipate welcoming David and his team into our management fold. We have a tried and tested model with a core focus on clients, and relishing the opportunity to make a real difference to local people and businessesâ€. 

David Mangan, Managing Director of Liability and General Insurance Brokers Ltd, shared his perspective on the acquisition, stating, "I have ran a successful business for 10 years, and the decision to sell was driven by the opportunity for support and investment from a true independent broker like Brunel. I am excited about the next chapter with Brunel, and living locally know exactly what is required to deliver a market leading proposition, and confident that together, we will build one of the largest brokers for the regionâ€. 

The acquisition of L&G's renewal rights signifies a strategic step forward for Brunel Insurance Brokers as it continues to expand its presence, at a time when the group is benefiting from significant growth, and profitability.
author: Brunel Insurance Brokers

postContent:
Thereâ€™s an elephant in the room.
 
Itâ€™s big, and blue-coloured with gold stars. It also has a name - the EU Mobility Package. Which is an odd name for an elephant, but donâ€™t be fooled... itâ€™s still potentially a jumbo headache for transport operators.
 
Whilst weâ€™re leaving the EU proper in a matter of weeks, under the transition agreement, regulations that come into force before December 31st have to be adopted into UK law. The Mobility Package is one of them, so our EU elephant will shortly be wearing the Union flag.

While most of the package deals with international journeys, it also calls for enforcement of a piece of regulation which will have the greatest domestic impact - EU562/2014 Article 36 & 34. 

Basically, all drivers are now required to have a full 28 days records of all activity and inactivity for each and every day on their digi-card. For periods when the driver is away from the vehicle, these need to be input manually prior to commencing their next period of driving. Fine if this is just a daily or weekly rest - but a huge pain in the proverbials for occasional drivers.

So, not quite the early Christmas present drivers might be looking for, but one that I can help them with to ensure a happier new year... 

https://lnkd.in/dSJxMVc

postContent:
6:30am today, on site quality-checking Drivers' Daily Defect Checks; not newsworthy in itself, but the shocking thing was the surprise bemusement of the Plant Manager and other drivers who had never seen a Transport Manager on site before!

Transport Managers checking to ensure that their drivers are undertaking Daily Defect Checks correctly should be commonplace. The DVSA Guide to Maintaining Roadworthiness states, 'a way of monitoring the quality of the daily check is to have a visiting agent or competent in-house member of staff re-examine the vehicle as it leaves or enters the operating centre. The inspection result can be checked against the driver's defect reports to ensure the driver's check is of sufficient quality.'

I believe more Transport Managers should ensure defect checks are not just a tick box exercise as that potentially puts dangerous vehicles on the road.

Sunhouse is now BCorpâ„¢ Certified and we are a member of 1% for the PlanetÂ®

When we set Sunhouse up, in a tiny attic in 2008, we were determined to create an agency that above all had positivity running through its veins. Yes we had aspirations to work with great brands, yes we were determined to create great work, but from the outset we were insistent that that had to be done in our own, positively different way.

Now a team of 40 amazing people with a rich and diverse network of clients, we have far more responsibility and far more pressure, so keeping that positive Sunhouse culture alive is more important now than it ever has been. But how do we do that? It canâ€™t just be pool tables, Labradors, free ice cream and the odd beer, it has to run far deeper than that.

A few years ago we joined a global Climate march. Taking to the streets in our hometown of Bath we beat our drums (actually an upturned canoe) and our team created amplification stations, making live posters for the marchers so they could get their protest heard. With the whole agency involved the positive buzz from that day still resonates now. It was culturally way more powerful than any party weâ€™ve had, and we have had some parties.

Last year we rebranded Work For Good, a beautiful team of people who are making a real difference, working their socks off to help businesses raise money for charities they care about (look these guys up â€“ they are awesome!). For the team at Sunhouse the experience of working to create something effective, for great people and a great cause, further deepened the positivity running through the agency.

So whatâ€™s next? We are very excited to announce that we are BCorpâ„¢ certified and have become a member of 1% for the PlanetÂ®.

As many of you will know B Corpâ„¢ certification measures a companyâ€™s entire social and environmental impact. With certification we become part of a global movement of companies who are pushing for change and who prioritise the environment and society in the way they do business. It doesnâ€™t stop here, in 3 years weâ€™ll be tested again, so it is now up to us to improve on our score and keep pushing to be better.

On our BCorpâ„¢ journey we learnt about 1% for the PlanetÂ®, an alliance of businesses who understand the necessity of protecting the natural environment. We will donate 1% of our gross sales (regardless of profit) to some of the thousands of environmental partners tackling the planetâ€™s most pressing environmental issues.Â When we all work together, 1% adds up.

I think thereâ€™s an outdated sense in business that if you want to make money you have to somehow compromise your values, but weâ€™re discovering with initiatives like B Corpâ„¢ and 1% for the PlanetÂ®, and by working with great people, clients and partners that it doesnâ€™t have to be that way. We can use business as a force for good and that is the simplest way to keep our special brand of positivity alive.

#positivelydifferent
author: Tom Maurice

postContent:
Do you have a borehole that is picking up bad water quality results?

It may require a makeover in the form of a re-line.

Old and aging boreholes can suffer from corrosion, steel casing installed all thoughs years ago could be past there life span and allowing unwanted surface groundwater to enter your borehole, this could not only effect water quality, it can allow cascading water in the borehole which can lead to iron bacteria breeding and clogging up you borehole.

Drilcorp have an answer, rather than drill a new borehole, if you have a large enough diameter you can re-line your borehole. 

There are various methods to cover most diameters and materials,
At Drilcorp we have the Experiance to handle all.

Why not contact info@drilcorp.com for a no obligation quotation.

Boreholes are our Business.

#drilcorp #borehole #drilling #drinkingwater #processwater #breweries #distilleries #water #borestorer #artesian #openloopgeothermalheating #aquifer

We understand how important it is for people to have a solid understanding of sustainability, particularly within the housing sector, so that we can all do our bit to live more economically and tackle the challenges facing our planet.
 
This is why weâ€™ve created Sustainable Futures, an introductory virtual programme for our customers to learn more about sustainable living. The sessions have been developed as part of our Greenoak Centre of Excellence initiative.
 
Each session, delivered by a member of Stonewaterâ€™s retrofit and sustainability teams, or an external expert such as fuel poverty charity National Energy Action, covers topics such as understanding how global warming and greenhouse gases effect housing.
 
Participants have also been learning about energy efficiency, emissions, fuel poverty and EPC ratings.

postContent:
During my maternity leave, between the cuddles, chaos, and cat naps, I challenged myself to keep learning â€” and Iâ€™m proud to share that I completed MiniMBA

Diving in as the newly appointed CEO of automotive brand Bonetti was daunting enough when every decision counts, but the healthy dose of competitiveness as the weeks went on actually became pretty fun... Thanks Mark Ritson! The course gave me new perspectives on leadership, strategy and innovation with a highlight being decision analysis with Yael Grushka-Cockayne. Iâ€™m excited to apply these insights as I step back into my role.

Balancing professional growth with a new chapter in life wasnâ€™t easy. But it helped me feel myself when at points I felt anything but. A big thank you to Josh Nesfield FRSA who supported me along the way.

For anyone considering upskilling during a career breakâ€”whether maternity leave or otherwiseâ€”Iâ€™d highly recommend it and the Mini MBA. Luckily I could listen and learn whilst pacing around the park with a sleeping baby!

Would love to hear from others whoâ€™ve navigated learning alongside big life changes. How did you find it?

#MiniMBA #CareerDevelopment #MaternityLeave #Leadership

postContent:
New business - how we facilitate it and how we demonstrate value to prospective clients is a huge focus of all agency leadership, particularly in the current climate after a very tough 2024 for many. 

It was refreshing to get together in person this morning to talk all things new business with other agency leaders, see some familiar faces and make new connections. 

Our table discussions covered everything from our shared challenges to how a new business process can be better embedded across the business.

For me, where agencies can be overly reliant on leadership to drive new business, investing in a strong and consistent marketing and sales process combined with team training and inclusion sets up the wider agency to support with agency growth. 

Big thanks to The Wow Company for hosting this Agency Bites and for facilitating Rory Spence â­ 

#newbusiness #agency

postContent:
At the moment only 43% of people who request social care from their local authority receive it. We're developing a digital service that will help many more people get legal advice and support to access the social care they have a right to. We want as many people as possible to understand that this service exists and they are not alone. To do this we're running an insight questionnaire to understand people's perception of social care so our messaging will hit the right notes with people. Please can you help me by filling in the questionnaire? It is short, 60 seconds max.

ğŸ‘‰ https://lnkd.in/eZQjmqfi

ğŸ™‹ğŸ½â€â™€ï¸Do you need to be looking for social care? NO. 

Everyone will need social care at some point, maybe for your parents, yourselves or someone you care for, so your opinion is exactly what we need to hear.

Please do it and share with others so we get a broad understanding of people's perceptions. Many, many thanks,

postContent:
What if I told you that you are playing small?

Or that it's likely that YOU:
- have a niggling feeling that you are intended for more, but lack the courage to go for it. 
- are scared of judgement if you try.
- don't know how to bring the change that you want to see in your life and so you stay right where you are.

What if I told you that:
- you ALREADY have the courage inside of you
- other peopleâ€™s opinions of us are none of our business
- together we can bring the change. 

Since launching Freckles Childcare 5 years ago, ONE thing that has remained consistent throughout is that I have to BELIEVE IN MYSELF.

Believing in yourself requires confidence and confidence (for me) is defined by 5 pillars; foundations, body, self, career and life.

I have spent the past 5 years building on my confidence so that I show up fearlessly.

I am NOT fearless all of the time but on the days when I fall down my foundations of confidence are so strong that I get BACK UP again and I carry on.

On Wednesday night I opened the doors to Fearless Female academy ğŸ™Œ where members will move from low self-belief to CONFIDENCE. Where together we will show up as the FEARLESS FEMALES we are truly meant to be.

Join / find out more here ğŸ‘‰ https://lnkd.in/dX8Q45x #fearlessfemale

postContent:
ğŸŒÂ What does real climate impact look like?

For us atÂ Carbon Kind, it starts by puttingÂ local communitiesÂ at the heart of carbon projects.

Weâ€™re developingÂ high-integrity, certified carbon initiativesÂ in West Africa -  from clean cookstove distribution and borehole rehabilitation, to regenerative biochar farming. 

Every project isÂ community-led, transparent, and designed to deliverÂ measurable social and environmental impact.

By supporting our work, partners are not only reducing or removing carbon, theyâ€™re:
- Restoring ecosystems
- Increasing access to safe water
- Empowering women and smallholder farmers
- Driving climate justice

Weâ€™re building a better model for offsetting â€“ one rooted in trust, transparency, and transformation.

If you're a carbon consultant or sustainability lead looking for ethical, traceable credits, Iâ€™d love to connect and hear how you're thinking about quality and integrity in this space.

author: Vashti Seth

postContent:
ğŸŒÂ Ethical Carbon Credits: Why They Matter to Me

For a long time, I believed carbon credits were just about offsetting emissions, and, to be honest, I wasn't sure if they were truly beneficial. But my journey has shown me they can beÂ genuinely transformativeÂ when done right.

Through our projects, like restoring boreholes and distributing fuel-efficient cookstoves in rural Togo, Iâ€™ve seen firsthand how ethical carbon credits create powerful change, not just for the climate, but for the lives of real people in communities that have contributed the least yet are impacted the most by climate change.

These initiatives don't simply cut carbon, they provide families with safe water, healthier homes, and pathways out of poverty. WhenÂ communities drive the solutions, the outcomes are more resilient, equitable, and genuinely transformative.

Real change happens when we focus on lasting, community led, climate projects ğŸŒ±

#ClimateJustice #CarbonCredits #CommunitySolutions #Sustainability #CarbonKind

The bigger the business the worse they areâ€¦.Barclays, our business bank of 18 years (donâ€™t even mention British Gas or BT to me ha!!) wtf? 

Poorly trained staff, automated phone systems, repetitive synthesizer shit music on hold for 45 minutes to be told to call this numberâ€¦.bounce, bounceâ€¦repeat. 5 different numbers / departments. No solution other than me feeling like slamming my head in a door! 5 hours has been spent trying to make two basic updates. 

Trying to save money when theyâ€™ve got Â£millions of our money already. Conclusion, they hemorrhage customers (as one advisor told me) Madness!

author: Richard Flemmings

postContent:
A super engaging and thought provoking day at Rothamsted Research institute today for a workshop discussing the Transition to Regenerative Agriculture - thanks to Emma Chapelhow, Katherine Wotherspoon and the UK Agri-Tech Centre team for the invitation.

Regenerative agriculture is necessary. But the transition isn't easy. It requires a push from the whole supply chain. Plus supporting governance and regulation. Plus consumer buy in. Plus the right innovation, data and evidence.

Although it's difficult, conversations like today, with a varied and informed group of stakeholders will help to move the dial.

Brilliant Rothamsted facility tour at the end of the day - what a treat to see the world's oldest ongoing scientific experiment, including curated soil samples dating back to the 1840s! ğŸ¤“
author: Richard Flemmings

postContent:
It was a pleasure to have coordinated a housing roundtable discussion at Geocom conference recently, all now summarised within an Association for Geographic Information (AGI) report, available at the link below.

We couldnâ€™t have wished for a better chair in Alexandra Notay, Hon MRTPI, who facilitated a well organised, energetic and constructive discussion - no mean feat with a 1 hour time window and 20 brilliant contributors from a wide range of backgrounds!

My key takeaways when asking the question â€œHow do we make better use of geospatial across the housing sector, and bridge the gap between technology owners and technology end users?â€ - we need more story telling, more collaboration, and less jargon.

Lots of excellent follow on conversations are already happening (and watch this space for news of a new geospatial housing network launching soon).

https://lnkd.in/eu9ZtA4J
author: Richard Flemmings

postContent:
Great to have integrated Planet data into our ground breaking Windermere project last year.

The additional level of detail within the imagery allowed us to bring fresh evidence to the discussion about the Cunsey mass fish death, and continue to question whether an algal bloom was actually responsible.

Map Impact are now working in other catchments across the UK, applying satellite data (alongside other data sources) to understand catchment wide factors that influence fresh water quality. Feel free to drop me a note if you'd like to know more.
author: Richard Flemmings

postContent:
I can't speak highly enough of this book.

At times it gave me a sense of hopelessness, as the impacts of agricultural industrialisation are described in brutal first-hand detail. Decimation of rural communities and nature, all greatly accelerated during my lifetime. And all set in the global context of needing to find a way to continue to feed 8 billion people.

But the hopelessness turned to hopefulness, as a method is laid out for managing a landscape in a balanced way, to allow nature and agriculture to flourish together. It's not perfect. And compromise and collaboration is required. But it is possible to do things differently and break the mould of: â€œmore, cheaper, fasterâ€.

I was mid-way through reading this when the DEFRA Landuse Consultation was launched last week, which was timely. This should be on a compulsory reading list for anyone involved.

If anyone in my network has already read this one, Iâ€™d love to hear your thoughts.

https://lnkd.in/epkqwv63
author: Richard Flemmings

postContent:
LVS Ascot- early morning to continue the fight!

Finally met the great Jess Staufenberg after many emails to arrange a visit to our wonderful school- although neither of us recognised each other until the end! (Was a bit early!) Thank you Kay Burley at Sky News for hosting our discussion this morning on the Labour policy to add VAT to education possibly as early as January 2025.

There is such strength of feeling for both sides of the argument and I totally get it- education in the UK needs to get its act together and bring well qualified teachers into the classroom and ensure children are in school to benefit from this expertise. Seeing the posts that are coming through on twitter, there is still fierce debate and this policy was one of the most heated debates during the election period. 

It's a done deal but what happens next counts. 

You can't throw money at a problem and hope it fixes it. You also can't throw money at a problem when you don't have the expected revenue from a policy and the consequences could have disastrous effects on the education of children, both state and independent as well as the public purse.

I'm an advocate of working together to provide the best for every child.

I'm proud of this stance and as always #ProudToBeLVSAscot Licensed Trade Charity Independent Schools Council Independent Schools Association (ISA) The Society of Heads Boarding Schools'â€‹ Association (BSA) #EducationNotTaxation

postContent:
April is stress awareness month and we can all help to manage our own mental health by being aware of the smaller day to day things that can cause stress and have the potential to develop into larger mental health issues.

Identifying smaller issues that can cause stress and putting something positive in place like getting those tasks done first or having a different approach can help.

Try and recognise when you have done something positive for yourself or another and reward yourself with something as little as a cup of tea or a small sweet treat. 

https://lnkd.in/ekUCkM6E

postContent:
Every NHS trust faces unique challenges, but thereâ€™s one they all have in common - fatigue and burnout. 
 
Archus Insight can help to reduce pressures on your staff, providing actionable insight that better supports the work theyâ€™re doing. 
 
Our team of expert healthcare analysts will work closely with you to fortify your Business Intelligence function, ensuring you only have the very best analytical information to inform your decision-making. 
 
By using comparative data, our team of expert consultants can help you to identify new opportunities for service improvements that make life easier for your staff. For example, embracing innovations that reduce length of stay and cut out unnecessary admissions could reduce your workload and - by extension - reduce the risk of mistakes and/or staffing issues caused by burnout. 
 
With regular benchmarking sessions and data reporting, you can even monitor the progress of your modernisation and its impact on your staff. 
 
Message me to find out more.

postContent:
The first step in tackling unfair variation in health services is to identify where the problems are. Our programmes combine data relating to population, deprivation, healthcare infrastructure and clinical outcomes, benchmarking your performance against relevant peers. 

Our consultants work alongside our modular benchmarking programme, which analyses internal, local and national health data to identify key areas of focus.

By better understanding all of the contributing factors, we can provide insight into true unwarranted variations, looking at the reasons why they happen, suggesting an alternate approach and measuring the impact of making those changes over time.

#NHSEngland #NHSData #HealthInnovation #HealthcareProfessionals

postContent:
ğŸ‰ Celebrating 20 Years of Navigating Change Together - A Milestone for Practicus! ğŸ‰

As we mark the 20th anniversary of Practicus this month, we're filled with gratitude and a sense of accomplishment. It's been two decades since we embarked on our mission to help organisations and people navigate through the complexities of business change. This year, we celebrate not just the journey but the successes, challenges and invaluable experiences we've encountered along the way. 

This anniversary is a testament to the dedication of our teams and interims, the trust of our clients and the collaborative spirit that runs through all the work we undertake. 

We'll be commemorating the occasion in a number of ways over the coming weeks but today we're sharing some of the moments from our birthday celebrations on Friday.

As we look to the future, we're excited for what's next. With the same passion and purpose that have guided us for two decades, we're ready to face new challenges, embrace opportunities and continue making a difference in the lives of those we work with.

Here's to 20 years of Practicus, and to many more years of making change work for everyone. Thank you to everyone who's been part of our story - here's to continuing the journey together!

(Particular Thank Yous to Sam Hawkins and Dave Kemble for running an excellent Practicus quiz, Philly Wallin for the Practicus catch-phrase bingo, Darren Tolhurst for the Practicus awards and to everyone involved in making Friday so special, not least Paul Wandless, Boyd Kershaw and Jason Luckhurst for founding this amazing business.)

#Practicus #Anniversary #20Years #ChangeManagement #Celebration #ThankYou #interimmanagement
author: Practicus

postContent:
In these times of disruption and upheaval, itâ€™s always nice to have some good news to share. For that reason, I am very proud of the whole Practicus team who came first in this yearâ€™s Institute of Interim Management (IIM) Survey. Every year for the last six years we have risen up the table, reaching second place last year and third the year before. I think itâ€™s worth taking a moment to say what a herculean effort that is given the strength of the competition and the lengths the IIM goes to in ensuring the survey remains the industry standard for excellence. Team I salute you! And I want to thank everyone who participated in this yearâ€™s survey, nearly 3,000 interim managers all told. 

The next part is the hardest of all, taking the quality of our services still further to better meet the needs of the market while continuing to adapt to the challenges that life throws our way. Given how everyone here adjusted during the lockdown, I feel re-assured that the people at Practicus are up to the task.

postContent:
Unfortunately I need to call out the abhorrent behaviour of Jardine Motors Group, JLR and Grange Hatfield. I am experiencing repetitive diesel particulate filter faults with a JLR approved Land Rover Discovery Sport, I purchased in September 23. 

ğŸ’© 8 weeks into ownership there was an issue with the O2 sensor. I contacted JLR Assist as I had concerns I might breakdown either on a motorway or on a rural road to get to my horses. I was told my vehicle would be safe to drive. Jardine Slough who I purchased the vehicle from were not accepting recoveries until January 24!?! So I reluctantly booked the appointment for the New Year. 

ğŸ’© 25th December Christmas Day- my car went into limp mode, it was unsafe to drive due to loss of power. I then struggled between the dealership and JLR Assist to get the vehicle recovered, no one would take responsibility as to whose responsibility it was to recover the vehicle to the dealer. ğŸ¤¦ğŸ»â€â™€ï¸ Phone call after phone call, I managed to get the car recovered. 

ğŸ’© The DPF needed to be replaced which Jardine Slough undertook under warranty apparently but if I read my warranty document itâ€™s not covered. The part was on back order so it was the end of February before I could collect my repaired vehicle.

ğŸ’© Then at the end of April, the DPF on my vehicle failed again. Yet again a struggle to find a JLR dealership to recover the vehicle to, this time it ended up at Grange Hatfield. Unfortunately, they wanted to charge me Â£3.5k to undertake repairsâ€¦

ğŸ’© My car has been at the dealership since the end of April, I have refused to pay for the repair and I have asked why the DPF would have failed again. Apparently my driving style ğŸ¤£ğŸ«£ğŸ«£

ğŸ’© Mid-September 24, a phone call â€œgood news, my DPF is going to be replaced FOCâ€. Itâ€™s now November, I still donâ€™t have my car as the part is now on back order. ğŸ˜¬ğŸ¤¦ğŸ»â€â™€ï¸

ğŸ’© I have had to buy, tax and insure another vehicle for the 6 months while I have waited for JLR and there is no end in sight. 

The purpose of my post is that I hope anyone planning to purchase a JLR vehicle makes a very considered decision, knowing that for a premium priced brand their treatment of customers is pretty ğŸ’©ğŸ’©ğŸ’©. Then the product itself is not fit for purpose. 

The LinkedIn posts I see Adrian Mardell CEO of JLR demonstrates how deluded and arrogant they truly are as an organisation towards their customers. He also ignores me which is also the stance of the JLR dealership network when I question the quality and integrity of their product. ğŸ¤£ğŸ¤£

Thank you for enduring my lengthy post, feel free to share far and wideâ€¦.

#jlr #discoverysport #scammers #motortrade #landrover

Jaguar Land Rover UK ğŸ’©ğŸ’©ğŸ’©ğŸ’©

postContent:
A Small Business:
- Less than 50 employees
- Turns over under Â£10m
- Average profit Â£13k/year
- Makes up 99% of UK private sector companies
- Employs 61% of UK working people
- Are the back bone of the UK economy

As a small business owner, so far this year, we have seen significant rises in:
â¬† Rent
â¬† Service Charge
â¬† Utilities

And as a business that works with small businesses and is heavily reliant on them being able to invest and recruit, I would be interested to know how a 2% rise in NI contribution for employers will help with growth.

Lets not forget, this is not a 2% rise in cost, it is a 15% rise in that cost for a business. 

As the Politicians say, lets wait for Wednesday and see exactly how 'working people' are going to see improvements over the next 12 months and beyond.

postContent:
Our event as part of Bristol Community Festival on Saturday had 374 visitors ğŸ’š 

The nature of community events is you put in months of organising and staff time and potentially zero people walk through the door. Lucille and I were so proud to bring lots of different groups and activities to our Greenway Centre to platform the community action in Southmead ğŸ˜Š 

We had Southmead's first seed swap with support from the Bristol Seed Swap team.
We launched Southmead Repair Cafe (last Saturday of the month going forward!) with sewists, electrical fixers, and bike repairs.
We talked to people about how to make Southmead's homes more energy efficient and affordable.
We shared soup, welsh cakes, falafel, sushi, and curry made by residents.
Meadows to Meaders gathered new stories for future scripts. 
Our monthly market showcased local makers.
And Men's Space shared their crafts of garden benches and bird boxes.

Just a real lush vibe with lots of new visitors. Want to uplift all my colleagues who supported us in the build up and on the day! ğŸ™Œ 

Lucille Smith, Vicky Wall, Suzanne Daggar, Mark Lemon (Dip SCM), Alex Bennett, Gemma Tilston, Amy Kinnear, Eve Payne, Amy Price, Tom Sollars, Sher Fowler Heidi LeyshonğŸ’š

The compliance and risk landscape is evolving rapidly, and itâ€™s fascinating to see how these changes are shaping the skills that top compliance professionals need to succeed.

ğŸ’  AI & Automation â€“ Itâ€™s not just about being tech-savvy anymore; itâ€™s about understanding how to harness AI to work smarter, handle data faster, and navigate the ethical challenges that come with it.
ğŸ’  Cybersecurity â€“ With cyber threats becoming more sophisticated, candidates who can collaborate with IT teams to stay one step ahead are absolutely essential.
ğŸ’  Proactive Risk Management â€“ Strong analytical skills and the ability to think ahead are now critical. Itâ€™s all about predicting whatâ€™s next and preparing for it.
ğŸ’  Transparency & Ethics â€“ Compliance is more than following regulations, itâ€™s about building trust and aligning with the bigger picture of brand integrity. MiFID IIâ€™s focus on investor protection and transparency highlights just how crucial these skills are in todayâ€™s market.

As a specialist recruiter in Risk and Compliance and passionate about connecting top talent with these opportunities, Iâ€™m always looking for candidates with the skills and mindset to tackle these emerging challenges. 

Are these the top skills to watch, or are there more?
