postContent:
Where did 10 years go?

Matthew Church and I started MAKE in 2013 from scratch. Against advice from pretty much everyone, at the start of 2015, with a new mortgage, newborn sons and a good head of hair, I took the decision to ditch the security of safe employment to take MAKE full-time.

Now MAKE celebrates 10 years of service ğŸ˜€ .

A trait shared by both Matt and I is the desire to always be better. Whilst this drive has helped ensure MAKE is here a decade later, it does mean we are not the best at reflecting on â€œsuccessâ€. So affording ourselves just a brief moment to look back, I have explored what 10 years of MAKE looks like in numbers.

In 2013 I scribbled down a list of values I wanted MAKE to live by. One of these was to â€œdeliver an experience that matches the end product.â€ As we reflect on the past and plan the next 10 years of MAKE, I have spent some time looking at how we balance this value with growing MAKE.

Almost from the day we started we were asked about establishing MAKE in London. To date this is something we have fought against, as we were concerned that over-extending our reach would compromise both the experience and product we deliver. However, our move last year into Devon and with Rob Shipp MCIOB now 18 months in, we are now in a position to grow beyond our traditional south-west base.

To that end, as part of our 10 years celebrations, I'm happy to confirm we are now opening a new London base in addition to our Bristol and Devon teams. This move will help deliver an even better experience for our projects and clients in and around London.

But thatâ€™s not all.

MAKE is not your typical building company and we are always challenging the best way to deliver a project. We are really excited about our newÂ venture coming soon, which will bring the MAKE experience and process to the wider industry. Keep your eyes open for further details in the days and weeks ahead.

Hereâ€™s to the next 10 years.
author: Michael Teeling

postContent:
Those who know us know we like to fly under the radar and work on some great projects that we donâ€™t often get to shout about.

As Founders, Matthew Church and I, made the decision earlier this year to take the next step in MAKE's growth and look to reinforce our leadership team. This summer we managed to bring the fantastic Rob Shipp MCIOB into the business. Rob has been brought on as a Director with responsibility for overseeing the build operations of our business and has been a great appointment.

Now we are looking to take the next step and support Rob with the appointment of a Commercial Manager, to oversee all commercial aspects of our build operations. This is a great opportunity for someone of the same quality and outlook as Rob to join our business for the long term.

This isnâ€™t going to be an appointment made purely on experience, the key for Matt and I is to find someone who can demonstrate an absolute belief in MAKEâ€™s vision to be different, to be better, to work on interesting projects and to be a great place to work.

From my personal experience, I always had the belief that the construction industry could be better. If you think the same and believe you can make a difference, we would love to hear from you.

More details about the role can be found on our website.

We have celebrated our 17th birthday, and saw the amount of money we have raised on behalf of our 60+ charity partners exceed Â£155 million in first year income â€“ something we are really proud of!!

postContent:
Keeping the fluid flowing! The hydraulic control systems onboard the AC75 are fundamental to its operation. If the hydraulic fluid ever stops flowing, the boat stops flying and sailing ğŸ¦¾ğŸ› ï¸
 
The critical importance of these systems is matched only by their complexity and power. They must be designed within a tight framework of rules to be as light, efficient, powerful and fast as possible. And this is done with a fluid pressure equal to, or perhaps even greater than that which is likely to have crushed the Titan submersible on its final undersea journey. 
 
This is engineering on the edge, and it makes the job of maintaining these systems at a peak level of performance very demanding. It all means that the teamâ€™s Hydro squad must be some of the most knowledgeable and experienced people in the business but also some of the hardest working, getting it done day and night - and they are all of that and more.Â We also work with our partners Domin to push the hydraulic boundaries even further, a prime example of how collaboration can lead to innovation ğŸ¤œ ğŸ¤›

postContent:
Domin servo valves are incredibly strong, thanks to the use of maraging steel in our additive manufacturing process. This material was chosen for its exceptional qualities, including a tensile strength of up to 2,000 MPa (290 ksi) and high toughness with elongation at break up to 10%. Maraging steel's low carbon content ensures good machinability and the ability to be cold-rolled up to 90% without cracking. Furthermore, its good weldability allows for small and complex designs without compromising durability and strength.

With heat treatment, maraging steel experiences minimal dimensional change, enabling machining to final dimensions. The high alloy content provides high hardenability, forming ductile FeNi martensites upon cooling, leading to non-existent or negligible cracks. Additionally, these steels can be nitrided for increased case hardness and polished for a fine surface finish, while offering moderate corrosion resistance and resilience to stress corrosion and hydrogen embrittlement. 

The versatility of additive manufacturing allows us to easily make design modifications and seamlessly transition to the manufactured part, ensuring our customers receive valves tailored to their system's specific requirements. 

#innovation #motioncontrol #hydraulics #3Dprinting #automation #technology

The Easter break is on the horizon for schools, with most students breaking up next week. 

Itâ€™s this time of year that is often the ideal moment to take stock of things and find improved ways of working. For example, as a school, is there anything you know could be more efficient?
 
Or even more so, how do you even know if things are operating efficiently? 
 
Looking at catering and food costs is a great starting point. Itâ€™s a chance to find out if your school is getting the best value from its various contracts which are often provided by many suppliers.

A common oversight for busy schools is not putting measures in place to ensure that their food service is operating at its full competency. 
 
It doesnâ€™t matter if your kitchen is run in-house or via outsourced contractors, applying modern measuring techniques allows schools to make key cost-related discoveries, often highlighting huge saving opportunities, which can in-turn be used to drive improvements for all parties. 
 
This is one way to make sure school kitchens are offering the very best food and dining experience possible for their budget, and for their students.

postContent:
Last week we held our first ever Wellbeing Week at The Quality Assurance Agency for Higher Education! Our goal was to promote self-care and wellness, and create something that everyone could get involved with. 

The week consisted of a few different things: 

ğŸ“† A wellbeing calendar with daily suggestions for people to try, ranging from mindfulness exercises to healthy habits and positive actions. 
ğŸ”ˆ A speaker session with the wonderful Kat Thorne who shared her story and how one small habit can change your day. Iâ€™m looking forward to the follow up session in a few weeks.
ğŸ’š A â€˜get to know usâ€™ drop in session with our trained Mental Health First Aiders. A chance to get to know them, find out more about mental health first aid and what that support can look like. 
â˜•ï¸ A â€˜Positivity-teaâ€™ catch up, open to all, where the only rule is: we focus on positive things! We are hoping this will become a monthly thing. 
ğŸ’¬ A Wellbeing Teams channel for sharing ideas, photos and general chit chat - which is so important when working remotely.

I loved doing something different that encouraged prioritising my own mental and physical health, and that of those around me. Iâ€™m looking forward to doing more in this area in the coming months ğŸ™‚

A big shout out to Stephanie Stephenson, Caroline Blackburn, all of our Mental Health First Aiders and to everyone else that got involved - you made the week a success!

postContent:
Stumbled across the below & found it pretty interesting !

The 3 in front are old they walk in front to set the pace of the running group lest they get left behind.

The next 5 are the strongest & best, they are tasked to protect the front side if there is an attack.

The 5 behind them are also among the strongest; they are tasked to protect the back side if there is an attack.

The last one is the LEADER. He ensures that no one is left behind. He keeps the pack unified and on the same path. He is always ready to run in any direction to protect & serves as the 'bodyguard' to the entire group.

Just in case you all wanted to know what it really means to be a leader.

postContent:
We have just successfully completed a significant project for Emery Brothers at Beckford Tower near Bath. Our mission was to design and install an independent access scaffold without intrusive anchors, ensuring full access to the tower.
Additionally, the scaffold was engineered to laterally support a passenger hoist up to a height of 25 meters. The entire structure reached a height of 30 meters, topped with a temporary roof for weather protection.
Our design featured a sophisticated array of plan braces and structural transoms to transfer axial loads into the tower.
A true masterpiece of scaffolding, expertly installed by the dedicated TRS team.
#emerybros #complexscaffold

âš ï¸Take a lookâš ï¸ 

If youâ€™ve ever wondered what the inside of a hot water cylinder looks like then hereâ€™s a fine example as to why they should be inspected annually. 

Vast amounts of scale build up in hot water cylinders. 

This reduces efficiency, increases utility costs but most significantly, provides a lovely environment for bacteria such as Legionella to thrive in. Prevention is better than cure so a well maintained water softener will prevent the scale from forming.

Water softening, internal inspection and acid descaling services all provided by us here at Concept.

 ğŸ”¹ Potable: Internal inspection every 6 months

postContent:
A significant achievement for our real estate client! 49% of energy saving ğŸ“‰
At a large commercial building managed by one of our clients, we were engaged to identify and resolve the reasons for high gas consumption. The boilers were running 24/7 at high temperatures, even in summer months. This led to a significant increase in gas consumption. ETS then dialled in remotely and investigated possible reasons for the boilers staying on constantly. We made remote changes to the boiler control and time schedules and optimised the setpoints over a few days. To ensure these savings remain long-term, we also visited the site to check the boiler control loop strategy and amended this where required. During this visit, we noticed some failed room sensors were linked to the boiler control, leading to the boilers going into frost condition unnecessarily. We removed these sensors, so expect further savings following the on-site changes.

Energy and Carbon reductionğŸŒ±
â€¢ There has been a 49% saving between pre- and post-energy consumption. Estimate of 3x weeks before and 3x weeks after.
â€¢ The avoided consumption was a 68% saving, equivalent to Â£6,300+ over the first 25 days. For this calculation, we compared the actual and expected consumption using heating degree days (now we are in the winter period).

Are you ready for the energy-saving for your properties? Dial in today âš¡
#BuildingEnergyManagementSystem #EnergySavings #CommercialBuildings #EnergyManagement
author: Energy & Technical Services Ltd.

At 100th Monkey, we are proud of the incredible women who make our company what it is - driving impact, supporting one another, and continuously growing. 

We also take immense pride in the many female leaders and team members weâ€™ve had the privilege to train and support. Every week, we help women build their influence, communicate with confidence, and make a lasting impact in their workplaces. Their success is our success, and their leadership makes the world of work better for everyone.

To all the women we work with - inside and outside our company - thank you for your strength, your ambition, and your dedication to lifting others as you rise.

#IWD #teamdevelopment #learninganddevelopment #growth #training
author: The 100th Monkey

postContent:
We saw an instant impact with delegates ten years ago when we pioneered bringing data into our soft skills courses. We measured pace in words per minute, vocal range in Hertz, emphasis levels in decibels and the length of sentences. Trainees said they loved the objective feedback and being able to see tangible steps to progress their communication skills. 

Since then we have continued to seek ways to unlock the science of speaking, and it has been a long held desire to develop an AI tool that we trusted could generate accurate data, align to our frameworks, and complement our way of thinking. 

This is why we are so delighted to have found and partnered with the brilliant people of Yoodli AI Roleplays. The platform really is a game changer for both delegate experience in-session, and critically, for continued learning, post training.

postContent:
Auf Wiedersehen, January! 

It was a month packed with our clientsâ€™ goal setting workshops, annual kick-off meetings, big stage presentations, whole-function trainings â€¦ and a surprising number of 100th Monkey trips to Munich. From what we heard from many clients, it felt like a long month... And itâ€™s certainly been a busy one for us! 

Our highlights:
âœ… Facilitating conversations between leaders and teams to underscore the importance of hÍŸeÍŸaÍŸlÍŸtÍŸhÍŸy, high performing teams in 2025
âœ… Running a new virtual programme for medical field teams across east, central and west coast USA
âœ… Our most ambitious standalone training yet â€“ sharpening the question handling skills of 71 delegates, in six languages, with every delegate role-playing, recorded, played back, and coached â€¦ in three hours! A stellar team performance (pictured)
âœ… Supercharging leadersâ€™ big stage presentation skills for their all-company kick off meeting through bespoke workshops to refine their content and delivery style
âœ… A storytelling masterclass in beautiful Bavaria (pictured), where delegates learned storytelling structures and tools to enhance their impact and influence, and evidence their work with greater power

What a start to the new year! 

We'd love to hear more about how we can support your team in 2025 â€“ drop us a line at hello@100monkey.co.uk

postContent:
A listening dayâ€¦

After the energy and sprint to the finish line of securing our recent round and partnerships, I am engaging a different gear. 

A gear and phase of listening and hearing what is going on out there and how others are viewing the world and next phase of our transition to net zero. 

As a CEO leading on fundraising, I spend so much time pitching and sharing our story, it is really great to sit and listen to the changing trends out there in climate policy, funding and adaptation. 

I am ClimateImpact today listening to others and meeting new friends! 

Say hi if you are here.

postContent:
Come and join us exhibiting and speaking at Innovation Zero on the 29th April. 

I will be mapping out a new way of producing carbon negative building materials and highlighting the massive opportunity for the UK government Department for Business and Trade, building on the years of support from Innovate UK to build our pilot line.

How can we use derelict industrial landscape to create a net zero industry, jobs and revenue (tax) for UK whilst using this model to export UK created IP to help the decarbonise the global construction industry? 

Simplesâ€¦..right? 
All in 15 mins.

Really looking forward to this one!
Let me know if you are going to be there and want to meet up. I shall be there for both days as will our team on our stand. ğŸ‘Š

postContent:
"Careers of imagination" celebrated by Thangam Debbonaire MP

Really great to get a boomsatsuma mention at Bristol24/7's amazing job on the central Bristol hustings this week. Doing the right thing in an increasingly troubled world can be very challenging, but the vocal support from our national representatives is really encouraging, not just for the great team at boomsatsuma but also the incredible young people some from our most marginalised communities that study with us and are seeking to make an active and positive contribution to the creative industries.

It was great to see we even garnered some cross party support from Samuel P. S. Williams the conservative candidate celebrating boomsatsuma support from Ed Rowberry and BBRC. as "A model from Bristol that needs to be shared nationally."

We had the pleasure of hosting a visit from Thangam to our Creative Technology centre and one of the students commented afterwards that she wasn't what they expected from a politician as "she actually seemed to be interested in what they thought."

Maybe there is hope... Good Luck Thangham on Thursday and come back soon.

postContent:
Ahead of Dying Matters Week, Iâ€™m delighted to announce that St Peter's Hospice, Bristol is launching a new strategy which has been developed in collaboration with employees, volunteers, supporters and the public. Our aim? To double the number of people we support within the next five years.

Currently, we know weâ€™re only supporting about a third of those needing end of life care, but we want to do more. As our community grows and diversifies, we must adapt to meet the increasing demand and needs of our patients. Recent years have certainly been challenging, but weâ€™re now focused on an ambitious plan to help us reach and support more people, for longer. Driven by research and stakeholder feedback, our strategy has three areas of focus: 

- Putting communities at the heart of our work, 
- Normalising conversations about death and dying, 
- Leading, learning and innovating.

We've also given our brand a refresh, something we havenâ€™t done in over a decade. Research showed us there were many barriers to people accessing our support or donating to us, but our modernised look helps breaks down misconceptions about St Peterâ€™s, which will help us connect with more of our local communities and increase donations.

Ultimately, our strategy is crucial for helping us achieve our vision of transforming the experience of death through understanding, compassion and care.Â Death is an inevitable part of life, affecting everyone, but with the right support, we can make it more dignified, comfortable, and aligned with peopleâ€™s wishes.
author: Susan Hamilton

postContent:
Last week I spoke to the BBC about the Â£25 million of government funding hospices have been given for this financial year. We are really grateful for this funding. This is capital funding and St Peter's Hospice, Bristol use it to pay for essential maintenance of our hospice buildings and IT systems. 

The remaining Â£75 million will be given out in the next financial year and we look forward to receiving our allocation to support our capital investment program. 

Longer term the hospice sector needs a sustainable funding solution. Many hospices have already cut services and financial pressures will continue to mount, particularly with the additional tax following changes in national insurance. 

We welcome the ongoing discussions the sector is having with government on a sustainable funding solution. Hospices are delivering on government priorities for avoiding hospital admissions and improving community care. It is vital that this continues and is adequately funded.

postContent:
Today we say goodbye to our CEO, Sean Sargent. Sean has led the business from an early-stage start-up, just 4 years ago, to becoming a key player in the UKâ€™s efforts to develop its own lithium and battery metals supply chain. There have been many challenges along the way, and under Seanâ€™s leadership the company has always been able to respond with agility â€“ one of our companyâ€™s core values.

As we worked through the latest iteration of our strategy to develop large-scale lithium refining capability, it became clear that we needed to adjust the team to focus on our near-term objectives, resulting in changes across the organisation. Weâ€™re confident that these changes will result in Green Lithium being further able to deliver shareholder value and play its role in the emerging UK and broader European battery market.

Sean said, â€œIt is with mixed emotions that Iâ€™m leaving not only Green Lithium but also leaving many people I consider to be great friends. I would also like to extend my sincere thanks to all our delivery partners, who contributed so much to our achievements. As I leave Green Lithium for my next challenge I wish the company every success for the futureâ€.

We wish Sean every success in his next endeavour.

postContent:
On Monday 9 December, we commenced detailed ground investigations and characterisation activities covering the location of our Scale-Up Plant at Kinkerdale Road, Middlesbrough. The undertaking was planned with our environmental management partner Sol Environment Ltd, geo-environmental specialists Brownfield Solutions, landowner PD Ports, and specialist local contractors RD Drilling and HERRING PLANT HIRE LIMITED. The work involved borehole drilling, trial pit excavation, and the collection of groundwater, soil and rock samples.

This work is vital for establishing environmental baseline data for our chosen site and will inform any required land remediation strategies, enable detailed foundation design, and support additional submissions to Redcar & Cleveland Borough Council necessary to discharge two further planning consent conditions.

Charlie Tasker, Programme Director of Green Lithium, said: â€œThe commencement of this activity is a significant landmark in our overall project development programme. It is the result of months of preparation and has involved significant collaboration between our own design team, PD Ports, Sol Environment and Brownfield Solutions to allow rapid mobilisation following the receipt of necessary permissions.â€

â€œWe had identified the scheme as a major project milestone; completing the on-site work before the New Year has been an energising achievement for our team.â€
author: Green Lithium

postContent: Thank you Teesside University. It's a great space to collaborate and grow our business.
author: Sean Sargent

postContent:
In July 2023, we secured outline UK Planning Permission approval from Redcar & Cleveland Borough Council for our large-scale lithium refinery â€“ this is the principal consent required to construct a facility in the UK. It was later extended to include our smaller industrial-scale facility on the same PD Ports site on Teesport. The outline approval included various specific conditions, which we are now systematically closing out to reach the construction phase. 
 
Following successful completion of our environmental impact assessment (EIA) during the initial 2023 application, we were set the condition of producing a biodiversity masterplan, focused on the wider ecological considerations of our development in Teesside, UK. Our plan, co-developed with Sol Environment Ltd, includes initiatives towards creating a net positive environmental impact, such as natural water purification through re-bedding techniques and habitat creation in collaboration with a local farm.Â This biodiversity masterplan was the only condition with a set timeframe and it has now been approved by the council. We are continuing to close out the remaining conditions ahead of construction. 
 
Charlie Tasker, Programme Director of Green Lithium, commented:Â â€œWe are thrilled to receive this recent confirmation, which brings us one step closer to construction and to realising our vision of a cleaner, more sustainable lithium supply chain. The large-scale refinery will create over 1,000 jobs during the construction phase and provide 250 full-time, highly-skilled positions for local workers once operational.â€ 
 
â€œGreen Lithium is deeply committed to leading in ESG standards, and this includes significantly reducing the carbon footprint of lithium refining. We will deploy low-energy processes, use renewable electricity and process hydrogen gas once available to achieve a much lower carbon footprint than conventional refineries, setting new benchmarks for sustainability in the industry.â€
author: Green Lithium

After 14 successful years as Managing Director of Horstman UK and CEO of the Horstman Group, Ian Pain FIMechE will be stepping down at the end of November to take on the new challenge of CEO at RENK America. We extend our thanks to Ian for his unwavering commitment and #leadership, which have been instrumental to Horstmanâ€™s growth and success. We wish him every success in this exciting new chapter of his career.
 
Effective December 1st, Gareth Elwell will assume the role of CEO of the Horstman Group, overseeing Horstman UK, Horstman USA, and Horstman Canada. Gareth has been a key member of the Horstman team for nearly a decade, holding roles such as Programme Manager, Head of Programmes, and, since 2019, Group Finance Director.
 
In addition, Mark Allemby BSc (Hons) MAPM will take over as Managing Director of Horstman UK. Since joining Horstman in 2010, Mark has made significant contributions in roles including Programme Manager, Programmes Director, and Deputy Managing Director.
 
We are proud to have promoted both Gareth and Mark from within the organisation.Â We wish them both continued success in their new roles as they lead Horstman into its next phase of #growth and #innovation.

postContent:
London Climate Action Week is underway, and as climate professionals come together to help solve the #climateemergency, it's important that we recognise the role of #nuclear in achieving this.

Last week, the Governmentâ€™s climate advisors announced that much more still needs to be done if the UK is to meet it's #netzero targets by 2050, which further highlights the need for a total decarbonisation of the energy sector.

We believe that in order to do this, we need to support the drive towards more nuclear power capacity and projects such as Sizewell C, which will not only help us reach these targets but also help create a highly skilled workforce which is key to build back greener, faster and better from the pandemic.

Read in our blog, here: https://lnkd.in/eqew_7e

#LCAW2021 #buildbackbetter

postContent:
The UK has more than 3.5 million shift workers, and with this type of work often requiring long hours working away from home, fatigue amongst workers is common and can result in accidents. 

To prevent injuries and keep productivity levels high, it's important to offer high-quality worker accommodation that provides the highest level of comfort and security, so that workers feel rested and well-prepared for their next shift. 

There are a number of ways to provide this but through integrating smart technology into the guest experience, the living environment can be enhanced which will ultimately have a better impact on worker performance and #wellbeing: https://lnkd.in/dmrEQb4
 
#construction #productivity
author: Mark Bass

postContent:
Really useful Well-being Roundtable event today at the Engine Shed Bristol hosted by Looking After Me and Oli Ballard. 

Lots of insight from the room - 4.5 day working weeks, monthly 15 minute Health Coach check-ins, Wellness Walks, Personal Growth Budgets, and training and supporting line-managers. The importance of pro-active mental health strategies has certainly got me thinking. 

Having the chance to discuss challenges we face at work in such a friendly environment was in itself good for my mental health.

postContent:
A key focus at Inside Travel Group | B Corpâ„¢ is how we can play our part in tackling Overtourism, specifically this year for our InsideJapan brand. 

As Japan has boomed as a destination - from 4.8 million overseas visitors when we started InsideJapan Tours 25 years ago to 36.8 million last year - Overtourism is an issue which has had increasing airtime. 

One pillar of our approach is dispersal of visitors - and doing that by promoting 'under-visited' destinations. We have picked five places in Japan that currently have fewer overseas visitors but have the capacity and desire to have more. 

Pleased to get this page up on our website today about our first of our 'under-visited' destinations, the Toyama area of Japan:

https://lnkd.in/ehxrsnRk

We will be sending some 15,000 plus people to Japan this year and we would love for as many of them as possible to see beyond the usual destinations.

I will share more about our other pillars in tackling Overtourism in a future post.
author: Simon King

postContent:
We have just wrapped up a fun, engaging, and impactful B Corp month here at Inside Travel Group | B Corpâ„¢ and this video says it all better than I ever could!

https://lnkd.in/ezFGCZvN

B Lab - the organisation behind B Corp - has got a fair amount of stick the last few months, but I think the newly announced standards are going to be a game-changer. 

The new standards will take some serious hard work for us to navigate, but having a minimum standard across purpose and governance, fair work, JEDI, human rights, climate action, environmental stewardship, and collective action, rather than a points-based system where you could excel in one area but fail in another, will raise the bar.
author: Simon King

postContent:
This week, the wider travel sector descended on Inside Travel HQ in Bristol. 
First, we were delighted to host Travel by B Corp members - an industry collective born out of a vision to change the travel industry for good. 

It came at a good time, the tail-end of #BCorpMonth,Â amid a growing recognition that to realise the trueÂ impact of B Corp, we need sectors to come together to share learnings, pool resources, and maximise collective voice.

Highlights included insights on nudging responsible traveller behaviour from Milena Nikolova at BehaviorSMART, the lowdown on evolving B Corp standards from Andy Hawkins, Rachel Parsons & Camilla Barnes, and then a visionary travel workshopÂ from Will Gardner. 

A huge thank you to Thomas Power for organising the sessions, and Exodus, Byway, Felloh | B Corpâ„¢, The Thinking Traveller, Sykes Holiday Cottages, TTG Media, Sanderson Phillips | Certified B Corpâ„¢, Swoop Adventures, Warwick Events | Certified B Corporation, Selective Asia | B Corpâ„¢, HF Holidays, Steppes Travel, Lovat Parks Limited, Sawday's, LEMONGRASS MARKETING LIMITED, Senderos Vitales, ABTOT Limited, Pura Aventura | Travel PositiveÂ®, and Wild Dog Design for participating on the day. 

We then opened up beyond B Corp - welcoming travel businesses and journalists from across the South West in an evening orchestrated by James Mundy. The evening networking includedÂ insight on Undertourism from our Sustainability Executive, Dom Hughes. 

#TravelbyBCorp #BLabUK #Overtourism #Undertourism

Emergency refrigeration hire: That heart-sinking feeling when the engineer breaks the news about your business's broken freezer. Panic ensues, and you start contemplating the fate of your stock. Will you be able to save it? What will the boss say? Should you start devouring it all now?
Fear not! There's a solution that'll save your baconâ€”hiring a refrigerated freezer/trailer.

Imagine not having to wait for days while your stock perishes and you're unable to restock. With a hired refrigerated freezer/trailer, you'll have a speedy solution at your doorstep in no time. Say goodbye to time-sensitive spoilage!

Trail-blazing Mobility: Keeping it Cool, No Matter the Terrain
When it comes to accessibility, these trailers are real game-changers. Delivered by a 4x4 vehicle, they can navigate fields, small tracks, and even big budget movie setsâ€”places bigger units wouldn't dare venture. Whether your breakdown occurs in the wild or on a set, these trailers have you covered!

Cool Convenience: Plug, Chill, and Breathe Easy
Don't sweat the technicalities! These trailers can be plugged into any regular electrical socket. No need for fancy power suppliesâ€”just plug in and experience instant chilling relief. It's as easy as icing a cake!

Ready to Stay Cool? Team Refrigeration is Here to Help!
Don't let a refrigerated/freezer breakdown leave you in a panic. Take charge of the situation by ordering a trailer from Team Refrigeration. With their quick and hassle-free service, you can sit back, relax, and just chill out while your stock remains safe and sound.

postContent:
In 2015 we had an idea - let's work together as festivals on sustainable travel, because it's our #1 source of emissions, and it's challenging. This week we celebrate collectively raising almost Â£750k for environmental restoration - how amazing is that! So, massive thanks to the many people who have helped make this happen, and if you have a good idea in life, go for it as you might be surprised what happens! We're aiming for Â£1m by 2026!

At onboard:earth we are celebrating our brilliant community of events, companies and audiences raising over Â£100,000 for environmental restoration in 2024. This means we have now gathered over Â£740,000 for environmental restoration projects since the charity was founded by SHAMBALA FESTIVAL LIMITED, Boomtown Festival and @Kendal Calling Festival since 2015! 

This year donations have gone to four awesome projects: 
 
ğŸ’š Reforestation in Nicaragua, a PlanVivo verified carbon offset project, which works with smallholder farmers to restore forests in partnership with local communities. 

ğŸ’š Tree-planting, forestry protection and the creation of sustainable livelihoods through reforestation schemes in Northern Malawi with Temwa 

ğŸ’š Storing and sequestering vast quantities of carbon by protecting threatened rainforests. Safeguarding biodiversity by preserving vital wildlife corridors and funding training for local communities to combat forest fires and unlawful deforestation Rainforest Trust UK

ğŸ’š Here in the UK donations will fund a Community Energy Cooperative in Wiltshire for the construction of a rooftop solar array for a local school for students with special educational needs and disabilities, generating low-cost green electricity for the school, funding workshops on keeping warm in winter and using surplus power to fund local wildlife restoration projects. Wiltshire Wildlife Community Energy 

Now we set sights on helping our community raise Â£1 million for environmental restoration by 2026 and launch new tools to support our members and the industry to measure and reduce travel impacts as a first step >> https://lnkd.in/eRZfFhD4

Greg Cochrane Christopher Barrett Caroline Clift âœ’

postContent:
In my 15yrs+ of climate advocacy and activism in live events, this is a proud moment â€“ we have successfully tested a way to stimulate real change in the sector; equitably, affordably, quickly and at scale. Read the report of key findings from the 12-month pilotÂ with 60 events - https://lnkd.in/ejRhdfhD

Vision for Sustainable Events, Julie's Bicycle & Andrew Lansley worked with 10 local authorities, 60 events (with audiences of 2.3m) on a ground-breaking national pilot to establish minimum environmental standards and assessment for outdoor events.

The Green Events Code of Practice (GECOP) national pilot achieved a 60% increase in sustainability measures across the 60 music, sports and community events, proving that local authority-led assessments can drive widespread adoption of sustainability practices.

The project was funded by Arts Council England, EarthPercent and participating local authorities. The project was also supported by Festivalrepublic, SHAMBALA FESTIVAL LIMITED, LAEOG UK, LIVE (Live music Industry Venues and Entertainment) and the 60 participating events. This is sector collaboration in action - everyone working together to create a framework for change. And it's working!

Rob van Wegen Green Events Holger Jan Schmidt YOUROPE Carlijn Lindemulder Lyke Poortvliet Megan Best Meegan Jones John Rostron Craig Mathie Graham MacVoy ğŸ‘©ğŸ»â€ğŸ’»Hannah Cox Native Events  Ross Patel Cathy Runciman Steve Heap Lab Vlieland Marie Sabot Carly McLachlan Greg Cochrane Christopher Barrett Caroline Clift âœ’ Victoria Chapman Zac Fox Anna Johnson PIEMA REnvP Lukas Howell MSI CEnv FIEMA FRSA Bryonie Mathews Association of Independent Festivals Anna Abdelnoor

postContent:
Some Sunday reading.
My name is Sunday. Iâ€™m a dynamic policy expert with a proven track record in evidence-based advocacy, research & policy engagement, & forging impactful partnerships. With an inquiring mind & the ability to foresee policy, political, & reputational challenges, I excel in driving innovative solutions that lead to sector-wide changes in understanding, attitudes, & practice. 

My presence & published record ensure I am a lightning rod for diverse thoughts from across political divides, with a reputation for rigorous analysis & free thinking. Iâ€™m also empathetic, loyal, & quite funny. 

Why am I telling you this? Because exactly 3 years to the day I was welcomed into Wonkhe (my first in-person day doubled as an Xmas party!), Iâ€™m saying goodbye. 

Being with a company close to a third of its existence has been quite the journey. What was proposed as a 12-month contract to look at the concept of Belonging turned into a greater adventure - even greater than my already very adventurous previous roles working in strategic delivery on post-covid student engagement & before serving as President of my SU during the height of a pandemic.

From briefing VCs on new regulatory implications to advising cross-party boards on education reform, itâ€™s been a whirlwind. Iâ€™m proud to have consistently delivered actionable insights against a backdrop of political turmoil and rapid change (4 prime ministers, 2 governments, & 6 education secretaries!). Iâ€™ve established a national sphere of influence across education, medicine, gender-based violence, wellbeing, neurodiversity, accessibility, &Â  housing - bridging academia & policy to advance stability & integrity in these sectors.

Iâ€™m deeply passionate about the role HE plays in shaping society, driving innovation, promoting equality, & expanding opportunity. 

Iâ€™m particularly interested in roles that align with my skills in:
- Research, impact, & stakeholder engagement
- Communication and policy analysis
- Policy development and leadership

Where I can:
- Get the right people in the right places to solve the right problems.
- Contribute to policy debate and shape the policy landscape.
- Detect and interpret underlying factors driving patterns in data.
- Identify strategic opportunitiesâ€”like parliamentary agendasâ€”for academics, researchers, and practitioners to influence decisions and tackle real-world challenges.

What I bring:
- A unique ability to unify diverse perspectives and agendas around shared objectives.
- Strong public speaking, written, and oral communication skills, tailored to diverse audiences.
- A drive to solve global challenges like environmental sustainability, social equity, and technological innovation.
- A deep understanding of UK politics, the policy landscape, and public opinion.
- The gift of thriving in chaos.

If you or someone in your network could benefit from my skillset, please feel free to reach out. For more background on my achievements, please read the article linked.

author: Jonathan Harper

postContent:
Paraorchestra won Best Ensemble last night at the 2025 Royal Philharmonic Society awards and I couldn't be happier!

This kind of recognition means so much. We won't wallow in it forever, but I take it as an important milestone in the journey of Paraorchestra, one where the classical sector (finally) understands our value in pushing the genre forward. 

From a tiny start-up in 2015 with a small Arts Council England grant to get us going, the momentum we have created continues to amaze me. On paper it's easy to understand but somewhat harder to deliver: we've taken artistic risks that ignore the conventions of classical music; we've put thought and care into shaping ideas that new audiences want; and we've embedded a new and equitable model of practice that creates an ecology for disabled musicians and artists to thrive. 

Thank you to saxophonist and award presenter Jess Gillam, who introduced our win with these words: 

â€œParaorchestra should be the Pride of Britain. They are inspirational in their care and creativity putting disabled musicians centre-stage. Those musicians are pioneering how orchestras and audiences interact. They are invigorating concert halls with thrilling experiences. Hereâ€™s to Paraorchestra, showing us all a way forwardâ€

And a big thank you to everyone who has messaged since, and to all friends and colleagues that celebrated with our squad of musicians, team members and trustees at the awards last night. I think it is unlikely I will let go of the trophy anytime soon....
author: Jonathan Harper

postContent:
Are we at the tipping point of a new reuse economy?

For the last 8 years, we've been monitoring readiness and motivations of UK public towards adopting reuse, refill and return behaviours. Our latest 2025 study is now available â€” whatâ€™s clear is that demand for change is growing louder and more urgent. Hereâ€™s what we found:

ğŸŒ 8 in 10 of UK public are already taking action to reduce single-use plastics in their weekly shop.
ğŸ’·72% want to see more reusable, refillable and returnable options where they shop.
ğŸ›ï¸ Shopping patterns are shifting towards reuse at least 1 in 4 respondents say they are regularly purchasing in reusable, refillable or returnable packaging.

Barriers still remain, with half say reuse options simply arenâ€™t available (for the products or brands the purchase), and over half feel confused by the sustainability language used by businesses.

But research shows clear pathways and opportunities for the reuse economy. Where do we begin? Which product categories for reuse are more appealing as a first step? What are the communication initiatives to focus on? Which commercial benefits would help people form new habits for reusables?

Read the full report here: https://lnkd.in/eEsewVMC and get in touch with us if you have any questions!

Curious for more? Get in touch with our team. Let's work together to improve access to reuse, and build a packaging system that works for people and planet.

Source: Survey was carried out in April 2025, with 2,004 UK adults by market research Obsurvant.

#ReuseRevolution #CircularEconomy #PlasticPollution #CityToSea #AnnualPolling #ConsumerInsights #RefillNotLandfill
author: City to Sea

postContent:
A major milestone has just landed in the campaign to rid our streets and seas of plastic pollution â€” MPs have officially called on the UK Government to BAN plastic chewing gum. ğŸ™Œ 

This exciting move follows a people-powered push led by our friends at Nuud, supported by us here at City to Sea alongside Kids Against Plastic, Common Seas, Plastic Health Council, A Plastic Planet, Everyday Plastic, Plastic Free July, Plastic Soup Foundation and Just One Ocean. Together, we helped launch a 38 Degrees petition that brought thousands of voices together to demand action â€” and Westminster is finally listening.

The motion, led by Kevin Stewart and backed by a powerful group of cross-party MPs and MSPs, urges the UK Government to act now on growing public health concerns around microplastics in gum. The science is shockingâ€”groundbreaking research from Dr. Cuong Cao and @Udit Pant at Queen's University Belfast has shown that justÂ one pieceÂ of plastic gum can release more thanÂ 250,000 microplastic particlesÂ into the human body. 

Weâ€™ve banned plastic straws. Weâ€™ve banned plastic vapes. But somehow, plastic gum is still being chewed and chucked, sticking around in our environment and even ending up inside us. Itâ€™s time to change that. Itâ€™s time to #BanPlasticGum. 

Weâ€™re so proud to have played a part in this moment through our partnership with Nuud, and weâ€™ll keep pushing until plastic gum is off the shelves for good. ğŸ’ª

Read the full parliamentary motion: https://lnkd.in/dvQahsrF
author: City to Sea

postContent:
So many fascinating insights and calls to action came out of yesterday's Bristol Women in Business Charter event at City Hall from a wealth of successful and inspiring speakers and leaders. 

Ruth B. argued that gender equality is good for growth as higher wages and financial security increases demand for goods  and services.  She cited that Â£1.5 billion is lost annually because women are not economically active enough, and shared evidence of wage deflation as women enter workforce sectors ğŸ¤‘ 

ğŸ’°Sarah Coles's talk made me want to sort my finances out and make sure everyone has signed up to the City to Sea pension scheme. She shared that women's money does not work as hard for them as mens', with wage, pension and investment gaps leaving women insecure in later life.  We have at least moved past the 'Dave' gap - there are now more female fund managers than fund managers called Dave...just!  ğŸ™Œ 

And so to the panel - a wealth of expertise and knowledge across public and private sectors. Sarah Crew Chief Constable of Avon & Sommerset Police values unlikely partnerships and listening hard to uncomfortable truths, Emma Louise Wood (nee Zeeman) said that organisations need to change not people and thanks to Rebecca Baldwin-Cantello BEM for reminding us that 'this S*%$ effects everyone', improving equity for one group delivers benefits for others! ğŸ† 

Finally five sets of five minutes that really mattered! Thanks to Tara Miran, Kyrby Brown, Bianca Jones, Matt Humberstone and Lewis Wedlock for sharing lived experience, personal challenges, triumphs, and the urgent actions businesses must take to create truly inclusive workplaces. â° 

Thanks to Sandra Gordon, Kristal McNamara, Sonia Cohen, Sarah Rice and Lucy Kirmond for putting on such an inspiring intersectional event. Where do we sign? 
â€‹

postContent:
NEW | China's coal-fired power generation fell for a third consecutive month in July 2024

Our latest monthly Ember electricity data shows that additions in wind and solar as well as gains in hydropower have led to the largest declines in coal generation in two years and the first sustained declines since the Covid-19 pandemic.

â˜€ Wind and solar power have seen consistent additions over the past three years. Year-on-year, wind and solar have now increased for 29 consecutive months! This has brought China closer to reducing its reliance on fossil fuels in the power sector.

ğŸŒŠ  In July 2024, hydropower rose to a new record high for a single month of 168 TWh â€“ 13% higher than the previous record of 149 TWh set in May 2022. Droughts had led to low output in 2023, masking underlying additions in hydro capacity. 2024 has so far shown improved conditions with the added capacity over the last few years manifesting in new records.

As China moves into a new phase of absolute coal power decline, there is a need for a 'beyond-diversification' strategy. My colleague Muyi Yang wrote about this in a recent report https://lnkd.in/dzyjBCae


Check out our latest electricity data, including the latest data on China in our data explorer: https://lnkd.in/gTrDpsMn

postContent:
Steve Jobs once took 18 seconds to think before answering a question.

In a world obsessed with instant reactions, that pause felt like an eternity. But it taught us a powerful lesson about leadership.

In the rush of daily decision-making, we often think quick answers show confidence. But sometimes, the most impactful leaders are those who take a moment to think.

Hereâ€™s what Iâ€™ve learned about the power of strategic silence:

Respect: Pausing before responding shows respect for the question and the questioner. Itâ€™s about thoughtful communication.

Clarity: A brief moment of reflection allows you to align your response with your vision, not just react. Itâ€™s not about speedâ€”itâ€™s about accuracy and purpose.

Cultural Impact: In a remote team, every word matters. Strategic pauses in communication set the tone for your culture.

At Athyna, weâ€™ve seen the impact of thoughtful pauses in our meetings, decisions, and team interactions. They give us the space to be clear, intentional, and aligned.

Next time you're in a high-stakes meeting or facing a tough question, take five seconds to think. Youâ€™ll be surprised at how much better your response can be.

Leadership isnâ€™t about filling silence. Itâ€™s about making every word count.

Whatâ€™s the best moment of strategic silence youâ€™ve had as a leader?
author: Bill Kerr

postContent:
I Wish Iâ€™d Thought of This:

Fish in the canals of Utrecht, Netherlands had a major problem. They were getting stuck behind a gate, and then they were getting eaten.

Then, the internet stepped in.

Every early spring, fish like bream, pike, and bass migrate upstream to spawn in shallower waters.

But the Weerdsluis lockâ€”normally opened for boat trafficâ€”stays mostly shut during this season. With few ships moving through, the lock doesnâ€™t open often. So the fish pile up, waiting. And predators know exactly where to find them.

The solution? A doorbell. For fish.

City ecologists and developers created the â€œFish Doorbellâ€ (Visdeurbel): an underwater livestream aimed at the lock gate, open to anyone online. 

When a viewer spots a fish, they press a digital button. That signal goes to lock operators, who then open the gate and let the fish continue their journey.

Itâ€™s crowdsourced conservationâ€”powered by curiosity, empathy, and Wi-Fi.

Since launching, the Fish Doorbell has gone viral. Millions of people from around the world have played digital crossing guard, helping restore a natural migration path that human infrastructure blocked.

No committees. No consultants. Just a clever fix and a shared instinct to help.

Feel free to help the fish yourself at visdeurbelÂ (dot) nl.

Potentially of interest to:

The Nature Conservancy Conservation International WWF Greenpeace International Emily Darling Sacha Dench Lara Jackson

postContent:
Two and a bit weeks ago I was punched by a stranger on the tube ğŸ˜°
 

Afterwards I was left standing alone for 30 MINUTES after hitting the
EMERGENCY button FOUR TIMES at a Help Point at one of London's busiest hubs - Oxford Circus.

No one answered the intercom. No one attended in person.

And this one still cuts deep...No commuters checked on me - even as I sobbed. 

Shock turned to angry disbelief: how could such a DIRE failure of our emergency protocols happen in our capital?

I raised the 'alarm' with an open letter to Sadiq Khan, demanding a test of all Help Points and a safety message directing commuters to the ticket hall if the intercom isnâ€™t answered.

I asked you to make as much noise as possible and WOW did you show up. 2.1 MILLION IMPRESSIONS ğŸ¤¯ 

Over TWO THOUSAND SHARES. And hundreds of you writing to offer
words of comfort, share your own experiences and to say you would have stepped in.

Within hours, my inbox filled with journalists -the Telegraph, Evening Standard, The Times, ITV, Jeremy Vine, and more. 

Reliving the attack for interviews has been traumatic, but I knew it was crucial to raise such a shocking failing of our emergency systems.

Last week, I sat down with TFL's Director of Security and Policing, a Superintendent from British Transport Police and the Deputy Mayor of Transport for London...

And walked away with COMMITMENTS - action in weeks or months, not years ğŸ’ª 

Hereâ€™s what was achieved: 

Emergency Guidance Stickers
TfL will explore placing stickers on Help Points listing '999' and the BTP number, and advising passengers to proceed to the ticket hall if help isnâ€™t immediate. 

I was funnelled to an intercom that failed, visible guidance on what to do in that situation could save lives and stop hesitation.

Bystander Campaign Review:
TfL will review their campaign to stress how crucial it is for bystanders to step in. 

A simple â€œare you ok?â€ can be LIFE CHANGING for a victim and their recovery. I've offered expertise to make current campaigns more impactful.

Technical System Review:
TfL has agreed to stress-test systems to ensure they work with multiple emergencies happening at once. 

AND clarify audio recording protocols - vital for capturing evidence for the BTP since CCTV doesnâ€™t capture sound.

Balancing this campaign with the launch of my careers platform has been TOUGH. Up at 6am each day...the high cortisol of live TV and other media meant struggling to sleep before 1am. 

But I couldn't just stand by and do nothing...

I share this update with immense pride in advocating for us Londoners â¤ï¸ To all victims, you are incredibly brave. Your voice MATTERS.

Of course, this is just the BEGINNING. And I'm here for however long it takes to see this through. 

My heart overflows with gratitude for all that gave a DAMN, and I urge you once again to repost and share OUR remarkable achievement (I couldn't have done it without you) - so the world knows that real action is underway âœŠ 

#tfl #safety
author: Sally Wynter ğŸ‘¹

postContent:
What a brilliant surprise today â€” Natalie Carpenter wrote this moving piece about all the incredible things sheâ€™s done since coming on my course. Thank you, Natalie â€” it means the world.
Itâ€™s not the first time Iâ€™ve heard someone say theyâ€™d rather quit their job than go on a presentation course. Public speaking stirs up big feelings â€” fear, shame, the huge pressure of perfectionism. Impostor syndrome affects nearly 70% of us, but it feels so personal when it hits.
Thatâ€™s one of the reasons I stopped running in-house courses. Open groups give people space to show up as themselves, away from workplace dynamics, and safely explore whatâ€™s really getting in the way. 
And itâ€™s such a joy to see what happens when people do. Iâ€™m really proud of Natalie â€” and her confidence practice thatâ€™s helped her get out of her own way.

postContent:
In a future under threat of climate change, thereâ€™s hope for rewilding the planet... but first, where do you store all your gear?

The Immersive Adventure Agency, based in South Hams runs "The Bioasis," a programme offering young people environmental education through immersive, adventure-based experiences. They teach skills like team building, problem solving, and survival, all while exploring how to "rewild" the planet.

As theyâ€™ve grown, the agency needed more storage for their expanding gearâ€”large tents, catering equipment, and survival tools. Their solution? A 40ft green, high-cube storage container, offering extra height for their large military-grade tents. Delivered to their top-secret, exposed location this week, the container provides the security, durability, and weather resistance they needed.

Prepping for your next adventure? Let us handle the storage!

postContent:
More and more police forces and justice organisations are prioritising workforce planning, but WHY?

Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â There has been a drastic shift in terms of workforce experiences and skillsets over recent years. The numbers of Officers/Staff that are new in service is ever increasing and developing the right career pathway and internal movement processes (the cycling of CID/ARG/Proactive team recruitment from frontline) is more important than ever. 

Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â Crime and interventions can now be costed, in both hard Â£, but also community impact. It isnâ€™t just about aligning Officers/Staff to crime volumes anymore, investing and deploying specific interventions can reduce operating costs and demand, which not only protects victims, but saves Â£. 

Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â New skills are needed, including digital, AI, investigation, but also crucially around business management. Command areas have to create target operating models that closer reflect business models in order to be efficient. 

SO WHAT help is out there and how can Forces start?

Forces can adopt an evidenced based, tool box approach to workforce planning and should start by:

1.Â Â Â Â Â Creating and deploying a strategy that connects future planning with operational activities. Use this strategy to structure a Gold, Silver, Bronze approach to implement and evaluate.

2.Â Â Â Â Â Using models and toolkits (such as succession and movement models, vacancy calculators, cost analysis, role profile aggregators) to target critical areas of the workforce and processes. Good models and toolkits will save Â£!

3.Â Â Â Â Â Evaluating commissions and embedding evaluators from the start will provide an evidence base as to what plans, changes are working.

When your workforce makes up 80-90% of your assets, you cannot afford to not plan! There are tools and services available now that can save Â£m in operating costs and deliver a better service.

If you are looking for support, please contact us at Skills for Justice

#workforce #policing #justice #planning #savings
author: Matthew Girdlestone

postContent:

postContent:
Output quality and yield requirements for flat glass tempering are increasing while availability of experienced operators is decreasing even faster. It is increasing challenges for glass processors globally.
For this reason, Glaston is strongly focusing on developing process- and factory automation aiding our customers to achieve their production goals of predictable production and stabile quality even without any experienced operators to control the process.

Tryba Industrie in France was the 1st one to get our upgrade of Autopilot technology and service agreement for their FC Series furnace in August 2023.

Feedback from Tryba after 6months of operation shows, that Autopilot has proven to fulfill the demanding goals.
â€œ
My general thoughts are quite simpleÂ :
Due to increased energy price, we are working night shift only with completely new operators (nothing to do with glass before coming to work for me in October).
They have been operating the furnace alone every night from November with minimal training.
With Autopilot they donâ€™t need to care about the process settings.
No problem with quality or productivity.
 
I couldnâ€™t be happier with the results.
 
Cordialement,
OBERLÃ‰ JÃ©rÃ´me
Responsable dÃ©partement vitrerie 
Tryba Industrie SAS
â€œ
Please contact Glaston sales to learn more about the Glaston Autopilot and how it could help you to achieve improvements in your flat glass tempering!
Autopilot is available for most of Glaston FC and RC series furnaces as an option or upgraded to existing ones.

postContent:
Making Waves: Water Babies Swims into a New Era with American Investment

As the world's largest baby and toddler swimming school, we are very excited to announce we've been acquired by Elmsley Capital and Westerly Group as we look toward building on our success in the UK and existing international markets. 

After 22 swimcredible years, our founder Paul Thompson is hanging up his trunks and passing the goggles to new owners but he will remain a part of the Water Babies family as a Non-Executive Board Director.

â€œThere are many mixed emotions when selling the business you founded 22 years ago, but the overriding feeling is one of great excitement for the next chapter of Water Babies. It has a fabulous team, from top to bottom and a very special culture and it is now time for the next generation to shine with the excellent support of Ross and Brian; we could not have found better custodians.â€ - Paul Thompson

Since our inception, Water Babies has grown into the worldâ€™s largest baby swim school, today teaching more than 80,000 babies every year through a network of family run franchise businesses across the UK, Ireland, Canada, The Netherlands, China and the USA. Winning numerous consumer awards and establishing partnerships with bodies such as Swim England and the Royal Lifesaving Society, we've worked hard to become widely regarded as the leading authority on baby swimming in the UK. Our new owners recognise the amazing work put in by all of our staff and franchisees and we'll continue with our well-loved business as usual in the UK and Internationally.

As a business we're so proud of the work we've put in and the progress we've made, and we can't wait to keep getting better and better. You can read our full press release through the link below â¬‡ï¸ 

https://lnkd.in/eaR-RnDP

Now let's keep doing what we do best - teaching a skill for life and inspiring a lifelong love of the water ğŸ’™ğŸ§¡

#WaterBabies #Franchisor #FranchiseBusiness #BabySwimming #ToddlerSwimming
author: Water Babies Global

postContent:
ğŸ’™ Water Babies Conference 2024 ğŸ§¡
 
What an incredible couple of days at our home, Winslade Park, celebrating an amazing year and reflecting on our successes and achievements as a global franchise business. Being able to welcome our franchisees from around the world together is the highlight of our year, and what a conference it's been!
 
We reflected on the incredible work from the last 12 months, as well as looking forward to new, collaborative, and exciting projects to keep pushing Water Babies forward as the world leader in baby and toddler swimming.
 
We welcomed the brilliant Peter Cross as our keynote speaker, who sparked meaningful discussions about the power of customer service, and how we can be the gold standard within our industry and beyond.
 
We were also delighted to be joined by our friends at Tommy's, who shared the incredible impact our Splashathon fundraising has on their mission to save babies lives. This was brought home even more as we had the honour of listening to two inspiring mums and Water Babies customers, Vikki and Amie, who bravely shared their real experiences of baby loss and the vital support they received. 
 
Our charity, the Children's Alliance, shared its powerful work to create better starts and brighter futures for children across the UK, having impacted 3,107 children's lives and supported 9 projects. This includes developing an inclusive swimming programme with Access Sport. Ben Humphrey from Access Sport explained how the programme enables disabled children to learn a skill for life in a safe and supportive environment.
 
It was an incredible couple of days, all finished off with a bit of Water Babies fun at our 'Top of the Pops' themed party! ğŸ•º
 
Thank to everyone who made this year's conference one of our best. See you next year! ğŸ¥‚

#WaterBabies #WaterBabiesConference2024 #FranchiseConference

postContent:
Dave and Babs are third generation farmers, farming responsibly alongside nature to maintain and improve this beautiful landscape. They both consider themselves custodians of the land for future generations. Historically small farms can find it hard to make living for the whole family and 30 years ago this was the case when Babs needed to diversify. From a farmers wife who set up a care organisation some 20 years ago to now leading the CHAOS Group - its been a long bumpy road!

Thankfully diversification has lead us to where we are today, incredibility grateful to share this wonderful space and have it as the home of CHAOS Farm.

We are going to be sharing much more of the farm with you over the coming weeks as it's fundamental to all we do and more excitingly....our future!

#NaturePositive #FarmingWithNature #

postContent:
ğŸ¤” How Reliable Are Stop Collar Holding Force Measurements?

At Centek, we test to real-world conditions to ensure accurate, dependable results. Our stop collars are tested on both soft and hard casing, and we consider a failure the moment slippage beginsâ€”not after the APIâ€™s allowed 4" distance.

Why does this matter? When testing on soft casing, set screws can dig in and drag, causing casing material to build up under the collar. This artificially increases holding force, leading to misleading resultsâ€”especially if you're using harder casing in the field.

If you're relying on test data, check how holding force is measured. Does your supplier report the true slip point, or do they use the API allowance?

For more details, contact sales@centekgroup.com.

#WellIntegrity #StopCollars #CasingEquipment #CentekPerformance 
#excellencetothecore #oilgas #centralizer
author: Centek Group

postContent:
The Hidden Risk of Stop Collar Failures

Stop collars may be small, but their impact on well integrity is anything but. When a stop collar fails, it can lead to centralizer movement, poor cementing, and even wellbore instabilityâ€”causing costly delays and potential safety risks.

Common Causes of Stop Collar Failure:

âŒ Insufficient Holding Force â€“ If the stop collar slips, centralizers can shift, leading to improper standoff.
âŒ Poor Installation â€“ Incorrect placement or inadequate torque can weaken the grip.
âŒ Low-Quality Materials â€“ Inferior stop collars may not withstand high downhole pressures and temperatures.
âŒ Inadequate Testing â€“ Without rigorous testing, failures can occur unexpectedly in challenging well conditions.

At Centek, we take stop collar performance seriously. Our solutions are tested to extreme conditions to ensure maximum holding force and reliabilityâ€”because when failure isnâ€™t an option, quality matters. https://zurl.co/HsocB 

#WellIntegrity #CementingSuccess #StopCollars #OilAndGas 
#excellencetothecore #oilgas #centralizer
author: Centek Group

postContent:
As operators push to maximize production from mature fields, re-entry wells are proving to be a cost-effective and efficient way to access untapped hydrocarbons. But these projects come with unique challengesâ€”from navigating casing windows to managing torque, drag, and cementing complexities.

Choosing the right centralization strategy is critical. Bow spring #centralizers, like the Centek S2, are designed for irregular wellbores, ensuring smooth casing deployment and optimal cement placement. A  re-entry project in Ecuador proved their effectivenessâ€”delivering cost savings of up to $250,000 and securing well integrity.

postContent:
Heart of Headland is a wonderful charity that operates to create care packages for patients undergoing chemo/immunotherapy at Treliske Hospital. Their ChemoHero packages have been thoughtfully put together by the nurses, with each item targeted at easing a specific side effect from these treatments.

From puzzle books to pass the time during therapy sessions and soothing skin balms, through to stress-calming roller balls and protein/chocolate bars for a little energy boost, each item in their ChemoHero boxes has been thoughtfully put together with the patients care very much at the forefront of their mind.

Some of our lovely Gems went along today to support their wonderful volunteers to help package up 120 boxes, 100 of which will have been given out within this next month. Quite a staggering thought. Their ChemoHero boxes bring so much joy to their patients with each box carefully packaged with tissue paper and labels, signed by the person that packed them, to help create that more personalised, caring feel. 

Cornish Gems donated access to their special healing sounds and breathing techniques via QR code.  This helps specifically to reduce stress cortisol levels by tapping into your nervous system. This can be used by all patients and their families by simply scanning the code and listening! 

This truly is, a wonderful and caring charity and we were honored to have been a part of it today. 

For anyone wishing to donate to help keep these boxes going, you can do so here:

https://lnkd.in/eU2SxpqU
author: Nadia Macer-Wright

postContent:
Cow & Sow Signature Grilled Steak Candle
Hand-poured. Flame-grilled. 100% ridiculous.
Buy it now for just Â£10 at: https://lnkd.in/e36tAxvS.

Introducing the candle you didnâ€™t know you needed (and definitely didnâ€™t ask for). Infused with the smoky scent of dry-aged perfection, this artisanal wax blend is our proudest (and most pointless) creation yet. Designed for the devoted carnivore, the steak-scented sensualist, and the aromatherapy renegade, itâ€™s a flickering tribute to flame-grilled fantasy.

Crafted using our proprietary â€œSmokehouse Essence No.1â€, each candle is lovingly hand-poured and imbued with the unmistakable aroma of a 42-day dry-aged ribeye mid-sizzle. It opens with top notes of cracked black pepper and seared crust, followed by a heart of juicy pink centre and buttery marbling. The base notes? Oak smoke, a whisper of rosemary, and just the faintest hint of charred cast iron. Close your eyes and youâ€™re back in the steakhouse â€” minus the chewing.

At Cow & Sow, we donâ€™t just serve steak â€” we celebrate it. So when someone in the office joked that â€œour ribeye smells better than my Jo Malone,â€ we knew we had to act. After three months, seventeen ruined slow cookers, and one HR complaint, the Grilled Steak Candle was born. A scent so rich, so evocative, so entirely unnecessary â€” we just had to bottle it (or jar it, technically).

Light it during dinner to enhance your appetite. Use it to relive your last date night at Cow & Sow. Or simply enjoy it while soaking in a hot bath with a glass of Malbec and a side of imaginary mashed potatoes. Warning: May cause spontaneous hunger, fridge raids, and impromptu BBQs in winter.

Perfect For:

postContent:
The 6 steps to avoid falling into "performance punishment" at work:

Being good at your job sometimes backfires.

You get more work, more responsibilities, but not necessarily more pay.

You get trapped in the 'performance punishment' trap.

Here's how it works:

â†³ You exceed expectations
â†³ Your boss gives you more work
â†³ You complete it on time
â†³ They think you can handle even more work
â†³ You complete it on time
â†³ Repeat (until you're burnt out)

The end result is you're overworked and underpaid.

Your work output slows down.

Your happiness at work decreases.

Your quality of life suffers.

So, how do you avoid 'performance punishment?'

1. Communicate your boundaries
2. Be upfront about your pay expectations
3. Negotiate workloads
4. Ask for support when necessary
5. Prioritize self-care
6. Know when to say "no"

While it can be tempting to say "yes" to every task, it's important to consider the impact it will have on your overall performance.

Saying "no" can actually improve your reputation and effectiveness.

Remember, it's not always about doing more.

It's about doing things the right way.

Focus on quality, effectiveness, and results.

Say "no" to unnecessary work.

Advocate for yourself.

And always prioritize self-care.

-------------------------------------------------

Credits to David Neal for the OG post!

-------------------------------------------------

Follow me Dan Murray-Serter ğŸ§  for more on habits and leadership.

postContent:
Melting of the worldâ€™s glaciers is â€œaccelerating alarminglyâ€.

A new study carried out by 35 teams was published in the Nature journal this week, we are globally losing the world's glaciers of 5% of their volume since 2000, the equivalent of about 273 gigatonnes (1bn tonnes) of ice per year â€” or enough water for the worldâ€™s population for 30 years.

The report highlights that glacial melt has increased sea levels by 18mm, when every centimetre of sea level rise exposes another 2mn people to annual flooding somewhere on our planet. 

Financial Times - Climate Capital
author: Murad Qureshi

postContent:
Really pleased to see that Department for Energy Security and Net Zero is consulting on extending the Warm Homes Discount to eligible households on communal electricity supplies/private wire.  This includes many heat network consumers, who have previously been denied this energy discount.

We at Heat Trust have been asking government to address this anomaly for almost three years, and suggested extending the existing scheme for park homes residents (run by Charis), so it's great to see this being proposed...

BUT...  there is to be no new money (from energy suppliers) for the scheme despite this significant extension of the number able to claim.  This seems unreasonable and suggests many eligible households will still miss out on the discount.

postContent:
Ashfield Land is reshaping its leadership team in a move that will see founder and 35-year Managing Director Andrew Fisher step into the Chairman role.Â Directors Steven McGarva and Ben Holmes will take on roles as â€˜Managing Director Northâ€™ and â€˜Managing Director Southâ€™ respectively.

Ashfield Land was co-founded by Andrew Fisher in partnership with Robin Faber in 1990 and Andrew has led the business as Managing Director over 35 successful years.

To enable the next chapter in the privately-owned firmâ€™s evolution, Steven McGarva and Ben Holmes will become new MDs, expanding their existing responsibilities within an overall leadership group which includes Operations Director, Claire Cope and Projects Director, Paul Jagroop. 

Andrew Fisher, Chairman of Ashfield Land, said: â€œWe set up Ashfield Land in 1990 to offer something different into the real estate market and Iâ€™ve been proud to lead the business for the last 35 years.Â Now itâ€™s time for a refresh and itâ€™s exciting to see Steven McGarva and Ben Holmes stepping forward as our new managing directors across the North and South respectively, working in our leadership group with Claire Cope and Paul Jagroop and sustaining the breadth and depth of experience that makes Ashfield Land unique.Â This is an evolution move and a continuity play for the business â€“ we know what we want to be, do, and offer our partners and collaborators in the market.Â Weâ€™re excited for the future with our re-shaped leadership team.â€

Steven McGarva, Managing Director North at Ashfield Land, said: â€œRefreshing our leadership team while continuing our ethos for dynamic, strategic decision-making is the right thing for the business to do.Â Andrew has done a fantastic job leading our business and Iâ€™m excited and looking forward to continuing to work with him, Ben and the wider leadership team in the new Managing Director North role.â€

Ben Holmes, Managing Director South at Ashfield Land, said: â€œI joined Ashfield Land because I could see both an exceptional track record and an exciting future for the business.Â Iâ€™m pleased to be part of this future and shaping it more directly as Managing Director South.Â Ashfield Land is all about delivery and Iâ€™m looking forward to continuing that track record and to more excellent results.â€

The changes are effective from today (1 May 2025).

Read the full News release at: https://lnkd.in/eeRzhmwA

postContent:
After a week of ticking off our to-do listsâ€”and like most others, squeezing in time for personal development, family, and friends (if time permitted)â€”we blink, and itâ€™s Friday again. Where does the time go, we wonder?

As much as we love the weekend, I say: do something fun and fulfilling so the days, weeks, and years donâ€™t start to just roll into one. Challenge yourself this weekend to spend an hour doing something outside your comfort zone. Live a little on the wild sideâ€”or at least a different side.

Can you do something that will teach you something new? Iâ€™m not quite sure where Iâ€™d start, but Iâ€™m thinking about what would pique my interest. It could be listening to a new podcast, visiting a new area, grabbing a coffee in a local cafÃ© and striking up a conversation with a local resident... who knows?

Which brings me to my question: how often do we truly experience something new? Something where we pause and say, â€œAh, Iâ€™ve never done that before,â€ or, â€œWow, I didnâ€™t know that.â€
Happy Friday!

postContent:
When youâ€™re trying to reach a new level in your life, productivity, and output, it requires a new mindset, set of habits, and energy to see the vision through to fruition. It starts with the belief that you can evolve for the better, followed by holding yourself accountable and meeting the objectives you set for yourself.
Every day is a new opportunity to try and try again. Eventually, your new habits will become a natural part of your routine.

On that note, I am committing to getting to the gym after work. I did well in January, then fell off in February. Someone feel free to check in with me tomorrow and ask if Iâ€™ve done itâ€¦ I have now put it out to the world! :D

SMALL STEPS LEAD TO BIG CHANGE!
author: Charmaine Lawrence

postContent:
When people think about being a manager or boss, the role often seems glamorous. But the reality is, it comes with significant responsibilities. You canâ€™t run a business without a team, and with a team comes people management. Balancing staff needs alongside the requirements of the organisation is a true juggling act.

Whether you are one year in or ten years in, the journey is about learning and building character. If we aspire to be among the high achievers making a huge impact and disrupting industries, we must first master management and leadership at a smaller level on the way up.

Every day, I am thankful because I am in my dream job. This is a reminder that you donâ€™t have to be perfect, but you must learn from mistakes and aim to get 1% better with each step. Always do your best!

How are you finding working in a senior role?

PS - This photo was taken on the train, on my way to Portsmouth to commemorate D-Day 80. It was a deeply moving experience, reflecting on the bravery of those who came before us.
author: Charmaine Lawrence

postContent:
I'm incredibly proud to now have these life-saving anaphylaxis Kitts in our leisure sites. 

We believe we are the first indoor leisure sites to have them. They sit alongside our defibrillators and first aid kits to ensure that we are able to respond as robustly as possible in the event of a first aid emergency.

It has been nearly two years since we first reached out to Kitt Medical's James Cohen and I have been constantly in awe of the work they are doing. 

They originally started in schools but have now expanded out into wider businesses. Our Teams calls changed backdrop as they moved from shared office space into their own offices along the way, but their passion and drive to make anaphylaxis Kitts as common as defibrillators did not change.

A really purpose-driven start-up that now has over 750 of them across the country, I'm exited to see the future growth of this company.

We're hopefully soon rolling them out into our nurseries too. Watch this space!

Our teams are incredibly grateful to have them on site too. The pictures show our multi-site GM Becca Newman proudly showing off her Kitt.

If you're interested in getting a Kitt at your business, here's the website: https://kittmedical.com/

Kitt Medical
