postContent:
Challenges come in all shapes and sizes, but the last 24 hours have been a standout period. 

Iâ€™m incredibly proud of our teams for the resilience and agility they have shown this weekend across our leisure sites. At each site weâ€™ve needed to fundamentally change our Christmas experience due to Storm Darragh. 

That has meant working late into the night to rapidly deconstruct our grottos outside and reconstructing them indoors as well as creating a brand new entrance for our Weston-super-Mare seafront site on their opening day for the Christmas experience. It has also meant a lot of work to keep guests updated as we cancelled the first session of the day across all of our sites whilst the red warning was still in place.

Throw in a few other challenges like the triple whammy of our booking system, internet and phone lines going down this morning and it has been a real day of challenges. Even just getting to work today has not been without its problems, but they all have. 

Our laser-tight focus on guest experience is what drives our teams. Giving families the best Christmas experiences has been at the forefront of their minds these past 24 hours.

It is our busiest month of the year as our Christmas experiences see some 15,000 people through come through the doors. Our customer reviews are some of the highest in the country for similar experiences. This is all down to the fantastic people I am lucky enough to call colleagues.

I reflected on all of this as I stood on Weston-super-Mare seafront at lunchtime directing families to our newly created entrance (hence the picture). 

I am proud to say to colleagues that I have done every single role in the organisation as weâ€™ve grown the business and I wasnâ€™t going to let the hastily created role of â€˜customer signposterâ€™ detract from that statement!

A big thank you to all our team who have definitely gone the extra mile this weekend!
author: Tom Filer

postContent:
**The Ethical Dilemma in Solar Energy: A Call for Transparency** 

The transition to renewable energy is a global priority, but recent investigations reveal a troubling ethical concern. According to The i Paper, solar panels installed at major UK sites â€” including Manchester City Football Club Womenâ€™s Stadium and David Lloyd Clubs â€” may have links to forced labour in China. 

A critical component of these panels, polysilicon, has been traced to production facilities in Xinjiang, China, where the Uyghur minority has been subjected to forced labour. While there is no suggestion that organisations knowingly sourced these panels under such conditions, the findings raise important questions about supply chain transparency and ethical procurement. 

This issue underscores the need for businesses and institutions to conduct rigorous due diligence when adopting green technologies. As sustainability efforts accelerate, it is crucial to ensure that ethical considerations are embedded in procurement decisions. 

How can organisations balance their commitment to renewable energy with responsible sourcing? Contact the Unseen UK Business Services team for help and support at business@unseenuk.org 

#Sustainability #EthicalSupplyChains #RenewableEnergy #HumanRights #ForcedLabour

Matt Crossman, Chloe C., Laura Murphy, Helena Kennedy Centre for International Justice

postContent:
ğŸ“‰Â Reputational risk. Regulatory exposure. Human cost.

Starbucks is under fire following a lawsuit in Brazil allegingÂ slavery-like conditionsÂ on coffee farms linked to its supply chainâ€”farms that had already been flagged for labour violations.

Despite existing ethical sourcing protocols like Starbucks' C.A.F.E. Practices, serious questions remain:

ğŸ” Are voluntary standards enough?
âš ï¸ Where does accountability truly lie?
ğŸ“Š How robust is ESG reporting without third-party verification and enforcement? Why not use MillionMakersâ„¢?

This is not just about Starbucks. Itâ€™s a systemic issue that spans global supply chainsâ€”from coffee to cocoa, fashion to fisheries.

ğŸ“ŒÂ Business leaders take note:

Transparency must be real-time and data-driven.
Human rights due diligence must be proactive, not reactive.
Reputational risk is now intrinsically linked to supply chain ethics.

Ethical sourcing isnâ€™t a sustainability add-onâ€”itâ€™s a governance issue, a legal risk, and a boardroom responsibility.

Why not work with Unseen UK Business Services team to ensure you create genuine change. Contact them via business@unseenuk.org

postContent:
British workers are reported to be among the saddest, loneliest, and least engaged in Europe.

A sobering reminder for anyone leading a business in the UK: how our colleagues feel about their work is directly tied to our companyâ€™s success.

So, it is hard not to see a link between this and the wider challenges Britain faces with productivity and growth.

We must listen more, care more, and lead better. A workforce that feels good about its work is not a luxury. It is essential.

Who is with me?

Itâ€™s not every day you see sports, leisure and film production merging in a single community-focused project.

The planned Â£13 million development in Derby is an interesting example of how repurposing old spaces can revitalise local areas.

What's particularly impressive is the forward-thinking rehabilitation unit planned for the final phase, supporting both stunt professionals and elite athletes. 

This type of infrastructure development creates sustainable pathways for specialised technical careers while breathing new life into industrial heritage buildings.

Projects like this have real potential to create lasting economic and social benefits.

For Bedfordshire, itâ€™s a chance to position itself as a hub for world-class entertainment and innovation. For the wider economy, itâ€™s a timely reminder of what targeted investment can achieve when itâ€™s backed by collaboration, ambition and long-term thinking.

ğŸ—ï¸More homes for Bristol! ğŸ  Work has started on our newest site with Vistry Group 

We're transforming a former school site in Hengrove - empty for over a decade - into a community of 200 new sustainable homes. 
 
Half of the 130 homes built in the first phase will be affordable, for social rent and shared ownership. The other half will be sold on the open market. 
 
Phase two will be a 70-home extra care facility for older people with care and support needs.

Weâ€™re incredibly proud of this development, which will transform empty brownfield land into much needed new homes for people young and old. 

It's the fourth Goram Homes site in construction, meaning we're now building around 600 homes. And we were thrilled to share progress with Cllr Barry Parsons and Cllr Andrew Brown âœ… Bristol City Council
author: Goram Homes

postContent:
Work has begun on Vistry Group and Goram Homes newest joint venture site in Bristol.
 
The development will transform a former school site off New Fosseway Road in Hengrove, which has been empty for over a decade, into a community of 200 new sustainable homes.
 
Featuring a mix of one to four bedroom homes, the energy efficient properties will include solar panels and air source heat pumps, alongside electric car charging points.
 
Half of the 130 homes built in the first phase will be affordable housing, for social rent and shared ownership, while the other half will be sold on the open market.
 
Phase two of the site will be a 70-home extra care facility for older people with care and support needs who wish to maintain their independence with the assurance of on-site care.

 Dear valued Contractor,

postContent:
Being made redundant sucks. Dealing with two redundancies in your household at the same time is downright scary. 


Mortified to hear about the Smartcomm Ltd administration a couple of weeks' ago. 

This has directly affected a few people in my network, but none more so than Lucy Fleming and Jamie Brown.

Two very talented young professionals who have lost their entire household income in one fell swoop. 

As an engaged couple, while they should be planning their wedding, they find themselves at the mercy of the market during a very challenging time. 

Lucy is looking ideally for a Bid Coordinator/Manager role within the AV/IT industry, but is open to every opportunity.

Jamie is looking for IT Manager or similar role within any industry.

They're both looking for roles based in High Wycombe, Marlow, Maidenhead or Remote.

Be a good human and please like, comment and share this post to support them in working through this very uncertain time.
author: Daley Robinson

postContent:
PLEASE STOP OVERPAYING FOR YOUR GROUP PROTECTION INSURANCES. 

I don't often write on LinkedIn, but I felt compelled to after helping a prospect last week who had two businesses each with a full suite of Group Protection Insurances (Group Life, Group Income Protection and Group Critical Illness) looked after by a large household name broker. 

This broker charged a fixed fee of over Â£2,400 (plus VAT) per policy, no matter the size of the plan (some of the premiums were only Â£1k a year so the broker charge was equivalent to over 150% commission!). All-in-all the client was heading towards a fee bill north of Â£17k! 

I am delighted to say this 'prospect' is now a happy Excellect client paying a fraction of this by way of a small transparent premium-linked commission paid through their monthly premiums. 

If you are paying your broker a fee for your Group Protection policies please send me a PM, I would be delighted to review this for you. 

#excellect #everyonebenefits #insurancebroking #insurancebroker #exorbitantfees #treatingcustomersfairly #groupprotection #grouplifeassurance #groupincomeprotection #groupcriticallillness

*6 month Job Opportunity - Business strategy and business development*  Secondment? Sabbatical?  Change of career?  Something entirely different? 

Table Top Travels is a brilliant initiative to have come out of the work Alive have done with the University of Bristol as part of the Connecting Through Culture project.

Tabletop Travels is a multi-sensory travel experience in the form of a gift box, co-designed with and for older people who are isolated at home. Recipients have been telling us how the experience has boosted their emotional wellbeing. 

UK Research and Innovation is supporting us from April to September 2025 to establish a sustainable social enterprise. We are looking for someone to join our small team to help us grow. You would lead on business strategy and developing relationships with corporate sponsors and community partners. Your role is instrumental in getting Tabletop Travels to those for whom it will make a real difference. The job is at the School of Education, Bristol University but can be done remotely and is offered at 3 or 4 days a week at Â£41k pro rata. There are opportunities to continue beyond the period of this funding. 

To have a chat call Tot Foster on 07973917655.

This is an amazing opportunity that would suit someone looking to do something different, with business and sales experience but wanting to market something that  does help improve people's wellbeing. 

Could you share a member of staff with us for 6 months to help launch a new product and support a charity?  Please share this opportunity - it's a great opportunity for the right person.

And whenever I ask â€œWhy did you choose Cobus?â€ the answers tend to fall into three categories.

Trust

Clients know weâ€™ll deliver to critical deadlines with cost certainty so we donâ€™t go over budget. Whether itâ€™s a full-scale fit-out or a single-floor refurbishment, they trust us to get it right, because weâ€™ve done it before. 

Simplicity

Our proven four step methodology, means our clients donâ€™t have to juggle contractors, suppliers, and multiple timelines. We give them one team, one point of contact, one seamless process.

Relationships

We take time to understand what each client actually needs. We stay involved, stay accountable, and stay connected, even after the project is complete.

Thatâ€™s why so many of our clients return for future work. And itâ€™s what we pride ourselves on most.

postContent:
Long post incoming (and believe it or not, this is the trimmed down version of the one sent to my team ğŸ˜‰)

This month marks my 10 year work anniversary with The Letting Game! I was just 22 years old when I joined the team as a Tenancy Co-ordinator. Never did I think that I would still be here 10 years later as Managing Director! 

To mark the occasion, I wanted to shareÂ 10 things I've learnt during my time with The Letting Game! 

1. Stay in your own lane
There's a great quote by Robin Sharma that says,Â "Run your own race. Who cares what others are doing? The only question that matters is: Am I progressing?"Â Â It's very easy to compare ourselves to others. Success comes from persistence and staying true to your own unique path.

2. Honesty is the best policy
Honesty is foundational to building trust. When there's no trust, there are doubts. We're all human, we all make mistakes and it's OK to admit them when we do. 
 
3. Trust your gut
Learning to "trust my gut" has been the single, most invaluable lesson - and not just on a professional level.

4. Hard work pays off
To me, hard work means putting inÂ consistentÂ effort, time and energy. It's not about exerting yourself to the point of burn-out (although I've been guilty of this at times!), but more about being intentional and committed to success. 

5. Stay open to learning
Knowledge is power, right?! But no matter how much you know, there is always more we can learn. Every industry evolves and every person we meet, has experiences we can learn from. 

6. Team work really does make the dream work
Once upon a time I thought I could do it all, I was sometimes afraid to let people in but as the business grew, I started to learn the importance of collaboration. Working together leads to higher productivity and better morale!

7. Take time to reflect
I believe this is a skill which is largely underestimated, and only in more recent years have I really understood its value. Creating space to reflect has been one of the most important parts of my professional, and personal development. It's led me to making better decisions, build stronger relationships and lead the business more effectively.

8. Wellness matters
I'm very passionate about this one! Eating well, staying hydrated, moving and getting enough sleep isÂ essentialÂ for performance. I've seen the difference in my own performance when I've prioritised these habits. 

9. You don't grow in your comfort zone
My biggest learnings have come from my greatest challenges. I've certainly learnt to embrace the challenges along the way. Through being uncomfortable I've become more resilient which has helped me to adapt to this ever-changing industry and workplace.

10.Â Don't sweat the small stuff
This is a powerful one, and it's all about prioritisation and perspective. Focussing on the bigger picture has helped me to focus on what truly matters. It's a lesson in resilience and accepting the inevitable - not everything is in our control! #workmilestone

author: Jack Aldridge

postContent:
I have now applied for over 400 jobs and not even 1 interview!!!. 

The jobs I have applied for are not just at my anticipated salary level that I would like, but literally anything to help me pay my monthly bills . 
This is not just via LinkedInâ€¦ via lots of different sources. 

For the first time in my life, I can even more so see why some people just canâ€™t cope with this level of stress anxiety and pure desperation. Not only that but also abandonment by people who I thought would help and support me when I supported them in their time of need - you know who you are. 

To meet monthly living costs and just â€˜surviveâ€™ day to day is now becoming too much for me and I am sure many others feel the same. 

Tears are rolling down my face as I am typing this. I am at a total loss how I can pay my monthly bills and literally keep going. I feel lost and vulnerable and I am not afraid to share that. 

Why is it so hard to get a job? I have so much to offer a company and have worked so hard to get the experience I have gained, I am proud of my accomplishments. 

Please no horrible comments (trust me, I have had my fair share of them). I am just a person who wants a job to get by in life. That is all

#opentoconnect #openfornewopportunities #openforjobs #helpwanted #needajob

This was a great project to be part of, Now finally finished the testing and is in use for KiwiRail. 

Consisted of 2 conveyors with a custom-designed hopper to be loaded directly with an excavator and then loading into connected MFS wagons that can store 20 tons each. 
This setup helped speed up the process due to it being used in an 8.5 km tunnel and in a tight environment. 
NZ Conveyors supplied and installed all the components. 
Many thanks to those involved in this project. David Sauvageon Curran Fabrication and Design Ltd. EMF Switchboards OMC Power Equipment Coveya Ltd Barry Thompson Christian Matthews and many more

postContent:
Iâ€™m proud that Ecology Building Society has published its first Net Zero Transition Plan , as part of our Annual Report & Accounts for 2024 (https://lnkd.in/e6Em6gkc).

As a mutual founded to build a greener society and challenge the norms in financial services, we want to show leadership in our ambitions to reduce our own environmental impact.

And itâ€™s important weâ€™re transparent about our own journey to net zero, so we can share our learnings with our Members and peers.

I hope our Net Zero Transition Plan demonstrates how we continue to live our values and lead by example to show our sector that there can be other ways to do business.

The plan - created by Ecologyâ€™s Sustainability Lead, Stephanie Landymore, in partnership with teams across the Society - also illustrates that reaching net zero is not a linear journey.

In 2024, our financed emissions (carbon emissions from the homes we lend on) rose by almost 40% - on numbers alone this looks like bad news. But the rise is explained by the fact that last year we lent to more borrowers with the least energy-efficient properties. 

Ecology mortgages are enabling these Members to bring their homes up to a higher environmental standard, a reminder of the impact our lending can achieve.

While we move with the times and invest in the future of Ecology, this impact-led lending shows why weâ€™re needed today as much as when we were founded back in 1981.

In the face of the climate and ecological emergency, sadly the need for action has become no less urgent over the past four decades.

postContent:
Iâ€™ve long held the belief that as human beings we each have our own operating system; our own eco system (way of life that fits us) from which we survive and thrive. There is no one size, one fix, fits all. 
â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦
Life may throw curveballs our way. This is out of our control. What is in our control is building a foundation based on resilience and robustness so we can survive the storm. Remember, setbacks are not roadblocks, but rather opportunities for growth and change. The more you learn about yourself and the world around you, the more confident and educated on life you are going to be. 
â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦
I spent years researching stoicism & Buddhism, the cultural aspects of many countries, various philosophy concepts and religious scripts. I applied what I found useful for me alongside facing my own adversity in a plethora of ways. In doing so I arrived at some understanding of how to overcome adversity. I have come to learn that experience is the coin of the realm and the only knowledge that endures. 
â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦
After a few decades in the making, I am launching my mentoring services. The Practical Philosopher. It is an opportunity for me to make some meaning from all my challenges by sharing with others how I overcame them. https://lnkd.in/e935F9em 
â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦
Itâ€™s a platform for working with me to help you find your own eco system so you can find more contentment, peace, and acceptance. It will require you to hold your feet to the fire and may get uncomfortable at times. But if you are ready, we can work to create your own peaceful garden.
â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦
I will post more insights and hard-earned wisdom. You can drop me a DM or email to discuss my services. Visit my website for more information on group or one to one mentoring and testimonials.
author: Tony Terranova

postContent:
In May 2019, six of us with support crew/cameraman cycled 1,000 miles from John Oâ€™ Groats Scotland to Landsâ€™ End Cornwall in 3 days.Â Prior to/after the event more film footage was created. 
â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦
It was our intention to put together a true-life story of my wife Jenny and our familyâ€™s journey with Huntingtonâ€™s Diseases (HD). The documentary will be inspirational, and reality based aimed at raising awareness for HD and funds to finance the cure.

The funds we collected from the event went to UCL London (who are working on the cure). Covid combined with Jenny needing more care support derailed our efforts.

postContent:
Thank you everyone for the birthday messages I am grateful and humbled that you remembered. 
â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦.
With age comes wisdom due to all the mistakes and failures and wrong decisions we have made. The German proverb says, â€œtoo old too soon too wise too lateâ€. 
â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦.
For me I can say that your wealth is your health, it gives you a freedom you will not recognize until you have lost it. Make your physical, mental, emotional, and spiritual wellbeing your number 1 priority. That way you can be the best version of you and help your loved ones and others.
â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦â€¦.
You can always make more money, but you can make your time so choose who and how you spend it wisely. AND â€œif you have the ability to make a lot of moneyâ€- then do it and give lots of it away to those who need it and got dealt a shit card in life.

postContent:
The Bus Shelter Project, Dorset is a fantastic intiative which provides a pathway out of homelessness. On Tuesday I was invited to the opening of Phase 2 where I got to see first hand the difference those involved are making to peoples lives. 
Whilst we can be proud of our contribution at NewSpace, the real praise goes to those behind the scenes and especially the volunteers who dedicate their hearts and time to helping others  less fortunate than ourselves, everyday.
I was really humbled by my visit and left with a better appreciation of the root causes of homelessness and that in a cruel twist of events, often outside of our control, anyone could end up homeless. I was surprised to learn that much of the addiction we associate with homelessness is not the root cause and that people develop addictions on the streets to numb the pain of being homeless and the events that led to it, which are often so heartbreaking. I donâ€™t know what I would do if I lost my family, they are my life and my purpose. 
I also came to appreciate that people experiencing homelessness must be some of the most resilient people in our society and it shouldnâ€™t define who they are. 
Surely we can do more to prevent homelessness in the UK and provide a better root out of it. We all need shelter and support from family, friends and community. The Bus Project provides all of that and importantly a second chance. Every city should have the equivalent of The Bus Shelter Project in Dorset.

postContent:
As we reach the end of April we come to the end of Appraisal season, I have seen so many posts on linked in about the negativity of this time and the lack of value placed in appraisals. As the CEO it is the one document I read for every single staff member in our organisation. Why is this? It is the voice of the staff member (they write the first section) and provides a real indication of where each of our staff are at and how we are doing as an organisation in relation to them, it sets aspirations for the following year and the commitments we are all making to the organisation and our own development.
 
This didnâ€™t happen overnight we have been building a culture of positivity around appraisals. Spending time in culture conversations understanding the value of appraisals and building trust, to enable the team to feel they can be honest in them. We provide training every year for managers so they understand how to deliver the process, and get the right approach.
 
The question that always comes in these discussions is who is doing your appraisal? The answer is the chair of trustees, his reflections on the last year and his challenges to me on the plans for the future and my areas for development definitely set the tone for success of the charity. Donâ€™t underestimate the value of appraisals that are done well, they are an essential tool!
author: Tracy Clark

postContent:
ğŸŒŸ New Role Announcement ğŸŒŸ
Iâ€™m incredibly proud to share that Iâ€™ve been offered the opportunity to become an EDI Champion alongside my current role as Data Manager at Young Gloucestershire.
Equity, Diversity, and Inclusion isnâ€™t just something I care about professionallyâ€”itâ€™s something Iâ€™ve lived.
Iâ€™ve faced many moments in my journey where I didnâ€™t feel like I belonged. In a previous role, I often felt inadequate because of where I came fromâ€”and I now realise I was undervalued and underpaid, taken advantage of because I didnâ€™t have the confidence (or the privilege) to advocate for myself.
One moment Iâ€™ll never forget: being told, â€œYouâ€™ve done well, considering where youâ€™ve come from.â€
 At the time, I didnâ€™t know what to say. It was deeply hurtful and patronisingâ€”and it reinforced the idea that my background made me â€œless than.â€ That comment, and many others like it, stuck with meâ€”not because they define me, but because they remind me why this work is so necessary.
Growing up mixed-race in a single-parent household, losing my mother at 16, and fighting for custody of my younger sister while facing food insecurity and systemic barriers shaped who I am. My sister, who is part of the LGBTQ+ community, and my extended family in Gloucester have all experienced exclusion and racial prejudiceâ€”and those realities have fuelled my drive to create meaningful change.
As an EDI Champion, I will be committed to building spaces where no one feels small, silenced, or â€œless thanâ€ because of who they are or where they come from. I want to help create environments where every story matters, and every voice is valued.
Thank you to Young Gloucestershire for this opportunity and for recognising the importance of lived experience. This role isnâ€™t just a titleâ€”itâ€™s a responsibility I will carry with pride and purpose. ğŸ’›
#EDIChampion #EquityDiversityInclusion #YoungGloucestershire #RepresentationMatters #LivedExperience #KnowYourWorth #InclusionMatters #BreakingBarriers #NewBeginnings
author: Carmel Wlodarczyk

postContent:
At Meningitis Now we're in the middle of the managed chaos of an office #downsize and #refurb.

If you know our charity, you may know that we've been based at Fern House in #Stroud for nearly forty years. We're not moving, but recent shifts towards #hybrid and #digital ways of working have lessened our need for physical space - so we're reducing our #office and warehouse footprint and modernising our environment with the generous and creative help of Abbey Business Interiors.

These changes will save more than Â£100k over the next five years, enabling us to focus on what really matters - saving lives and rebuilding futures.

And some things won't change either - such as our beautiful and important #Remembrance Garden here at Fern House. 

So - as you can see from the pics, we're packing up anything that's old and unwanted (really?!) and getting fit for the future! 

#MarieKondo

postContent:
What a fantastic night for us tonight at the SoGlos - Gloucestershire's leading media brand Awards. 

We are extremely proud to have won the Charity of the Year award following our most successful
year of fundraising last year which was also our 30th year. 

Peter Hickman, now in his nineties took on the challenge of fundraising for a new childrenâ€™s hospital for the County & it opened in 2004. The charity then supported special schools of which there are now 14 in Gloucestershire who need sensory rooms, play areas & vehicles. 

Pied Piper support childrenâ€™s mental health provisions, wish holidays for children with life limiting illnesses with their families & equipment & nurses training bursaries on the Childrenâ€™s Unit. 

We couldnâ€™t do this without amazing support from the public & local businesses as well as dedicated Trustees & Volunteers. 

This award goes to everyone involved at Pied Piper ğŸ‘ğŸ‘

Katy Price Kelly Bennett-Ramsay Julie Kent MBE Marcus Gomery Jonathan Viney Cathryn Hage Louise Taylor Francesca Cole Ben Caton

An award winning project from last year demonstrating efficiency throughout. 

Automated low chemical filtration system and rain water harvesting to enable water neutrality.

Fully insulated shell with solar and heat retaining cover system, neatly hidden into a discrete pit housing.

Set in a contemporary tropic garden area with a stunning Dutch barn style modern home.
author: Max Wilson

postContent:
RHS Malvern Spring Festival 2025 is officially open to the public!

Here's a throwback to "It Doesn't Have To Cost The Earth", one of last year's gold medal winners. 
This garden was designed with sustainability and biodiversity in mind, and the need to reinstate habitats for wildlife impacted by property construction. The chosen materials include our Recycled Bespoke Harewood Stackers, Recycled Glass Sand, Somerset Buff Selfbinda, and Bespoke Bird Bath Boulders. 

Credits: 
Designed and built by Michael Lote

postContent:
We can't believe that Chelsea Flower Show is just around the corner! Our involvement began ten years ago in 2015, but the excitement about being involved in many incredible projects never changes. 

To celebrate the upcoming show, we're sharing some photos of "A Swiss Sanctuary", a dreamy garden inspired by the Alpine and Mediterranean planting to illustrate and celebrate the countryâ€™s distinctive and rich landscapes. Our Glacial Feature Stone replicates the majestic Swiss mountains, while the body of water represents the many lakes the country is renowned for. We have also contributed with our Chatsworth Organic Paving, Dartmoor Grey Selfbinda and Reclaimed Granite Kerb. 

Credits: 
Designed by Lilly Gomm 
Built by Collinson's Landscaping
